href="/wiki/N%C3%B9ng_people" title="N&#249;ng people">N&#249;ng</a> </li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 5.3% Others</li></ul>\n</div></li></ul></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Religion <div style="font-weight:normal;display:inline;"></div></th><td><div class="plainlist"><ul><li style="white-space:nowrap;">73.2% <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_folk_religion" title="Vietnamese folk religion">Folk</a> or <a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">Irreligious</a></li><li style="white-space:nowrap;">12.2% <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" style="white-space:nowrap;">0.1% Other religions<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBielefeldt2014_3-0"><a 1945</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">&#8226;&#160;<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Geneva_Conference_(1954)" numbers in Vietnam">Calling code</a></th><td><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_Vietnam" title="Telephone numbers in Vietnam">+84</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166" title="ISO domain">Internet TLD</a></th><td><a href="/wiki/.vn" title=".vn">.vn</a></td></tr></tbody></table>\n<table class="metadata mbox-small noprint selfref" role="presentation" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000;width: 22em;">\n<tbody><tr>\n<td class="mbox-image"><img alt="" data-file-height="219" data-file-width="144" decoding="async" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Chu_nom.svg/26px-Chu_nom.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Chu_nom.svg/39px-Chu_nom.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Chu_nom.svg/52px-Chu_nom.svg.png 2x" width="26"/></td>\n<td class="mbox-text plainlist" style="vertical-align:middle; font-size:95%;"><b>This article contains <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese</a> text.</b> Without proper <a href="/wiki/Help:Multilingual_support_(East_Asian)" title="Help:Multilingual support (East Asian)">rendering support</a>, you may see <a href="/wiki/Specials_(Unicode_block)#Replacement_character" title="Specials (Unicode block)">question marks, boxes, or other symbols</a> instead of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ch%E1%BB%AF_n%C3%B4m" title="Ch&#7919; n&#244;m">ch&#7919; n&#244;m</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ch%E1%BB%AF_H%C3%A1n" title="Ch&#7919; H&#225;n">ch&#7919; H&#225;n</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_alphabet" title="Vietnamese alphabet">ch&#7919; qu&#7889;c ng&#7919;</a>.</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p><b>Vietnam</b> (<span class="nowrap"><small><a href="/wiki/British_English" title="British English">UK</a>: </small><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/&#716;/: secondary stress follows">&#716;</span><span title="\'v\' in \'vie\'">v</span><span title="/j/: \'y\' in \'yes\'">j</span><span title="/&#603;/: \'e\' in \'dress\'">&#603;</span><span title="\'t\' in \'tie\'">t</span><span title="/&#712;/: primary stress follows">&#712;</span><span title="\'n\' in \'nigh\'">n</span><span title="/&#230;/: \'a\' in \'bad\'">&#230;</span><span title="\'m\' in \'my\'">m</span></span>, <wbr/>-<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/&#712;/: primary stress follows">&#712;</span><span title="\'n\' in \'nigh\'">n</span><span title="/&#593;&#720;/: \'a\' in \'father\'">&#593;&#720;</span><span title="\'m\' in \'my\'">m</span></span>/</a></span></span>, <span class="nowrap"><small><a href="/wiki/American_English" title="American English">US</a>: </small><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/&#716;/: secondary stress follows">&#716;</span><span title="\'v\' in \'vie\'">v</span><span title="/i&#720;/: \'ee\' in \'fleece\'">i&#720;</span><span title="/&#601;/: \'a\' in \'about\'">&#601;</span><span title="\'t\' in \'tie\'">t</span></span>-/</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Vietnam.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e8/En-us-Vietnam.ogg" title="En-us-Vietnam.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span></span>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJones2011532_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJones2011532-11">[9]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese</a>: <i lang="vi">Vi&#7879;t Nam</i> <small>pronounced&#160;</small><span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Vietnamese" title="Help:IPA/Vietnamese">[v&#238;&#601;t n&#257;&#720;m]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vietnam.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/cb/Vietnam.ogg" title="Vietnam.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span>), officially the <b>Socialist Republic of Vietnam</b> (<a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese</a>: <i lang="vi">C&#7897;ng h&#242;a x&#227; h&#7897;i ch&#7911; ngh&#297;a Vi&#7879;t Nam</i>), is the easternmost country on the <a href="/wiki/Indochina" title="Indochina">Indochina Peninsula</a>. With an estimated 94.6 million inhabitants as of  2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, it is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population" title="List of countries and dependencies by population">15th most populous country in the world</a>. Vietnam is bordered by <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> to the north, <a href="/wiki/Laos" title="Laos">Laos</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cambodia" title="Cambodia">Cambodia</a> to the west, part of <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">Thailand</a> to the southwest, and the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malaysia" title="Malaysia">Malaysia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a> across the <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea" title="South China Sea">South China Sea</a> to the east and southeast.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[n 3]</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/Capital_city" title="Capital city">capital city</a> has been <a href="/wiki/Hanoi" title="Hanoi">Hanoi</a> since the <a href="/wiki/Reunification_Day" title="Reunification Day">reunification</a> of <a href="/wiki/North_Vietnam" title="North Vietnam">North</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_Vietnam" title="South Vietnam">South Vietnam</a> in 1976, while its most populous city is <a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_City" title="Ho Chi Minh City">Ho Chi Minh City</a>.\n</p><p>The first state of Vietnam dated back to the third millennium BC, when ancient Vietnamese people established a monarchy governing tribes residing in modern-day Northern provinces of the country. The independent state was annexed by <a href="/wiki/Nanyue" title="Nanyue">Nanyue</a> in the second century BC. It subsequently became an administrative division of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Imperial_China" title="Imperial China">Imperial China</a> for over a millennium from 111 BC to 939 AD, when a new independent feudal state emerged following Vietnamese victory in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_B%E1%BA%A1ch_%C4%90%E1%BA%B1ng_(938)" title="Battle of B&#7841;ch &#272;&#7857;ng (938)">battle of B&#7841;ch &#272;&#7857;ng</a> against the Chinese. Successive <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Vietnamese_monarchs" title="List of Vietnamese monarchs">imperial dynasties</a> flourished as the nation expanded geographically and politically into Southeast Asia, until the Indochina Peninsula was <a href="/wiki/French_Indochina" title="French Indochina">colonised by the French</a> in mid-19th century.\n</p><p>French Indochina saw the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_invasion_of_French_Indochina" title="Japanese invasion of French Indochina">Japanese occupation</a> in 1940 amidst the escalation of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>. Following Japanese defeat in 1945, the Vietnamese fought French rule in the <a href="/wiki/First_Indochina_War" title="First Indochina War">First Indochina War</a>. On 2 September 1945, Vietnamese revolutionary leader <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/H%E1%BB%93_Ch%C3%AD_Minh" title="H&#7891; Ch&#237; Minh">H&#7891; Ch&#237; Minh</a> declared Vietnam\'s independence from France and therefrom established a provisional communist state. After nine years of war, the Vietnamese declared victory in the decisive <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_%C4%90i%E1%BB%87n_Bi%C3%AAn_Ph%E1%BB%A7" title="Battle of &#272;i&#7879;n Bi&#234;n Ph&#7911;">battle of &#272;i&#7879;n Bi&#234;n Ph&#7911;</a> in 1954. The nation was thereafter divided into two rival states, communist <a href="/wiki/North_Vietnam" title="North Vietnam">North</a>&#8212;the Democratic Republic of Vietnam, and anti-communist <a href="/wiki/South_Vietnam" title="South Vietnam">South</a>&#8212;the Republic of Vietnam. Conflicts intensified in the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a> with <a href="/wiki/Role_of_the_United_States_in_the_Vietnam_War" title="Role of the United States in the Vietnam War">extensive US intervention</a> in support of South Vietnam from 1965 to 1973. The war ended with <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Saigon" title="Fall of Saigon">North Vietnamese victory</a> in 1975.\n</p><p>North and South Vietnam were then reunified under a communist government in 1976. The newly established country remained impoverished and politically isolated until 1986, when the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Vietnam" title="Communist Party of Vietnam">Communist Party</a> initiated a series of <a href="/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BB%95i_M%E1%BB%9Bi" title="&#272;&#7893;i M&#7899;i">economic and political reforms</a> that facilitated Vietnamese integration into the world economy. By 2010, Vietnam had established <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Vietnam" title="Foreign relations of Vietnam">diplomatic relations</a> with 178 countries. Since 2000, Vietnam\'s GDP growth rate has been among the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_real_GDP_growth_rate" title="List of countries by real GDP growth rate">highest in the world</a>. Its successful economic reforms resulted in its joining the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">WTO</a> in 2007. Vietnam is also a member of the <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Southeast_Asian_Nations" title="Association of Southeast Asian Nations">Association of Southeast Asian Nations</a> (ASEAN), <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation</a> (APEC) and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_Internationale_de_la_Francophonie" title="Organisation Internationale de la Francophonie">Organisation Internationale de la Francophonie</a> (OIF).\n</p>\n<div class="toc" id="toc"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2>Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Etymology"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Etymology</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#History"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">History</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-3"><a href="#Prehistory"><span class="tocnumber">2.1</span> <span class="toctext">Prehistory</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-4"><a href="#Dynastic_Vietnam"><span class="tocnumber">4.4</span> <span class="toctext">Human rights</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-18"><a href="#Economy"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Economy</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-19"><a href="#Agriculture"><span class="tocnumber">5.1</span> <span class="toctext">Agriculture</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-20"><a href="#Science_and_technology"><span class="tocnumber">5.2</span> <span class="toctext">Science and technology</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-21"><a href="#Tourism"><span class="tocnumber">5.3</span> <span class="toctext">Tourism</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-22"><a href="#Infrastructure"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">Infrastructure</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-23"><a href="#Transport"><span class="tocnumber">6.1</span> <span class="toctext">Transport</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-24"><a href="#Energy"><span class="tocnumber">6.2</span> <span class="toctext">Energy</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-25"><a href="#Water_supply_and_sanitation"><span class="tocnumber">6.3</span> <span class="toctext">Water supply and sanitation</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-26"><a href="#Health"><span class="tocnumber">6.4</span> <span class="toctext">Health</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-27"><a href="#Education"><span class="tocnumber">6.5</span> <span class="toctext">Education</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-28"><a href="#Demographics"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">Demographics</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-29"><a href="#Urbanisation"><span class="tocnumber">7.1</span> <span class="toctext">Urbanisation</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-30"><a href="#Religion"><span class="tocnumber">7.2</span> <span class="toctext">Religion</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-31"><a href="#Languages"><span class="tocnumber">7.3</span> <span class="toctext">Languages</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-32"><a href="#Culture"><span class="tocnumber">8</span> <span class="toctext">Culture</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-33"><a href="#Literature"><span class="tocnumber">8.1</span> <span class="toctext">Literature</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-34"><a href="#Music"><span class="tocnumber">8.2</span> <span class="toctext">Music</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-35"><a href="#Cuisine"><span class="tocnumber">8.3</span> <span class="toctext">Cuisine</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-36"><a href="#Media"><span class="tocnumber">8.4</span> <span class="toctext">Media</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-37"><a href="#Holidays_and_festivals"><span class="tocnumber">8.5</span> <span class="toctext">Holidays and festivals</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-38"><a href="#Sports"><span class="tocnumber">8.6</span> <span class="toctext">Sports</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-39"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">9</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-40"><a href="#Footnotes"><span class="tocnumber">10</span> <span class="toctext">Footnotes</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-41"><a href="#Notes_and_references"><span class="tocnumber">11</span> <span class="toctext">Notes and references</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-42"><a href="#Notes"><span class="tocnumber">11.1</span> <span class="toctext">Notes</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-43"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">11.2</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-44"><a href="#Print"><span class="tocnumber">11.2.1</span> <span class="toctext">Print</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-45"><a href="#Legislation,_case_law_and_government_source"><span class="tocnumber">11.2.2</span> <span class="toctext">Legislation, case law and government source</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-46"><a href="#Academic_publications"><span class="tocnumber">11.2.3</span> <span class="toctext">Academic publications</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-47"><a href="#News_and_magazines"><span class="tocnumber">11.2.4</span> <span class="toctext">News and magazines</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-48"><a href="#Websites"><span class="tocnumber">11.2.5</span> <span class="toctext">Websites</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-49"><a href="#Free_content"><span class="tocnumber">11.2.6</span> <span class="toctext">Free content</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-50"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">12</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</div>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Names_of_Vietnam" title="Names of Vietnam">Names of Vietnam</a></div>\n<p>The name <i lang="vi" title="Vietnamese language text">Vi&#7879;t Nam</i> (<small>Vietnamese pronunciation:&#160;</small><span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Vietnamese" title="Help:IPA/Vietnamese">[vi&#601;&#768;t na&#720;m]</a></span>) is a variation of <i lang="vi" title="Vietnamese language text"><a href="/wiki/Nanyue" title="Nanyue">Nam Vi&#7879;t</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Chinese_language" title="Chinese language">Chinese</a>: <span lang="zh"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%8D%97%E8%B6%8A" title="wikt:&#21335;&#36234;">&#21335;&#36234;</a></span>; <a href="/wiki/Pinyin" title="Pinyin">pinyin</a>: <i><span lang="zh-Latn-pinyin">N&#225;nyu&#232;</span></i>; literally "Southern <i>Vi&#7879;t</i>"), a name that can be traced back to the <a href="/wiki/Tri%E1%BB%87u_dynasty" title="Tri&#7879;u dynasty">Tri&#7879;u dynasty</a> of the 2nd century BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWoods200238_14-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWoods200238-14">[11]</a></sup> The word <i>Vi&#7879;t</i> originated as a shortened form of <a href="/wiki/Baiyue" title="Baiyue">B&#225;ch Vi&#7879;t</a> (<a href="/wiki/Chinese_language" title="Chinese language">Chinese</a>: <span lang="zh"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%99%BE%E8%B6%8A" title="wikt:&#30334;&#36234;">&#30334;&#36234;</a></span>; <a href="/wiki/Pinyin" title="Pinyin">pinyin</a>: <i><span lang="zh-Latn-pinyin">B&#462;iyu&#232;</span></i>), a group of people then living in southern China and Vietnam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYue_Hashimoto19721_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYue_Hashimoto19721-15">[12]</a></sup> The form "Vietnam" (<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r867716940">.mw-parser-output .vi-nom{font-family:"Han-Nom Gothic","Nom Na Tong","Han-Nom Ming","Han-Nom Minh","HAN NOM A","HAN NOM B","Han-Nom Kai","Sun-ExtA","Sun-ExtB","Ming-Lt-HKSCS-UNI-H","Ming-Lt-HKSCS-ExtB","HanaMinA","HanaMinB","HanaMin","MingLiU","MingLiU-ExtB","MingLiU HKSCS","MingLiU HKSCS-ExtB","SimSun","SimSun-ExtB","FZKaiT-Extended","FZKaiT-Extended(SIP)",sans-serif}.mw-parser-output .vi-nom .ext{font-family:"Han-Nom Gothic","Han-Nom Ming","Han-Nom Minh","BabelStone Han","Sun-ExtB","MingLiU HKSCS-ExtB","Ming-Lt-HKSCS-ExtB","HanaMinB","Han-Nom Kai",sans-serif}</style><span lang="vi-Hani" title="Vietnamese language text"><span class="vi-nom"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%B6%8A%E5%8D%97" title="wikt:&#36234;&#21335;">&#36234;&#21335;</a></span></span>) is first recorded in the 16th-century oracular poem <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S%E1%BA%A5m_Tr%E1%BA%A1ng_Tr%C3%ACnh" title="S&#7845;m Tr&#7841;ng Tr&#236;nh">S&#7845;m Tr&#7841;ng Tr&#236;nh</a></i>. The name has also been found on 12 <a href="/wiki/Stele" title="Stele">steles</a> carved in the 16th and 17th centuries, including one at Bao Lam Pagoda in <a href="/wiki/Haiphong" title="Haiphong">H&#7843;i Ph&#242;ng</a> that dates to 1558.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPhan1976510_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhan1976510-16">[13]</a></sup> In 1802, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Ph%C3%BAc_%C3%81nh" title="Nguy&#7877;n Ph&#250;c &#193;nh">Nguy&#7877;n Ph&#250;c &#193;nh</a> (later become Emperor Gia Long) established the <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_dynasty" title="Nguy&#7877;n dynasty">Nguy&#7877;n dynasty</a>, and in the second year, he asked the <a href="/wiki/Jiaqing_Emperor" title="Jiaqing Emperor">Jiaqing Emperor</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Qing_dynasty" title="Qing dynasty">Qing dynasty</a> to confer him the title \'King of Nam Viet/Nanyue\' (<span lang="zh" title="Chinese language text">&#21335;&#36234;</span> in Chinese) after seizing Annam\'s ruling power but the latter refused since the name was related to <a href="/wiki/Zhao_Tuo" title="Zhao Tuo">Zhao Tuo</a>\'s Nanyue which includes the regions of <a href="/wiki/Guangxi" title="Guangxi">Guangxi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Guangdong" title="Guangdong">Guangdong</a> in southern China by which the Qing Emperor decide to call the area as "Viet Nam" instead.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-etymology_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-etymology-18">[n 4]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOoi2004932_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOoi2004932-19">[15]</a></sup> Between 1804 and 1813, the name Vietnam was used officially by Emperor Gia Long.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-etymology_18-1"><a href="#cite_note-etymology-18">[n 4]</a></sup> It was revived in the early 20th century by <a href="/wiki/Phan_B%E1%BB%99i_Ch%C3%A2u" title="Phan B&#7897;i Ch&#226;u">Phan B&#7897;i Ch&#226;u</a>\'s <i><a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Loss_of_Vietnam" title="History of the Loss of Vietnam">History of the Loss of Vietnam</a></i>, and later by the <a href="/wiki/Vi%E1%BB%87t_Nam_Qu%E1%BB%91c_D%C3%A2n_%C4%90%E1%BA%A3ng" title="Vi&#7879;t Nam Qu&#7889;c D&#226;n &#272;&#7843;ng">Vietnamese Nationalist Party</a> (VNQD&#272;).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETonnessonAntlov1996117_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETonnessonAntlov1996117-20">[16]</a></sup> The country was usually called Annam until 1945, when both the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Vietnam" title="Empire of Vietnam">imperial government</a> in <a href="/wiki/Hu%E1%BA%BF" title="Hu&#7871;">Hu&#7871;</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Vi%E1%BB%87t_Minh" title="Vi&#7879;t Minh">Vi&#7879;t Minh</a> government in Hanoi adopted <i lang="vi" title="Vietnamese language text">Vi&#7879;t Nam</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETonnessonAntlov1996126_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETonnessonAntlov1996126-21">[17]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Vietnam" title="History of Vietnam">History of Vietnam</a></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">Prehistory</span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:DrumFromSongDaVietnamDongSonIICultureMid1stMilleniumBCEBronze.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1360" data-file-width="1680" decoding="async" height="178" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/DrumFromSongDaVietnamDongSonIICultureMid1stMilleniumBCEBronze.jpg/220px-DrumFromSongDaVietnamDongSonIICultureMid1stMilleniumBCEBronze.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/DrumFromSongDaVietnamDongSonIICultureMid1stMilleniumBCEBronze.jpg/330px-DrumFromSongDaVietnamDongSonIICultureMid1stMilleniumBCEBronze.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/DrumFromSongDaVietnamDongSonIICultureMid1stMilleniumBCEBronze.jpg/440px-DrumFromSongDaVietnamDongSonIICultureMid1stMilleniumBCEBronze.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:DrumFromSongDaVietnamDongSonIICultureMid1stMilleniumBCEBronze.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%B4ng_S%C6%A1n_drums" title="&#272;&#244;ng S&#417;n drums">&#272;&#244;ng S&#417;n</a> bronze drum, <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">&#8201;800 BC</span>.</div></div></div>\n<p>Archaeological excavations have revealed the existence of humans in what is now Vietnam as early as the <a href="/wiki/Paleolithic" title="Paleolithic">Paleolithic</a> age. <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_erectus" title="Homo erectus">Homo erectus</a></i> fossils dating to around 500,000 BC have been found in caves in <a href="/wiki/L%E1%BA%A1ng_S%C6%A1n_Province" title="L&#7841;ng S&#417;n Province">L&#7841;ng S&#417;n</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ngh%E1%BB%87_An_Province" title="Ngh&#7879; An Province">Ngh&#7879; An</a> provinces in northern Vietnam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcKinney2009_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcKinney2009-22">[18]</a></sup> The oldest <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_sapiens" title="Homo sapiens">Homo sapiens</a></i> fossils from mainland Southeast Asia are of <a href="/wiki/Middle_Pleistocene" title="Middle Pleistocene">Middle Pleistocene</a> provenance, and include isolated tooth fragments from Tham Om and Hang Hum.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAkazawaAokiKimura1992321_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAkazawaAokiKimura1992321-23">[19]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERabett2012109_24-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERabett2012109-24">[20]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDennellPorr201441_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDennellPorr201441-25">[21]</a></sup> Teeth attributed to <i>Homo sapiens</i> from the <a href="/wiki/Late_Pleistocene" title="Late Pleistocene">Late Pleistocene</a> have also been found at Dong Can,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMatsumuraYonedaYukioOxenham200812_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMatsumuraYonedaYukioOxenham200812-26">[22]</a></sup> and from the Early <a href="/wiki/Holocene" title="Holocene">Holocene</a> at Mai Da Dieu,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMatsumuraLan_CuongKim_ThuyAnezaki2001_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMatsumuraLan_CuongKim_ThuyAnezaki2001-27">[23]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOxenhamTayles200636_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOxenhamTayles200636-28">[24]</a></sup> Lang Gao<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEanon.198516_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEanon.198516-29">[25]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKarlstr&#246;mK&#228;ll&#233;n200283_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKarlstr&#246;mK&#228;ll&#233;n200283-30">[26]</a></sup> and Lang Cuom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOxenhamBuckley2015329_31-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOxenhamBuckley2015329-31">[27]</a></sup> By about 1,000 BC, the development of wet-<a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a> cultivation and <a href="/wiki/Bronze" title="Bronze">bronze</a> casting in the <a href="/wiki/Ma_River" title="Ma River">Ma River</a> and <a href="/wiki/Red_River_(Asia)" title="Red River (Asia)">Red River</a> floodplains led to the flourishing of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%B4ng_S%C6%A1n_culture" title="&#272;&#244;ng S&#417;n culture">&#272;&#244;ng S&#417;n culture</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHigham1984_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHigham1984-32">[28]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENang_ChungGiang_Hai201731_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENang_ChungGiang_Hai201731-33">[29]</a></sup> notable for its elaborate bronze <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%B4ng_S%C6%A1n_drums" title="&#272;&#244;ng S&#417;n drums">&#272;&#244;ng S&#417;n drums</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEde_LaetHerrmann1996408_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEde_LaetHerrmann1996408-34">[30]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECal&#242;200951_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECal&#242;200951-35">[31]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKiernan201731_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKiernan201731-36">[32]</a></sup> At this time, the early Vietnamese kingdoms of <a href="/wiki/V%C4%83n_Lang" title="V&#259;n Lang">V&#259;n Lang</a> and <a href="/wiki/%C3%82u_L%E1%BA%A1c" title="&#194;u L&#7841;c">&#194;u L&#7841;c</a> appeared, and the culture\'s influence spread to other parts of <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Maritime_Southeast_Asia" title="Maritime Southeast Asia">Maritime Southeast Asia</a>, throughout the first millennium BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECal&#242;200951_35-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECal&#242;200951-35">[31]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECookeLiAnderson201146_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECookeLiAnderson201146-37">[33]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Dynastic_Vietnam">Dynastic Vietnam</span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Territorial_expansion_of_Vietnam_from_L%C3%BD_dynasty_to_Nguy%E1%BB%85n_dynasty_(1009%E2%80%931834).gif"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="715" data-file-width="430" decoding="async" height="366" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Territorial_expansion_of_Vietnam_from_L%C3%BD_dynasty_to_Nguy%E1%BB%85n_dynasty_%281009%E2%80%931834%29.gif/220px-Territorial_expansion_of_Vietnam_from_L%C3%BD_dynasty_to_Nguy%E1%BB%85n_dynasty_%281009%E2%80%931834%29.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Territorial_expansion_of_Vietnam_from_L%C3%BD_dynasty_to_Nguy%E1%BB%85n_dynasty_%281009%E2%80%931834%29.gif/330px-Territorial_expansion_of_Vietnam_from_L%C3%BD_dynasty_to_Nguy%E1%BB%85n_dynasty_%281009%E2%80%931834%29.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/85/Territorial_expansion_of_Vietnam_from_L%C3%BD_dynasty_to_Nguy%E1%BB%85n_dynasty_%281009%E2%80%931834%29.gif 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Territorial_expansion_of_Vietnam_from_L%C3%BD_dynasty_to_Nguy%E1%BB%85n_dynasty_(1009%E2%80%931834).gif" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Territorial expansion of Vietnam, 1009&#8211;1834</div></div></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BB%93ng_B%C3%A0ng_dynasty" title="H&#7891;ng B&#224;ng dynasty">H&#7891;ng B&#224;ng dynasty</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/H%C3%B9ng_kings" title="H&#249;ng kings">H&#249;ng kings</a> is considered the first Vietnamese state, known in Vietnamese as V&#259;n Lang.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPelley2002151_38-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPelley2002151-38">[34]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECottrell200914_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECottrell200914-39">[35]</a></sup> In 257 BC, the last H&#249;ng king was defeated by Th&#7909;c Ph&#225;n, who consolidated the <a href="/wiki/L%E1%BA%A1c_Vi%E1%BB%87t" title="L&#7841;c Vi&#7879;t">L&#7841;c Vi&#7879;t</a> and <a href="/wiki/%C3%82u_Vi%E1%BB%87t" title="&#194;u Vi&#7879;t">&#194;u Vi&#7879;t</a> tribes to form the <a href="/wiki/%C3%82u_L%E1%BA%A1c" title="&#194;u L&#7841;c">&#194;u L&#7841;c</a>, proclaiming himself <a href="/wiki/An_D%C6%B0%C6%A1ng_V%C6%B0%C6%A1ng" title="An D&#432;&#417;ng V&#432;&#417;ng">An D&#432;&#417;ng V&#432;&#417;ng</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE&#272;&#7913;c_Tr&#7847;nTh&#432;_H&#224;20008_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE&#272;&#7913;c_Tr&#7847;nTh&#432;_H&#224;20008-40">[36]</a></sup> In 179 BC, a Chinese general named <a href="/wiki/Zhao_Tuo" title="Zhao Tuo">Zhao Tuo</a> defeated An D&#432;&#417;ng V&#432;&#417;ng and consolidated &#194;u L&#7841;c into <a href="/wiki/Nanyue" title="Nanyue">Nanyue</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENang_ChungGiang_Hai201731_33-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENang_ChungGiang_Hai201731-33">[29]</a></sup> However, Nanyue was itself <a href="/wiki/Southward_expansion_of_the_Han_dynasty" title="Southward expansion of the Han dynasty">incorporated into the empire</a> of the Chinese <a href="/wiki/Han_dynasty" title="Han dynasty">Han dynasty</a> in 111 BC after the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Han%E2%80%93Nanyue_War" title="Han&#8211;Nanyue War">Han&#8211;Nanyue War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOoi2004932_19-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOoi2004932-19">[15]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYao201662_41-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYao201662-41">[37]</a></sup> For the next thousand years, what is now northern Vietnam remained mostly under <a href="/wiki/Chinese_domination_of_Vietnam" title="Chinese domination of Vietnam">Chinese rule</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHolmgren1980_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHolmgren1980-42">[38]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor198330_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor198330-43">[39]</a></sup> Early independence movements, such as those of the <a href="/wiki/Tr%C6%B0ng_Sisters" title="Tr&#432;ng Sisters">Tr&#432;ng Sisters</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lady_Tri%E1%BB%87u" title="Lady Tri&#7879;u">Lady Tri&#7879;u</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPelley2002177_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPelley2002177-44">[40]</a></sup> were only temporarily successful,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECottrell200915_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECottrell200915-45">[41]</a></sup> though the region gained a longer period of independence as V&#7841;n Xu&#226;n under the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anterior_L%C3%BD_dynasty" title="Anterior L&#253; dynasty">Anterior L&#253; dynasty</a> between AD 544 and 602.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETh&#225;i_Nguy&#234;nM&#7915;ng_Nguy&#7869;&#770;n195833_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETh&#225;i_Nguy&#234;nM&#7915;ng_Nguy&#7869;&#770;n195833-46">[42]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChesneaux196620_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChesneaux196620-47">[43]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEanon.197224_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEanon.197224-48">[44]</a></sup> By the early 10th century, Vietnam had gained autonomy, but not sovereignty, under the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kh%C3%BAc_family" title="Kh&#250;c family">Kh&#250;c family</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETuyet_TranReid200632_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETuyet_TranReid200632-49">[45]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In AD 938, the Vietnamese lord <a href="/wiki/Ng%C3%B4_Quy%E1%BB%81n" title="Ng&#244; Quy&#7873;n">Ng&#244; Quy&#7873;n</a> defeated the forces of the Chinese <a href="/wiki/Southern_Han" title="Southern Han">Southern Han</a> state at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_B%E1%BA%A1ch_%C4%90%E1%BA%B1ng_(938)" title="Battle of B&#7841;ch &#272;&#7857;ng (938)">B&#7841;ch &#272;&#7857;ng River</a> and achieved full independence for Vietnam after a millennium of Chinese domination.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHi&#7867;&#770;n_L&#234;200365_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHi&#7867;&#770;n_L&#234;200365-50">[46]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHong_LienSharrock201455_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHong_LienSharrock201455-51">[47]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKiernan2017226_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKiernan2017226-52">[48]</a></sup> Renamed as &#272;&#7841;i Vi&#7879;t (<i>Great Viet</i>), the nation enjoyed a golden era under the L&#253; and <a href="/wiki/Tr%E1%BA%A7n_dynasty" title="Tr&#7847;n dynasty">Tr&#7847;n</a> dynasties. During the rule of the Tr&#7847;n Dynasty, &#272;&#7841;i Vi&#7879;t repelled three <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasions_of_Vietnam" title="Mongol invasions of Vietnam">Mongol invasions</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECottrell200916_53-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECottrell200916-53">[49]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHong_LienSharrock201495_54-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHong_LienSharrock201495-54">[50]</a></sup> Meanwhile, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Vietnam" title="Buddhism in Vietnam">Buddhism</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81y%C4%81na" title="Mah&#257;y&#257;na">Mah&#257;y&#257;na</a> tradition flourished and became the state religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKiernan2017226_52-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKiernan2017226-52">[48]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeyes1995183_55-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeyes1995183-55">[51]</a></sup> Following the 1406&#8211;7 <a href="/wiki/Ming%E2%80%93H%E1%BB%93_War" title="Ming&#8211;H&#7891; War">Ming&#8211;H&#7891; War</a> which overthrew the <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BB%93_dynasty" title="H&#7891; dynasty">H&#7891; dynasty</a>, Vietnamese independence was <a href="/wiki/Fourth_Chinese_domination_of_Vietnam" title="Fourth Chinese domination of Vietnam">briefly interrupted</a> by the Chinese <a href="/wiki/Ming_dynasty" title="Ming dynasty">Ming dynasty</a>, but was restored by <a href="/wiki/L%C3%AA_L%E1%BB%A3i" title="L&#234; L&#7907;i">L&#234; L&#7907;i</a>, the founder of the <a href="/wiki/L%C3%AA_dynasty" title="L&#234; dynasty">L&#234; dynasty</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHong_LienSharrock2014111_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHong_LienSharrock2014111-56">[52]</a></sup> The Vietnamese dynasties reached their zenith in the L&#234; dynasty of the 15th century, especially during the reign of Emperor <a href="/wiki/L%C3%AA_Th%C3%A1nh_T%C3%B4ng" title="L&#234; Th&#225;nh T&#244;ng">L&#234; Th&#225;nh T&#244;ng</a> (1460&#8211;1497).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHong_LienSharrock2014120_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHong_LienSharrock2014120-57">[53]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKiernan2017265_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKiernan2017265-58">[54]</a></sup> Between the 11th and 18th centuries, Vietnam expanded southward in a process known as <i lang="vi" title="Vietnamese language text">nam ti&#7871;n</i> ("<a href="/wiki/History_of_Vietnam#Champa" title="History of Vietnam">southward expansion</a>"),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAndersonWhitmore2014158_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAndersonWhitmore2014158-59">[55]</a></sup> eventually conquering the kingdom of <a href="/wiki/Champa" title="Champa">Champa</a> and part of the <a href="/wiki/Khmer_Empire" title="Khmer Empire">Khmer Empire</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVo201113_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVo201113-60">[56]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOoiAnh_Tuan2015212_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOoiAnh_Tuan2015212-61">[57]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPhuong_Linh201639_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhuong_Linh201639-62">[58]</a></sup>\n</p><p>From the 16th century onward, civil strife and frequent political infighting engulfed much of Vietnam. First, the Chinese-supported <a href="/wiki/M%E1%BA%A1c_dynasty" title="M&#7841;c dynasty">M&#7841;c dynasty</a> challenged the L&#234; dynasty\'s power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAndersonWhitmore2014174_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAndersonWhitmore2014174-63">[59]</a></sup> After the M&#7841;c dynasty was defeated, the L&#234; dynasty was nominally reinstalled, but actual power was divided between the northern <a href="/wiki/Tr%E1%BB%8Bnh_lords" title="Tr&#7883;nh lords">Tr&#7883;nh lords</a> and the southern <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_lords" title="Nguy&#7877;n lords">Nguy&#7877;n lords</a>, who engaged in a <a href="/wiki/Tr%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%93Nguy%E1%BB%85n_War" title="Tr&#7883;nh&#8211;Nguy&#7877;n War">civil war</a> for more than four decades before a truce was called in the 1670s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELeonard1984131_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELeonard1984131-64">[60]</a></sup> During this time, the Nguy&#7877;n expanded southern Vietnam into the <a href="/wiki/Mekong_Delta" title="Mekong Delta">Mekong Delta</a>, annexing the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Highlands_(Vietnam)" title="Central Highlands (Vietnam)">Central Highlands</a> and the Khmer lands in the Mekong Delta.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVo201113_60-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVo201113-60">[56]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPhuong_Linh201639_62-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhuong_Linh201639-62">[58]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOoi2004356_65-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOoi2004356-65">[61]</a></sup> The division of the country ended a century later when the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/T%C3%A2y_S%C6%A1n" title="T&#226;y S&#417;n">T&#226;y S&#417;n</a> brothers established a new dynasty. However, their rule did not last long, and they were defeated by the remnants of the Nguy&#7877;n lords, led by <a href="/wiki/Gia_Long" title="Gia Long">Nguy&#7877;n &#193;nh</a> and aided by the French.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPageSonnenburg2003723_66-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPageSonnenburg2003723-66">[62]</a></sup> Nguy&#7877;n &#193;nh unified Vietnam, and established the <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_dynasty" title="Nguy&#7877;n dynasty">Nguy&#7877;n dynasty</a>, ruling under the name <a href="/wiki/Gia_Long" title="Gia Long">Gia Long</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOoi2004356_65-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOoi2004356-65">[61]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="French_Indochina">French Indochina</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Cochinchina_Campaign" title="Cochinchina Campaign">Cochinchina Campaign</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sino-French_War" title="Sino-French War">Sino-French War</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tonkin_campaign" title="Tonkin campaign">Tonkin campaign</a>, <a href="/wiki/French_Indochina" title="French Indochina">French Indochina</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Vietnam" title="Empire of Vietnam">Empire of Vietnam</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Indochine_fran%C3%A7aise_(1913).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="827" data-file-width="500" decoding="async" height="364" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Indochine_fran%C3%A7aise_%281913%29.jpg/220px-Indochine_fran%C3%A7aise_%281913%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Indochine_fran%C3%A7aise_%281913%29.jpg/330px-Indochine_fran%C3%A7aise_%281913%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Indochine_fran%C3%A7aise_%281913%29.jpg/440px-Indochine_fran%C3%A7aise_%281913%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Indochine_fran%C3%A7aise_(1913).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/French_Indochina" title="French Indochina">French Indochina</a> in 1913</div></div></div>\n<p>Since the 1500s, the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese</a> have become acquainted with Vietnamese coast where they reportedly erected a <a href="/wiki/Stele" title="Stele">stele</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A0m_Islands" title="Ch&#224;m Islands">Ch&#224;m Islands</a> to mark their presence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETu&#7845;n_Ho&#225;ng200750_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETu&#7845;n_Ho&#225;ng200750-67">[63]</a></sup> By 1533, the Portuguese began to land into the Vietnamese delta but were forced to leave due to local turmoil and fighting. They also had less interest in the territory than in both kingdoms in China and Japan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETu&#7845;n_Ho&#225;ng200750_67-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETu&#7845;n_Ho&#225;ng200750-67">[63]</a></sup> After having successfully settled <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Macau" title="Portuguese Macau">Macau</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Nagasaki" title="Portuguese Nagasaki">Nagasaki</a> to began the profitable Macau-Japan trade, the Portuguese began to be involved in trade with <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BB%99i_An" title="H&#7897;i An">H&#7897;i An</a> where many Portuguese traders and their <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholicism" title="Catholicism">Catholic</a> missionaries set their foot into the Vietnamese kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETu&#7845;n_Ho&#225;ng200750_67-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETu&#7845;n_Ho&#225;ng200750-67">[63]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Dutch_Empire" title="Dutch Empire">Dutch</a> also tried to establish contact with Vietnam through the central part of Quinam in 1601 but failed to mantain long presence there after several violent encounter with the locals. The <a href="/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company" title="Dutch East India Company">Dutch East India Company</a> (VOC) only managed to establish official relations with <a href="/wiki/Tonkin" title="Tonkin">Tonkin</a> in the spring of 1637 after leaving <a href="/wiki/Dejima" title="Dejima">Dejima</a> in Japan to establishing trade for <a href="/wiki/Silk" title="Silk">silk</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETu&#7845;n_Ho&#225;ng200752_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETu&#7845;n_Ho&#225;ng200752-68">[64]</a></sup> Meanwhile, the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">English</a> first attempt through the <a href="/wiki/East_India_Company" title="East India Company">East India Company</a> (EIC) to establishing contact with H&#7897;i An in 1613 are failed following a violent incident involving their merchant but the English return to establishing relations with Tonkin by 1672 where they were allowed to reside in <a href="/wiki/H%C6%B0ng_Y%C3%AAn" title="H&#432;ng Y&#234;n">Ph&#7889; Hi&#7871;n</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETu&#7845;n_Ho&#225;ng200753_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETu&#7845;n_Ho&#225;ng200753-69">[65]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ExpositionHanoi1902_GrandPalais_(1).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="473" data-file-width="759" decoding="async" height="137" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/ExpositionHanoi1902_GrandPalais_%281%29.jpg/220px-ExpositionHanoi1902_GrandPalais_%281%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/ExpositionHanoi1902_GrandPalais_%281%29.jpg/330px-ExpositionHanoi1902_GrandPalais_%281%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/ExpositionHanoi1902_GrandPalais_%281%29.jpg/440px-ExpositionHanoi1902_GrandPalais_%281%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ExpositionHanoi1902_GrandPalais_(1).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Grand_Palais_(Hanoi)" title="Grand Palais (Hanoi)">Grand Palais</a> built for the 1902&#8211;1903 <a href="/wiki/Hanoi_exhibition" title="Hanoi exhibition">world\'s fair</a> as <a href="/wiki/Hanoi" title="Hanoi">Hanoi</a> became French Indochina\'s capital.</div></div></div>\n<p>From between 1615&#8211;1753, French traders also have engaged in trade in the area around <a href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%A0ng_Trong" title="&#272;&#224;ng Trong">&#272;&#224;ng Trong</a> and actively spreading missionaries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELi199889_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELi199889-70">[66]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELockard2010479_71-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELockard2010479-71">[67]</a></sup> Following the detention of several missionaries as the Vietnamese kingdom feel threatened with the continuous <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christianisation" title="Christianisation">Christianisation</a> activities,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcLeod199122_72-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcLeod199122-72">[68]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/French_Navy" title="French Navy">French Navy</a> received approval from their government to intervene in Vietnam in 1834 with the aim to free imprisoned Catholic missionaries from a kingdom that was perceived as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Xenophobic" title="Xenophobic">xenophobic</a> against foreign influence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWoods2002245_73-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWoods2002245-73">[69]</a></sup> Vietnam\'s kingdom independence was then gradually <a href="/wiki/French_colonial_empire" title="French colonial empire">eroded by France</a> which was aided by the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish</a> and large Catholic militias in a series of military conquests between 1859 and 1885.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECortada199429_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECortada199429-74">[70]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeith201250_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeith201250-75">[71]</a></sup> In 1862, the southern third of the country became the French colony of <a href="/wiki/French_Cochinchina" title="French Cochinchina">Cochinchina</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcLeod199161_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcLeod199161-76">[72]</a></sup> By 1884, the entire country had come under French rule, with the central and northern parts of Vietnam separated in the two protectorates of <a href="/wiki/Annam_(French_protectorate)" title="Annam (French protectorate)">Annam</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tonkin_(French_protectorate)" title="Tonkin (French protectorate)">Tonkin</a>. The three Vietnamese entities were formally integrated into the union of <a href="/wiki/French_Indochina" title="French Indochina">French Indochina</a> in 1887.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOoi2004520_77-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOoi2004520-77">[73]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECook2001396_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECook2001396-78">[74]</a></sup> The French administration imposed significant political and cultural changes on Vietnamese society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrankum_Jr.2011172_79-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrankum_Jr.2011172-79">[75]</a></sup> A Western-style system of modern education was developed and Catholicism was propagated widely.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENhu_Nguyen201637_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENhu_Nguyen201637-80">[76]</a></sup> Most French settlers in Indochina were concentrated in Cochinchina, particularly in the region of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saigon" title="Saigon">Saigon</a> and in <a href="/wiki/Hanoi" title="Hanoi">Hanoi</a>, the capital of the colony.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERichardson1876269_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERichardson1876269-81">[77]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Guerrillas of the royalist <a href="/wiki/C%E1%BA%A7n_V%C6%B0%C6%A1ng_movement" title="C&#7847;n V&#432;&#417;ng movement">C&#7847;n V&#432;&#417;ng movement</a> massacred around a third of Vietnam\'s Christian population during the colonial period as part of their rebellion against French rule,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeith201253_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeith201253-82">[78]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnh_Ngo201671_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnh_Ngo201671-83">[79]</a></sup> but were defeated in the 1890s after a decade of resistance by the Catholics as a reprisal of their earlier massacres.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEQuach_Langlet1991360_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEQuach_Langlet1991360-84">[80]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERamsay2008171_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERamsay2008171-85">[81]</a></sup> Another large-scale rebellion, the <a href="/wiki/Th%C3%A1i_Nguy%C3%AAn_uprising" title="Th&#225;i Nguy&#234;n uprising">Th&#225;i Nguy&#234;n uprising</a> was also suppressed heavily.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZinoman2000_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZinoman2000-86">[82]</a></sup> The French developed a <a href="/wiki/Plantation_economy" title="Plantation economy">plantation economy</a> to promote the export of <a href="/wiki/Tobacco" title="Tobacco">tobacco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indigo_dye" title="Indigo dye">indigo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tea" title="Tea">tea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Coffee" title="Coffee">coffee</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELim201433_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELim201433-87">[83]</a></sup> however, they largely ignored the increasing demands for civil rights and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Self-government" title="Self-government">self-government</a>. A nationalist political movement soon emerged, with leaders such as <a href="/wiki/Phan_B%E1%BB%99i_Ch%C3%A2u" title="Phan B&#7897;i Ch&#226;u">Phan B&#7897;i Ch&#226;u</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Phan_Ch%C3%A2u_Trinh" title="Phan Ch&#226;u Trinh">Phan Ch&#226;u Trinh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Phan_%C4%90%C3%ACnh_Ph%C3%B9ng" title="Phan &#272;&#236;nh Ph&#249;ng">Phan &#272;&#236;nh Ph&#249;ng</a>, Emperor <a href="/wiki/H%C3%A0m_Nghi" title="H&#224;m Nghi">H&#224;m Nghi</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/H%E1%BB%93_Ch%C3%AD_Minh" title="H&#7891; Ch&#237; Minh">H&#7891; Ch&#237; Minh</a> fighting or calling for independence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELargo2002112_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELargo2002112-88">[84]</a></sup> This resulted in the 1930 <a href="/wiki/Y%C3%AAn_B%C3%A1i_mutiny" title="Y&#234;n B&#225;i mutiny">Y&#234;n B&#225;i mutiny</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Vi%E1%BB%87t_Nam_Qu%E1%BB%91c_D%C3%A2n_%C4%90%E1%BA%A3ng" title="Vi&#7879;t Nam Qu&#7889;c D&#226;n &#272;&#7843;ng">Vietnamese Nationalist Party</a> (VNQD&#272;) which was suppressed heavily by the French. The mutiny caused an irreparable split that resulted in many leading members of the organisation becoming <a href="/wiki/Communism" title="Communism">communist</a> converts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKh&#225;nh_Hu&#7923;nh198698_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKh&#225;nh_Hu&#7923;nh198698-89">[85]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOdellCastillo200882_90-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOdellCastillo200882-90">[86]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThomas2012_91-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThomas2012-91">[87]</a></sup> The French maintained full control over their colonies until World War II, when the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_War" title="Pacific War">war in the Pacific</a> led to the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_invasion_of_French_Indochina" title="Japanese invasion of French Indochina">Japanese invasion of French Indochina</a> in 1940. Afterwards, the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Japanese Empire</a> was allowed to station its troops in Vietnam while permitting the pro-<a href="/wiki/Vichy_France" title="Vichy France">Vichy French</a> colonial administration to continue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiller1990293_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiller1990293-92">[88]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGettlemanFranklinYoungFranklin19954_93-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGettlemanFranklinYoungFranklin19954-93">[89]</a></sup> Japan exploited Vietnam\'s natural resources to support its military campaigns, culminating in a <a href="/wiki/Japanese_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_in_French_Indochina" title="Japanese coup d\'&#233;tat in French Indochina">full-scale takeover of the country</a> in March 1945 and the <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_Famine_of_1945" title="Vietnamese Famine of 1945">Vietnamese Famine of 1945</a>, which caused up to two million deaths.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThanh_Ni&#234;n2015_94-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThanh_Ni&#234;n2015-94">[90]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Net2015_95-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Net2015-95">[91]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="First_Indochina_War">First Indochina War</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/First_Indochina_War" title="First Indochina War">First Indochina War</a>; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_Vietnam" title="Democratic Republic of Vietnam">Democratic Republic of Vietnam</a>; <a href="/wiki/State_of_Vietnam" title="State of Vietnam">State of Vietnam</a>; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/State_of_Vietnam_referendum,_1955" title="State of Vietnam referendum, 1955">State of Vietnam referendum, 1955</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Operation_Passage_to_Freedom" title="Operation Passage to Freedom">Operation Passage to Freedom</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:First_Indochina_War_map_1954_en.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="822" data-file-width="580" decoding="async" height="312" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/First_Indochina_War_map_1954_en.svg/220px-First_Indochina_War_map_1954_en.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/First_Indochina_War_map_1954_en.svg/330px-First_Indochina_War_map_1954_en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/First_Indochina_War_map_1954_en.svg/440px-First_Indochina_War_map_1954_en.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:First_Indochina_War_map_1954_en.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Situation of the <a href="/wiki/First_Indochina_War" title="First Indochina War">First Indochina War</a> at the end of 1954.<br/><div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #EEA270; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;Areas under <a href="/wiki/Vi%E1%BB%87t_Minh" title="Vi&#7879;t Minh">Vi&#7879;t Minh</a> control</div> <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #D3B2DB; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;Areas under <a href="/wiki/French_Foreign_Legion" title="French Foreign Legion">French</a> control</div> <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #00000; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;Vi&#7879;t Minh guerrilla encampment / fighting</div></div></div></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hanoi_in_the_1940s.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="806" data-file-width="1100" decoding="async" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Hanoi_in_the_1940s.jpg/220px-Hanoi_in_the_1940s.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Hanoi_in_the_1940s.jpg/330px-Hanoi_in_the_1940s.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Hanoi_in_the_1940s.jpg/440px-Hanoi_in_the_1940s.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hanoi_in_the_1940s.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Hanoi Tr&#224;ng Ti&#7873;n Street during the French colonial era, the <a href="/wiki/Hanoi_Opera_House" title="Hanoi Opera House">Opera House</a> can be seen at the beginning of the road, <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">&#8201;1940s</span>.</div></div></div>\n<p>In 1941, the <a href="/wiki/Vi%E1%BB%87t_Minh" title="Vi&#7879;t Minh">Vi&#7879;t Minh</a> which is a nationalist liberation movement based on a Communist ideology emerged under the Vietnamese revolutionary leader <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/H%E1%BB%93_Ch%C3%AD_Minh" title="H&#7891; Ch&#237; Minh">H&#7891; Ch&#237; Minh</a> who sought independence for Vietnam from France and the end of the Japanese occupation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJoes199295_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJoes199295-96">[92]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPike2011192_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPike2011192-97">[93]</a></sup> Following the military defeat of Japan and the fall of its puppet <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Vietnam" title="Empire of Vietnam">Empire of Vietnam</a> in August 1945, anarchy, rioting and murder were widespread since Saigon\'s administrative services collapsed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGunn2014270_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGunn2014270-98">[94]</a></sup> The Vi&#7879;t Minh occupied <a href="/wiki/Hanoi" title="Hanoi">Hanoi</a> and proclaimed a provisional government, which asserted national independence on 2 September.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPike2011192_97-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPike2011192-97">[93]</a></sup> Earlier in July, the  <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allies</a> decide to divide Indochina into half at the <a href="/wiki/16th_parallel_north" title="16th parallel north">16th parallel</a> to allow <a href="/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek" title="Chiang Kai-shek">Chiang Kai-shek</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949)" title="Republic of China (1912&#8211;1949)">Republic of China</a> receive Japanese surrender in the north while <a href="/wiki/Louis_Mountbatten,_1st_Earl_Mountbatten_of_Burma" title="Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma">Lord Louis Mountbatten</a> of the British receive the surrender in the south with the Allies agreeing that Indochina belonged to France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENeville2007175_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENeville2007175-99">[95]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESmith20076_100-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESmith20076-100">[96]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:French_Indochina_post_partition.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="457" data-file-width="300" decoding="async" height="335" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/French_Indochina_post_partition.png/220px-French_Indochina_post_partition.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/60/French_Indochina_post_partition.png 1.5x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:French_Indochina_post_partition.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Partition_(politics)" title="Partition (politics)">Partition</a> of French Indochina after the <a href="/wiki/1954_Geneva_Conference" title="1954 Geneva Conference">1954 Geneva Conference</a></div></div></div>\n<p>However, as the French were weakened as a result of <a href="/wiki/German_military_administration_in_occupied_France_during_World_War_II" title="German military administration in occupied France during World War II">German occupation</a>, the British-<a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">Indian</a> forces together with the remaining Japanese <a href="/wiki/Southern_Expeditionary_Army_Group" title="Southern Expeditionary Army Group">Southern Expeditionary Army Group</a> were used to maintain order and to help France re-establish control through the <a href="/wiki/War_in_Vietnam_(1945%E2%80%9346)" title="War in Vietnam (1945&#8211;46)">1945&#8211;1946 War in Vietnam</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENeville2007124_101-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENeville2007124-101">[97]</a></sup> H&#7891; Ch&#237; Minh at the time chose a moderate stance to avoid military conflict with France by which he asked the French to withdraw their colonial administrators, and asked for aid from French professors and engineers to help build a modern independent Vietnam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPike2011192_97-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPike2011192-97">[93]</a></sup> These requests, including the idea for independence, however could not be accepted by the <a href="/wiki/Provisional_Government_of_the_French_Republic" title="Provisional Government of the French Republic">Provisional Government of the French Republic</a>, which dispatched the <a href="/wiki/French_Far_East_Expeditionary_Corps" title="French Far East Expeditionary Corps">French Far East Expeditionary Corps</a> instead to restore colonial rule, causing the Vi&#7879;t Minh to launch a guerrilla campaign against the French in late 1946.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJoes199295_96-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJoes199295-96">[92]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPike2011192_97-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPike2011192-97">[93]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETonnesson201166_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETonnesson201166-102">[98]</a></sup> Matters also turned worse when the Republic of China gradually fell to the communists in the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Revolution" title="Chinese Communist Revolution">Chinese Communist Revolution</a>. The resulting First Indochina War lasted until July 1954. The defeat of French and <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_National_Army" title="Vietnamese National Army">Vietnamese loyalists</a> in the 1954 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_%C4%90i%E1%BB%87n_Bi%C3%AAn_Ph%E1%BB%A7" title="Battle of &#272;i&#7879;n Bi&#234;n Ph&#7911;">battle of &#272;i&#7879;n Bi&#234;n Ph&#7911;</a> allowed H&#7891; Ch&#237; Minh to negotiate a ceasefire from a favourable position at the subsequent <a href="/wiki/1954_Geneva_Conference" title="1954 Geneva Conference">Geneva Conference</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPike2011192_97-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPike2011192-97">[93]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWaite201289_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWaite201289-103">[99]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The colonial administration was ended and French Indochina was dissolved under the Geneva Accords of 1954 into three countries: Vietnam and the kingdoms of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Cambodia_(1953%E2%80%9370)" title="Kingdom of Cambodia (1953&#8211;70)">Cambodia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Laos" title="Kingdom of Laos">Laos</a>. Vietnam was further divided into North and South administrative regions at the <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_Demilitarized_Zone" title="Vietnamese Demilitarized Zone">Demilitarised Zone</a>, approximately along the <a href="/wiki/17th_parallel_north" title="17th parallel north">17th parallel north</a>, pending elections scheduled for July 1956.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[n 5]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Operation_Passage_to_Freedom" title="Operation Passage to Freedom">300-day period of free movement</a> was permitted, during which almost a million northerners, mainly Catholics, moved south, fearing persecution by the communists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOlson201243_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOlson201243-109">[104]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDK201739_110-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDK201739-110">[105]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Partition_of_Vietnam" title="Partition of Vietnam">partition of Vietnam</a> was not intended to be permanent by the Geneva Accords, which stipulated that Vietnam would be reunited after elections in 1956.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEvan_DijkGraySavranskayaSuri201368_111-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEvan_DijkGraySavranskayaSuri201368-111">[106]</a></sup> However, in 1955, the State of Vietnam\'s Prime Minister, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ng%C3%B4_%C4%90%C3%ACnh_Di%E1%BB%87m" title="Ng&#244; &#272;&#236;nh Di&#7879;m">Ng&#244; &#272;&#236;nh Di&#7879;m</a> toppled <a href="/wiki/B%E1%BA%A3o_%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i" title="B&#7843;o &#272;&#7841;i">B&#7843;o &#272;&#7841;i</a> in a fraudulent referendum organised by his brother <a href="/wiki/Ng%C3%B4_%C4%90%C3%ACnh_Nhu" title="Ng&#244; &#272;&#236;nh Nhu">Ng&#244; &#272;&#236;nh Nhu</a>, and proclaimed himself president of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republic_of_Vietnam" title="Republic of Vietnam">Republic of Vietnam</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEvan_DijkGraySavranskayaSuri201368_111-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEvan_DijkGraySavranskayaSuri201368-111">[106]</a></sup> At that point the internationally recognised <a href="/wiki/State_of_Vietnam" title="State of Vietnam">State of Vietnam</a> effectively ceased to exist and was replaced by the Republic of Vietnam in the south and H&#7891; Ch&#237; Minh\'s <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_Vietnam" title="Democratic Republic of Vietnam">Democratic Republic of Vietnam</a> in the north.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEvan_DijkGraySavranskayaSuri201368_111-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEvan_DijkGraySavranskayaSuri201368-111">[106]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Vietnam_War">Vietnam War</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a> and <a href="/wiki/Role_of_the_United_States_in_the_Vietnam_War" title="Role of the United States in the Vietnam War">Role of the United States in the Vietnam War</a></div>\n<p>Between 1953 and 1956, the North Vietnamese government instituted various agrarian reforms, including "rent reduction" and "<a href="/wiki/Land_reform_in_Vietnam" title="Land reform in Vietnam">land reform</a>", which resulted in significant political oppression.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMo&#239;se201756_112-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMo&#239;se201756-112">[107]</a></sup> During the land reform, testimony from North Vietnamese witnesses suggested a ratio of one execution for every 160 village residents, which extrapolated nationwide would indicate nearly 100,000 executions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETurner1975143_113-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETurner1975143-113">[108]</a></sup> Because the campaign was concentrated mainly in the <a href="/wiki/Red_River_Delta" title="Red River Delta">Red River Delta</a> area, a lower estimate of 50,000 executions became widely accepted by scholars at the time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETurner1975143_113-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETurner1975143-113">[108]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGittinger1959_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGittinger1959-114">[109]</a></sup> However, declassified documents from the Vietnamese and Hungarian archives indicate that the number of executions was much lower than reported at the time, although likely greater than 13,500.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVu2007_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVu2007-115">[110]</a></sup> In the South, Di&#7879;m countered North Vietnamese subversion (including the assassination of over 450 South Vietnamese officials in 1956) by detaining tens of thousands of suspected communists in "political re-education centres".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHeneghan1969160_116-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHeneghan1969160-116">[111]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETurner1975177_117-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETurner1975177-117">[112]</a></sup> This was a ruthless program that incarcerated many non-communists, although it was also successful at curtailing communist activity in the country, if only for a time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrozier1955_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrozier1955-118">[113]</a></sup> The North Vietnamese government claimed that 2,148 individuals were killed in the process by November 1957.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETurner1975174&#8211;178_119-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETurner1975174&#8211;178-119">[114]</a></sup> The pro-Hanoi <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vi%E1%BB%87t_C%E1%BB%99ng" title="Vi&#7879;t C&#7897;ng">Vi&#7879;t C&#7897;ng</a> began a guerrilla campaign in the late 1950s to overthrow Di&#7879;m\'s government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGilbert2013292_120-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGilbert2013292-120">[115]</a></sup> From 1960, the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> and North Vietnam signed treaties providing for further Soviet military support.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJukes1973209_121-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJukes1973209-121">[116]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOlsen200792_122-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOlsen200792-122">[117]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhoo201127_123-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhoo201127-123">[118]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Agent_Orange_Cropdusting.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="509" decoding="async" height="207" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Agent_Orange_Cropdusting.jpg/220px-Agent_Orange_Cropdusting.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Agent_Orange_Cropdusting.jpg/330px-Agent_Orange_Cropdusting.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Agent_Orange_Cropdusting.jpg/440px-Agent_Orange_Cropdusting.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Agent_Orange_Cropdusting.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Three US <a href="/wiki/Fairchild_C-123_Provider" title="Fairchild C-123 Provider">Fairchild UC-123B</a> aircraft spraying <a href="/wiki/Agent_Orange" title="Agent Orange">Agent Orange</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Operation_Ranch_Hand" title="Operation Ranch Hand">Operation Ranch Hand</a> as part of the overall <a href="/wiki/Herbicidal_warfare" title="Herbicidal warfare">herbicidal warfare</a> operation called Trail Dust with the aim to deprive the food and vegetation cover of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vi%E1%BB%87t_C%E1%BB%99ng" title="Vi&#7879;t C&#7897;ng">Vi&#7879;t C&#7897;ng</a>, <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">&#8201;1962&#8211;1971</span>.</div></div></div>\n<p>In 1963, Buddhist discontent with Di&#7879;m\'s regime erupted into <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_crisis" title="Buddhist crisis">mass demonstrations</a>, leading to a violent government crackdown.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMuehlenbeckMuehlenbeck2012221_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMuehlenbeckMuehlenbeck2012221-124">[119]</a></sup> This led to the <a href="/wiki/Cable_243" title="Cable 243">collapse of Di&#7879;m\'s relationship with the United States</a>, and ultimately to the <a href="/wiki/1963_South_Vietnamese_coup" title="1963 South Vietnamese coup">1963 coup</a> in which <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arrest_and_assassination_of_Ng%C3%B4_%C4%90%C3%ACnh_Di%E1%BB%87m" title="Arrest and assassination of Ng&#244; &#272;&#236;nh Di&#7879;m">Di&#7879;m and Nhu were assassinated</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWillbanks201353_125-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWillbanks201353-125">[120]</a></sup> The Di&#7879;m era was followed by more than a dozen successive military governments, before the pairing of Air Marshal <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Cao_K%E1%BB%B3" title="Nguy&#7877;n Cao K&#7923;">Nguy&#7877;n Cao K&#7923;</a> and General <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_V%C4%83n_Thi%E1%BB%87u" title="Nguy&#7877;n V&#259;n Thi&#7879;u">Nguy&#7877;n V&#259;n Thi&#7879;u</a> took control in mid-1965.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDuy_HinhDinh_Tho2015238_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDuy_HinhDinh_Tho2015238-126">[121]</a></sup> Thi&#7879;u gradually outmaneuvered K&#7923; and cemented his grip on power in fraudulent elections in 1967 and 1971.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIssermanBowman200946_127-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIssermanBowman200946-127">[122]</a></sup> Under this political instability, the communists began to gain ground. To support South Vietnam\'s struggle against the communist insurgency, the United States began increasing its contribution of military advisers, using the 1964 <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Tonkin_incident" title="Gulf of Tonkin incident">Gulf of Tonkin incident</a> as a pretext for such intervention.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlterman2005213_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlterman2005213-128">[123]</a></sup> US forces became involved in ground combat operations in 1965, and at their peak they numbered more than 500,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewy1980_129-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewy1980-129">[124]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGibbons2014166_130-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGibbons2014166-130">[125]</a></sup> The US also engaged in <a href="/wiki/Operation_Rolling_Thunder" title="Operation Rolling Thunder">a sustained aerial bombing campaign</a>.
