Meanwhile, <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> and the Soviet Union provided North Vietnam with significant material aid and 15,000 combat advisers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJukes1973209_121-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJukes1973209-121">[116]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOlsen200792_122-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOlsen200792-122">[117]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELi201267_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELi201267-131">[126]</a></sup> Communist forces supplying the Vi&#7879;t C&#7897;ng carried supplies along the <a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_trail" title="Ho Chi Minh trail">H&#7891; Ch&#237; Minh trail</a>, which passed through the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Laos" title="Kingdom of Laos">Kingdom of Laos</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGillet2011_132-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGillet2011-132">[127]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The communists attacked South Vietnamese targets during the 1968 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/T%E1%BA%BFt_Offensive" title="T&#7871;t Offensive">T&#7871;t Offensive</a>. Although the campaign failed militarily, it shocked the American establishment, and turned US public opinion against the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek2018_133-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek2018-133">[128]</a></sup> During the offensive, communist troops <a href="/wiki/Massacre_at_Hu%E1%BA%BF" title="Massacre at Hu&#7871;">massacred over 3,000 civilians</a> at <a href="/wiki/Hu%E1%BA%BF" title="Hu&#7871;">Hu&#7871;</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETurner1975251_134-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETurner1975251-134">[129]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrankum_Jr.2011209_135-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrankum_Jr.2011209-135">[130]</a></sup> Facing an increasing casualty count, <a href="/wiki/Opposition_to_United_States_involvement_in_the_Vietnam_War" title="Opposition to United States involvement in the Vietnam War">rising domestic opposition</a> to the war, and growing international condemnation, the US began <a href="/wiki/Nixon_Doctrine" title="Nixon Doctrine">withdrawing from ground combat roles</a> in the early 1970s. This process also entailed an unsuccessful effort to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vietnamisation" title="Vietnamisation">strengthen and stabilise South Vietnam</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEggleston20141_136-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEggleston20141-136">[131]</a></sup> Following the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Peace_Accords" title="Paris Peace Accords">Paris Peace Accords</a> of 27 January 1973, all American combat troops were withdrawn by 29 March 1973.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHistory2018_137-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHistory2018-137">[132]</a></sup> In December 1974, North Vietnam <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Ph%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Bc_Long" title="Battle of Ph&#432;&#7899;c Long">captured</a> the province of <a href="/wiki/Ph%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Bc_Long_Province" title="Ph&#432;&#7899;c Long Province">Ph&#432;&#7899;c Long</a> and started a <a href="/wiki/1975_Spring_Offensive" title="1975 Spring Offensive">full-scale offensive</a>, culminating in the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Saigon" title="Fall of Saigon">fall of Saigon</a> on 30 April 1975.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETucker2011749_138-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETucker2011749-138">[133]</a></sup> South Vietnam was briefly ruled by a <a href="/wiki/Provisional_Revolutionary_Government_of_the_Republic_of_South_Vietnam" title="Provisional Revolutionary Government of the Republic of South Vietnam">provisional government</a> for almost eight years while under military occupation by North Vietnam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrigham199886_139-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrigham199886-139">[134]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Reunification_and_reforms">Reunification and reforms</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Re-education_camp_(Vietnam)" title="Re-education camp (Vietnam)">Re-education camp (Vietnam)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_boat_people" title="Vietnamese boat people">Vietnamese boat people</a>, and <a href="/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BB%95i_M%E1%BB%9Bi" title="&#272;&#7893;i M&#7899;i">&#272;&#7893;i M&#7899;i</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Parade_Unification.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="427" data-file-width="600" decoding="async" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Parade_Unification.jpg/220px-Parade_Unification.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Parade_Unification.jpg/330px-Parade_Unification.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Parade_Unification.jpg/440px-Parade_Unification.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Parade_Unification.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Reunification parade following the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Saigon" title="Fall of Saigon">fall of Saigon</a>, with the city being renamed as <a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_City" title="Ho Chi Minh City">Ho Chi Minh City</a>, 1975.</div></div></div>\n<p>On 2 July 1976, North and South Vietnam were merged to form the Socialist Republic of Vietnam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_New_York_Times1976_140-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_New_York_Times1976-140">[135]</a></sup> The war left Vietnam devastated, with the total death toll standing at between 966,000 and 3.8 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirschmanPrestonManh_Loi1995_141-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirschmanPrestonManh_Loi1995-141">[136]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShenon1995_142-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShenon1995-142">[137]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEObermeyerMurrayGakidou2008_143-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEObermeyerMurrayGakidou2008-143">[138]</a></sup> In the aftermath of the war, under <a href="/wiki/L%C3%AA_Du%E1%BA%A9n" title="L&#234; Du&#7849;n">L&#234; Du&#7849;n</a>\'s administration, there were no mass executions of South Vietnamese who had collaborated with the US and the defunct South Vietnamese government, confounding Western fears.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEElliott2010499,_512&#8211;513_144-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEElliott2010499,_512&#8211;513-144">[139]</a></sup> However, up to 300,000 South Vietnamese were sent to <a href="/wiki/Re-education_camp_(Vietnam)" title="Re-education camp (Vietnam)">re-education camps</a>, where many endured torture, starvation and disease while being forced to perform hard labour.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESaganDenny1982_145-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESaganDenny1982-145">[140]</a></sup> The government embarked on a mass campaign of collectivisation of farms and factories.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpokesman-Review19778_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpokesman-Review19778-146">[141]</a></sup> In 1978, as a response towards the <a href="/wiki/Khmer_Rouge" title="Khmer Rouge">Khmer Rouge</a> who had been invading and massacring Vietnamese residents in the border villages in the districts of <a href="/wiki/An_Giang_Province" title="An Giang Province">An Giang</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ki%C3%AAn_Giang_Province" title="Ki&#234;n Giang Province">Ki&#234;n Giang</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKissi2006144_147-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKissi2006144-147">[142]</a></sup> the Vietnamese military <a href="/wiki/Cambodian%E2%80%93Vietnamese_War" title="Cambodian&#8211;Vietnamese War">invaded Cambodia</a> and removed them from power after overtaking <a href="/wiki/Phnom_Penh" title="Phnom Penh">Phnom Penh</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMeggle2004166_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMeggle2004166-148">[143]</a></sup> The intervention was a success, resulting in the establishment of a new pro-Vietnam socialist government, the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_Kampuchea" title="People\'s Republic of Kampuchea">People\'s Republic of Kampuchea</a> which ruled until 1989.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHampson1996175_149-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHampson1996175-149">[144]</a></sup> This action however worsened relations with China, who had been supporting the Khmer Rouge where they later launched a <a href="/wiki/Sino-Vietnamese_War" title="Sino-Vietnamese War">brief incursion into northern Vietnam</a> in 1979 and causing Vietnam to rely even more heavily on Soviet economic and military aid with the mistrust towards the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_China" title="Government of China">Chinese government</a> began to escalate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhoo2011131_150-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhoo2011131-150">[145]</a></sup>\n</p><p>At the <a href="/wiki/6th_National_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_Vietnam" title="6th National Congress of the Communist Party of Vietnam">Sixth National Congress</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Vietnam" title="Communist Party of Vietnam">Communist Party of Vietnam</a> (CPV) in December 1986, reformist politicians replaced the "old guard" government with new leadership.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBBC_News1997_151-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBBC_News1997-151">[146]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEV&#259;n_Ph&#250;c2014_152-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEV&#259;n_Ph&#250;c2014-152">[147]</a></sup> The reformers were led by 71-year-old <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_V%C4%83n_Linh" title="Nguy&#7877;n V&#259;n Linh">Nguy&#7877;n V&#259;n Linh</a>, who became the party\'s new general secretary.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBBC_News1997_151-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBBC_News1997-151">[146]</a></sup> Linh and the reformers implemented a series of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Free-market" title="Free-market">free-market</a> reforms known as <i lang="vi" title="Vietnamese language text"><a href="/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BB%95i_M%E1%BB%9Bi" title="&#272;&#7893;i M&#7899;i">&#272;&#7893;i M&#7899;i</a></i> ("Renovation") which carefully managed the transition from a <a href="/wiki/Planned_economy" title="Planned economy">planned economy</a> to a "<a href="/wiki/Socialist-oriented_market_economy" title="Socialist-oriented market economy">socialist-oriented market economy</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMurray199724&#8211;25_153-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMurray199724&#8211;25-153">[148]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBich_Loan2007_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBich_Loan2007-154">[149]</a></sup> Though the authority of the state remained unchallenged under <i>&#272;&#7893;i M&#7899;i</i>, the government encouraged private ownership of farms and factories, economic deregulation and foreign investment, while maintaining control over strategic industries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBich_Loan2007_154-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBich_Loan2007-154">[149]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHowe201620_155-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHowe201620-155">[150]</a></sup> The Vietnamese economy subsequently achieved strong growth in agricultural and industrial production, construction, exports and foreign investment despite through these reforms also have caused a rise in income inequality and gender disparities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGoodkind1995_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoodkind1995-156">[151]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGallup2002_157-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGallup2002-157">[152]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWagstaffvan_DoorslaerWatanabe2003_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWagstaffvan_DoorslaerWatanabe2003-158">[153]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Vietnam" title="Geography of Vietnam">Geography of Vietnam</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Geography_of_Vietnam.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="404" data-file-width="404" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Geography_of_Vietnam.jpg/220px-Geography_of_Vietnam.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Geography_of_Vietnam.jpg/330px-Geography_of_Vietnam.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/54/Geography_of_Vietnam.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Geography_of_Vietnam.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Nature attractions in Vietnam, clockwise from top: <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BA%A1_Long_Bay" title="H&#7841; Long Bay">H&#7841; Long Bay</a>, Y&#7871;n River and <a href="/wiki/Ban_Gioc%E2%80%93Detian_Falls" title="Ban Gioc&#8211;Detian Falls">B&#7843;n-Gi&#7889;c Waterfalls</a>.</div></div></div>\n<p>Vietnam is located on the eastern <a href="/wiki/Mainland_Southeast_Asia" title="Mainland Southeast Asia">Indochinese Peninsula</a> between the latitudes <a href="/wiki/8th_parallel_north" title="8th parallel north">8&#176;</a> and <a href="/wiki/24th_parallel_north" title="24th parallel north">24&#176;N</a>, and the longitudes <a href="/wiki/102nd_meridian_east" title="102nd meridian east">102&#176;</a> and <a href="/wiki/110th_meridian_east" title="110th meridian east">110&#176;E</a>. It covers a total area of approximately 331,212&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (127,882&#160;sq&#160;mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-area_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-area-159">[n 6]</a></sup> The combined length of the country\'s land boundaries is 4,639&#160;km (2,883&#160;mi), and its coastline is 3,444&#160;km (2,140&#160;mi) long.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENasuchon20087_160-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENasuchon20087-160">[154]</a></sup> At its narrowest point in the central <a href="/wiki/Qu%E1%BA%A3ng_B%C3%ACnh_Province" title="Qu&#7843;ng B&#236;nh Province">Qu&#7843;ng B&#236;nh Province</a>, the country is as little as 50 kilometres (31&#160;mi) across, though it widens to around 600 kilometres (370&#160;mi) in the north.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEProtected_Areas_and_Development_Partnership200313_161-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEProtected_Areas_and_Development_Partnership200313-161">[155]</a></sup> Vietnam\'s land is mostly hilly and densely forested, with level land covering no more than 20%. Mountains account for 40% of the country\'s land area,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFr&#246;hlichSchreinemachersStahrClemens20135_162-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFr&#246;hlichSchreinemachersStahrClemens20135-162">[156]</a></sup> and tropical forests cover around 42%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENatural_Resources_and_Environment_Program199556_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENatural_Resources_and_Environment_Program199556-163">[157]</a></sup> The Red River Delta in the north, a flat, roughly triangular region covering 15,000&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (5,792&#160;sq&#160;mi),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Agriculture_and_Rural_Development2007_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Agriculture_and_Rural_Development2007-164">[158]</a></sup> is smaller but more intensely developed and more densely populated than the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mekong_River_Delta" title="Mekong River Delta">Mekong River Delta</a> in the south. Once an inlet of the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Tonkin" title="Gulf of Tonkin">Gulf of Tonkin</a>, it has been filled in over the millennia by riverine <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alluvial_deposits" title="Alluvial deposits">alluvial deposits</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHuu_Chiem1993180_165-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuu_Chiem1993180-165">[159]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMinh_Hoangvan_LapKim_OanhJiro2016_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMinh_Hoangvan_LapKim_OanhJiro2016-166">[160]</a></sup> The delta, covering about 40,000&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (15,444&#160;sq&#160;mi), is a low-level plain no more than 3 metres (9.8&#160;ft) <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Above_mean_sea_level" title="Above mean sea level">above sea level</a> at any point. It is criss-crossed by a maze of rivers and canals, which carry so much sediment that the delta advances 60 to 80 metres (196.9 to 262.5&#160;ft) into the sea every year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHuu_Chiem1993183_167-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuu_Chiem1993183-167">[161]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHong_TruongYeStive2017757_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHong_TruongYeStive2017757-168">[162]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:I%27m_coming,_PXP.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="853" data-file-width="1280" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/I%27m_coming%2C_PXP.jpg/220px-I%27m_coming%2C_PXP.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/I%27m_coming%2C_PXP.jpg/330px-I%27m_coming%2C_PXP.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/I%27m_coming%2C_PXP.jpg/440px-I%27m_coming%2C_PXP.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:I%27m_coming,_PXP.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ho&#224;ng Li&#234;n S&#417;n <a href="/wiki/Mountain_range" title="Mountain range">mountain range</a>, a part of the <a href="/wiki/Fansipan" title="Fansipan">Fansipan</a> which is the highest summit in the country.</div></div></div>\n<p>Southern Vietnam is divided into coastal lowlands, the mountains of the <a href="/wiki/Annamite_Range" title="Annamite Range">Annamite Range</a>, and extensive forests. Comprising five relatively flat plateaus of basalt soil, the highlands account for 16% of the country\'s <a href="/wiki/Arable_land" title="Arable land">arable land</a> and 22% of its total forested land.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECosslettCosslett201713_169-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECosslettCosslett201713-169">[163]</a></sup> The soil in much of southern part of Vietnam is relatively low in nutrients as a result of intense cultivation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_DeDouglasMcMorrowLindley2008_170-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_DeDouglasMcMorrowLindley2008-170">[164]</a></sup> Several minor <a href="/wiki/Earthquake" title="Earthquake">earthquakes</a> have been recorded in the past with most occurred near the northern Vietnamese border in the provinces of <a href="/wiki/%C4%90i%E1%BB%87n_Bi%C3%AAn_Province" title="&#272;i&#7879;n Bi&#234;n Province">&#272;i&#7879;n Bi&#234;n</a>, L&#224;o Cai and <a href="/wiki/S%C6%A1n_La_Province" title="S&#417;n La Province">S&#417;n La</a> while some are recorded in the offshore of the central part of the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHong_Phuong20123_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHong_Phuong20123-171">[165]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVi&#7879;t_Nam_News2016_172-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVi&#7879;t_Nam_News2016-172">[166]</a></sup> The northern part of the country consists mostly of highlands and the <a href="/wiki/Red_River_Delta" title="Red River Delta">Red River Delta</a>. <a href="/wiki/Fansipan" title="Fansipan">Fansipan</a> (also called as Phan Xi P&#259;ng) which is located in <a href="/wiki/L%C3%A0o_Cai_Province" title="L&#224;o Cai Province">L&#224;o Cai Province</a> is the highest mountain in Vietnam, standing 3,143&#160;m (10,312&#160;ft) high.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Culture,_Sports_and_Tourism2014_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Culture,_Sports_and_Tourism2014-173">[167]</a></sup> From north to south Vietnam, the country also has <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Vietnam" title="List of islands of Vietnam">numerous islands</a> with <a href="/wiki/Ph%C3%BA_Qu%E1%BB%91c" title="Ph&#250; Qu&#7889;c">Ph&#250; Qu&#7889;c</a> being the largest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBoobbyerSpooner2013173_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBoobbyerSpooner2013173-174">[168]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Hang_S%C6%A1n_%C4%90o%C3%B2ng" title="Hang S&#417;n &#272;o&#242;ng">Hang S&#417;n &#272;o&#242;ng Cave</a> is considered as the current largest cave passage in the world since its discovery in 2009 while both the <a href="/wiki/Ba_B%E1%BB%83_Lake" title="Ba B&#7875; Lake">Ba B&#7875; Lake</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mekong" title="Mekong">Mekong River</a> being the largest lake and longest river in the country respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECosslettCosslett201313_175-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECosslettCosslett201313-175">[169]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnh2016a_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnh2016a-176">[170]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Telegraph_177-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Telegraph-177">[171]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Vietnam" title="Climate of Vietnam">Climate of Vietnam</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:327px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nha_Trang_skyline.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1213" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Nha_Trang_skyline.jpg/325px-Nha_Trang_skyline.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Nha_Trang_skyline.jpg/488px-Nha_Trang_skyline.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Nha_Trang_skyline.jpg/650px-Nha_Trang_skyline.jpg 2x" width="325"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Nha_Trang_skyline.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Nha_Trang" title="Nha Trang">Nha Trang</a>, a popular beach destination has a <a href="/wiki/Tropical_savanna_climate" title="Tropical savanna climate">tropical savanna climate</a>.</div></div></div>\n<p>Due to differences in latitude and the marked variety in topographical relief, the climate tends to vary considerably for each region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELap_Vu197966_178-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELap_Vu197966-178">[172]</a></sup> During the winter or dry season, extending roughly from November to April, the <a href="/wiki/Monsoon" title="Monsoon">monsoon</a> winds usually blow from the northeast along the Chinese coast and across the Gulf of Tonkin, picking up considerable moisture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERiehlAugstein19731_179-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERiehlAugstein19731-179">[173]</a></sup> The average annual temperature is generally higher in the plains than in the mountains, especially in southern Vietnam compared to the north. Temperatures vary less in the southern plains around Ho Chi Minh City and the Mekong Delta, ranging from between 21 and 35&#160;&#176;C (69.8 and 95.0&#160;&#176;F) over the course of the year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuleen2017_180-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuleen2017-180">[174]</a></sup> In Hanoi and the surrounding areas of Red River Delta, the temperatures are much lower between 15 and 33&#160;&#176;C (59.0 and 91.4&#160;&#176;F),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuleen2017_180-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuleen2017-180">[174]</a></sup> while seasonal variations in the mountains and plateaus and in the northernmost are much more dramatic, with temperatures varying from 3&#160;&#176;C (37.4&#160;&#176;F) in December and January to 37&#160;&#176;C (98.6&#160;&#176;F) in July and August.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Net2018a_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Net2018a-181">[175]</a></sup> As Vietnam received high rain <a href="/wiki/Precipitation" title="Precipitation">precipitation</a> with an average amount of rainfall from 1,500 millimitres to 2,000 millimetres during the monsoon seasons; this often causes flooding, especially in the cities with poor drainage systems.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThi_Anh_182-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThi_Anh-182">[176]</a></sup> The country is also affected by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tropical_depression" title="Tropical depression">tropical depressions</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tropical_storm" title="Tropical storm">tropical storms</a> and <a href="/wiki/Typhoon" title="Typhoon">typhoons</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThi_Anh_182-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThi_Anh-182">[176]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Vietnam" title="Wildlife of Vietnam">Wildlife of Vietnam</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_endangered_species_in_Vietnam" title="List of endangered species in Vietnam">List of endangered species in Vietnam</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wildlife_of_Vietnam.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="404" data-file-width="404" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Wildlife_of_Vietnam.jpg/220px-Wildlife_of_Vietnam.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Wildlife_of_Vietnam.jpg/330px-Wildlife_of_Vietnam.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e9/Wildlife_of_Vietnam.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Wildlife_of_Vietnam.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Native species in Vietnam, clockwise from top-right: <a href="/wiki/Crested_argus" title="Crested argus">crested argus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Red-shanked_douc" title="Red-shanked douc">red-shanked douc</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indochinese_leopard" title="Indochinese leopard">Indochinese leopard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saola" title="Saola">saola</a>.</div></div></div>\n<p>As the country is located inside the <a href="/wiki/Indomalayan_realm" title="Indomalayan realm">Indomalayan realm</a>, Vietnam is one of twenty-five countries considered to possess a uniquely high level of <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity" title="Biodiversity">biodiversity</a> as also been stated in the country National Environmental Condition Report in 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Environment_Administration_183-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Environment_Administration-183">[177]</a></sup> It is ranked 16th worldwide in biological diversity, being home to approximately 16% of the world\'s species. 15,986 species of <a href="/wiki/Flora" title="Flora">flora</a> have been identified in the country, of which 10% are endemic, while Vietnam\'s <a href="/wiki/Fauna" title="Fauna">fauna</a> include 307 <a href="/wiki/Nematode" title="Nematode">nematode</a> species, 200 <a href="/wiki/Oligochaeta" title="Oligochaeta">oligochaeta</a>, 145 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Acarina" title="Acarina">acarina</a>, 113 <a href="/wiki/Springtail" title="Springtail">springtails</a>, 7,750 insects, 260 reptiles, 120 amphibians, 840 birds and 310 mammals, of which 100 birds and 78 mammals are endemic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Environment_Administration_183-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Environment_Administration-183">[177]</a></sup> Vietnam has two <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Natural_Heritage_Site" title="World Natural Heritage Site">World Natural Heritage Sites</a>, the <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BA%A1_Long_Bay" title="H&#7841; Long Bay">H&#7841; Long Bay</a> and <a href="/wiki/Phong_Nha-K%E1%BA%BB_B%C3%A0ng_National_Park" title="Phong Nha-K&#7867; B&#224;ng National Park">Phong Nha-K&#7867; B&#224;ng National Park</a> together with nine <a href="/wiki/World_Network_of_Biosphere_Reserves_in_Asia_and_the_Pacific#Vietnam" title="World Network of Biosphere Reserves in Asia and the Pacific">biosphere reserves</a> including <a href="/wiki/C%E1%BA%A7n_Gi%E1%BB%9D_Mangrove_Forest" title="C&#7847;n Gi&#7901; Mangrove Forest">C&#7847;n Gi&#7901; Mangrove Forest</a>, <a href="/wiki/C%C3%A1t_Ti%C3%AAn_National_Park" title="C&#225;t Ti&#234;n National Park">C&#225;t Ti&#234;n</a>, <a href="/wiki/C%C3%A1t_B%C3%A0_National_Park" title="C&#225;t B&#224; National Park">C&#225;t B&#224;</a>, <a href="/wiki/U_Minh_Th%C6%B0%E1%BB%A3ng_National_Park" title="U Minh Th&#432;&#7907;ng National Park">Ki&#234;n Giang</a>, the Red River Delta, Mekong Delta, <a href="/wiki/Western_Ngh%E1%BB%87_An" title="Western Ngh&#7879; An">Western Ngh&#7879; An</a>, <a href="/wiki/M%C5%A9i_C%C3%A0_Mau_National_Park" title="M&#361;i C&#224; Mau National Park">C&#224; Mau</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cu_Lao_Cham_Marine_Park" title="Cu Lao Cham Marine Park">Cu Lao Cham Marine Park</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_World_Heritage_Convention1994_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_World_Heritage_Convention1994-184">[178]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_World_Heritage_Convention2003_185-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_World_Heritage_Convention2003-185">[179]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPha_Le2016_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPha_Le2016-186">[180]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lotus_flower_(978659).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2178" data-file-width="3267" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Lotus_flower_%28978659%29.jpg/220px-Lotus_flower_%28978659%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Lotus_flower_%28978659%29.jpg/330px-Lotus_flower_%28978659%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Lotus_flower_%28978659%29.jpg/440px-Lotus_flower_%28978659%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lotus_flower_(978659).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Nelumbo_nucifera" title="Nelumbo nucifera">Pink lotus</a>, widely regarded by Vietnamese as the <a href="/wiki/Floral_emblem" title="Floral emblem">national flower</a> of the country which symbolising beauty, commitment, health, honour and knowledge.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENh&#226;n_D&#226;n2011_187-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENh&#226;n_D&#226;n2011-187">[181]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHinchey201730_188-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHinchey201730-188">[182]</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>Vietnam is furthermore home to 1,438 species of freshwater <a href="/wiki/Microalgae" title="Microalgae">microalgae</a>, constituting 9.6% of all microalgae species, as well as 794 aquatic <a href="/wiki/Invertebrate" title="Invertebrate">invertebrates</a> and 2,458 species of sea fish.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Environment_Administration_183-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Environment_Administration-183">[177]</a></sup> In recent years, 13 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Genera" title="Genera">genera</a>, 222 species, and 30 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taxa" title="Taxa">taxa</a> of flora have been newly described in Vietnam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Environment_Administration_183-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Environment_Administration-183">[177]</a></sup> Six new mammal species, including the <a href="/wiki/Saola" title="Saola">saola</a>, <a href="/wiki/Giant_muntjac" title="Giant muntjac">giant muntjac</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tonkin_snub-nosed_monkey" title="Tonkin snub-nosed monkey">Tonkin snub-nosed monkey</a> have also been discovered, along with one new bird species, the endangered <a href="/wiki/Edwards%27s_pheasant" title="Edwards\'s pheasant">Edwards\'s pheasant</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBirdLife_International2016_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBirdLife_International2016-189">[183]</a></sup> In the late 1980s, a small population of <a href="/wiki/Javan_rhinoceros" title="Javan rhinoceros">Javan rhinoceros</a> was found in C&#225;t Ti&#234;n National Park. However, the last individual of the species in Vietnam was reportedly shot in 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKinver2011_190-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKinver2011-190">[184]</a></sup> In agricultural <a href="/wiki/Genetic_diversity" title="Genetic diversity">genetic diversity</a>, Vietnam is one of the world\'s twelve original <a href="/wiki/Cultivar" title="Cultivar">cultivar</a> centres. The Vietnam National Cultivar Gene Bank preserves 12,300 cultivars of 115 species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Environment_Administration_183-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Environment_Administration-183">[177]</a></sup> The Vietnamese government spent US$49.07 million on the preservation of biodiversity in 2004 alone, and has established 126 conservation areas, including 30 <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Vietnam" title="List of national parks of Vietnam">national parks</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Environment_Administration_183-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Environment_Administration-183">[177]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environment">Environment</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_Vietnam" title="Environmental issues in Vietnam">Environmental issues in Vietnam</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sa_Pa_mountain_hills_with_agricultural_activities.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1600" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="293" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Sa_Pa_mountain_hills_with_agricultural_activities.jpg/220px-Sa_Pa_mountain_hills_with_agricultural_activities.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Sa_Pa_mountain_hills_with_agricultural_activities.jpg/330px-Sa_Pa_mountain_hills_with_agricultural_activities.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Sa_Pa_mountain_hills_with_agricultural_activities.jpg/440px-Sa_Pa_mountain_hills_with_agricultural_activities.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sa_Pa_mountain_hills_with_agricultural_activities.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Sa_Pa" title="Sa Pa">Sa Pa</a> mountain hills with <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Vietnam" title="Agriculture in Vietnam">agricultural activities</a>.</div></div></div>\n<p>In Vietnam, <a href="/wiki/Poaching" title="Poaching">poaching</a> had become a main issue for their wildlife. Since 2000, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Non-governmental_organisation" title="Non-governmental organisation">non-governmental organisation</a> (NGO) called <a href="/wiki/Education_for_Nature_-_Vietnam" title="Education for Nature - Vietnam">Education for Nature - Vietnam</a> have been founded to instill the importance of wildlife conservation in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDall2017_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDall2017-191">[185]</a></sup> Following this, the seeds of the conservation movement starting to bloom with the foundation of another NGO called GreenViet by Vietnamese youngsters for the enforcement of wildlife protection. Through collaboration between the NGO and local authorities, many local poaching syndicates managed to be crippled with the arrestment of their leaders.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDall2017_191-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDall2017-191">[185]</a></sup> As Vietnam have also become the main destination for <a href="/wiki/Rhinoceros" title="Rhinoceros">rhinoceros</a> horn illegal export from <a href="/wiki/South_Africa" title="South Africa">South Africa</a>, a study in 2018 found the demands are due to medical and health-related reasons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDang_VuNielsen2018_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDang_VuNielsen2018-192">[186]</a></sup> The main environmental concern that persists in Vietnam until present is the chemical <a href="/wiki/Herbicide" title="Herbicide">herbicide</a> legacy of <a href="/wiki/Agent_Orange" title="Agent Orange">Agent Orange</a> that causing <a href="/wiki/Birth_defect" title="Birth defect">birth defects</a> and many health problems towards Vietnamese residents especially in the southern and central areas that was affected most by the chemicals with nearly 4.8 million Vietnamese have been exposed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBanoutUrbanMusilSzakova2014_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBanoutUrbanMusilSzakova2014-193">[187]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECerre2016_194-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECerre2016-194">[188]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrown2018_195-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrown2018-195">[189]</a></sup> In 2012, approximately 50 years after the war,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAgence_France-Presse2016_196-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAgence_France-Presse2016-196">[190]</a></sup> the United States began to start a <a href="/wiki/United_States_dollar" title="United States dollar">US</a>$43 million joint clean up project in the former chemical storage areas in Vietnam that was heavily affected with each clearance will be done through several phases.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECerre2016_194-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECerre2016-194">[188]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMacLeod2012_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMacLeod2012-197">[191]</a></sup> Following the completion of the first phase in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%A0_N%E1%BA%B5ng" title="&#272;&#224; N&#7861;ng">&#272;&#224; N&#7861;ng</a> in late 2017,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_States_Agency_for_International_Development_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_States_Agency_for_International_Development-198">[192]</a></sup> the United States announced its further commitment to clean other sites especially in another heavily impact site of <a href="/wiki/Bi%C3%AAn_H%C3%B2a" title="Bi&#234;n H&#242;a">Bi&#234;n H&#242;a</a> which is four times larger than the previous site with an additional estimate cost of $390 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStewart2018_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStewart2018-199">[193]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fog_in_T%C3%A2y_B%E1%BA%AFc.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3999" data-file-width="5999" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Fog_in_T%C3%A2y_B%E1%BA%AFc.jpg/220px-Fog_in_T%C3%A2y_B%E1%BA%AFc.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Fog_in_T%C3%A2y_B%E1%BA%AFc.jpg/330px-Fog_in_T%C3%A2y_B%E1%BA%AFc.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Fog_in_T%C3%A2y_B%E1%BA%AFc.jpg/440px-Fog_in_T%C3%A2y_B%E1%BA%AFc.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Fog_in_T%C3%A2y_B%E1%BA%AFc.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Fog" title="Fog">Natural fog</a> in <a href="/wiki/Northwest_(Vietnam)" title="Northwest (Vietnam)">northwest Vietnam</a> (T&#226;y B&#7855;c).</div></div></div>\n<p>The Vietnamese government spends over <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_%C4%91%E1%BB%93ng" title="Vietnamese &#273;&#7891;ng">VN&#272;</a>10 trillion each year ($431.1 million) for monthly allowance and physical rehabilitation of the Vietnamese victims caused by the chemicals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVi&#7879;t_Nam_News2018a_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVi&#7879;t_Nam_News2018a-200">[194]</a></sup> In 2018, Japanese Engineering Group, <a href="/wiki/Shimizu_Corporation" title="Shimizu Corporation">Shimizu Corporation</a> also working with Vietnamese military to built a plant in Vietnam for the treatment of Agent Orange polluted soils with the plant construction costs to be funded by the company itself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENikkei_Asian_Review2018_201-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENikkei_Asian_Review2018-201">[195]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENHK_World-Japan2018_202-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENHK_World-Japan2018-202">[196]</a></sup> One of the long-term plan to restore the southern Vietnam damaged <a href="/wiki/Ecosystem" title="Ecosystem">ecosystems</a> is through <a href="/wiki/Reforestation" title="Reforestation">reforestation</a> efforts which the Vietnamese government having done since the end of the war, starting with the replantation of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mangrove_forest" title="Mangrove forest">mangrove forests</a> in the Mekong Delta regions and in <a href="/wiki/C%E1%BA%A7n_Gi%E1%BB%9D_District" title="C&#7847;n Gi&#7901; District">C&#7847;n Gi&#7901;</a> outside of the main city where mangroves are important to prevent more serious flooding during the monsoon seasons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAgent_Orange_Record_203-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAgent_Orange_Record-203">[197]</a></sup> Apart from herbicide problems, <a href="/wiki/Arsenic_poisoning" title="Arsenic poisoning">arsenic</a> exposure to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ground_water" title="Ground water">ground water</a> in the Mekong Delta and Red River Delta also become a major concern,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBergStengelPhamPham2007_204-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBergStengelPhamPham2007-204">[198]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMerolaHienQuyenVengosh2014_205-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMerolaHienQuyenVengosh2014-205">[199]</a></sup> along with <a href="/wiki/Unexploded_ordnance" title="Unexploded ordnance">unexploded ordnance</a> (UXO) that poses dangers towards human and habitat life as another bitter legacy from the long wars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiguelRoland2005_206-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiguelRoland2005-206">[200]</a></sup> As part of the continuous campaign for <a href="/wiki/Demining" title="Demining">demining</a>/removal of UXO, various international <a href="/wiki/Mine_clearance_agency" title="Mine clearance agency">bomb removal agency</a> including those from the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_Kingdom_Department_for_International_Development2017_207-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_Kingdom_Department_for_International_Development2017-207">[201]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Denmark</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELM_Report2000_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELM_Report2000-208">[202]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korea</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_Nations_Development_Programme2018_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_Nations_Development_Programme2018-209">[203]</a></sup> as well the United States<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_States_Department_of_State2006_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_States_Department_of_State2006-210">[204]</a></sup> itself has providing help in the process with the Vietnam government spends over VN&#272;1 trillion ($44 million) annually on demining operations and another hundreds billions of &#273;&#7891;ng for treatment, assistance, rehabilitation, vocational training and resettlement for the victims of UXOs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Thanh2016_211-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Thanh2016-211">[205]</a></sup> Apart from the explosive removal from the legacy of civil war, the neighbouring Chinese government also has removed 53,000 land mines and explosives from the legacy of war between the two countries in an area of 18.4 square kilometres in neighbouring province of <a href="/wiki/Yunnan" title="Yunnan">Yunnan</a> between the <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93Vietnam_border" title="China&#8211;Vietnam border">China&#8211;Vietnam border</a> in 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETao2017_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETao2017-212">[206]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right:auto; width:auto; max-width:1008px;">\n<div class="thumbinner"><div class="noresize overflowbugx" style="overflow:auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ha_Long_Bay_panorama.jpg" title="Panoramic view of H&#7841; Long Bay"><img alt="" data-file-height="612" data-file-width="2340" decoding="async" height="262" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Ha_Long_Bay_panorama.jpg/1000px-Ha_Long_Bay_panorama.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Ha_Long_Bay_panorama.jpg/1500px-Ha_Long_Bay_panorama.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Ha_Long_Bay_panorama.jpg/2000px-Ha_Long_Bay_panorama.jpg 2x" width="1000"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ha_Long_Bay_panorama.jpg" title="File:Ha Long Bay panorama.jpg"> </a></div>Panoramic view of <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BA%A1_Long_Bay" title="H&#7841; Long Bay">H&#7841; Long Bay</a></div>\n</div></div>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Vietnam" title="Politics of Vietnam">Politics of Vietnam</a> and <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Vietnam" title="Government of Vietnam">Government of Vietnam</a></div>\n<p>Vietnam is a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marxism-Leninism" title="Marxism-Leninism">Marxist-Leninist</a> <a href="/wiki/One-party_state" title="One-party state">one-party</a> <a href="/wiki/Socialist_state" title="Socialist state">socialist</a> <a href="/wiki/Republic" title="Republic">republic</a>, one of the two <a href="/wiki/Communist_state" title="Communist state">communist states</a> (the other being <a href="/wiki/Laos" title="Laos">Laos</a>) in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_II_213-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_II-213">[207]</a></sup> Although Vietnam remains officially committed to <a href="/wiki/Socialism" title="Socialism">socialism</a> as its defining creed, its economic policies have grown increasingly <a href="/wiki/Capitalism" title="Capitalism">capitalist</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGreenfield1994204_214-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGreenfield1994204-214">[208]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBacciniImpullittiMalesky2017_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBacciniImpullittiMalesky2017-215">[209]</a></sup> with <i><a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">The Economist</a></i> characterising its leadership as "ardently capitalist communists".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Economist2008_216-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Economist2008-216">[210]</a></sup> Under the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Vietnam" title="Constitution of Vietnam">constitution</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Vietnam" title="Communist Party of Vietnam">Communist Party of Vietnam</a> (CPV) asserts their role in all branches of politics and society in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_II_213-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_II-213">[207]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/President_of_Vietnam" title="President of Vietnam">President</a> is the elected <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a> of the military, serving as the Chairman of the Council of Supreme Defence and Security, holds the second highest office in Vietnam as well as performing executive functions and state appointments and setting policy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_II_213-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_II-213">[207]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r856303569">@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti>.thumbinner{width:100%!important;max-width:none!important}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:none!important;width:100%!important;text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;max-width:312px"><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:102px;max-width:102px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Ph%C3%BA_Tr%E1%BB%8Dng" title="Nguy&#7877;n Ph&#250; Tr&#7885;ng"><img alt="Nguy&#7877;n Ph&#250; Tr&#7885;ng" data-file-height="192" data-file-width="144" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Nguyen_Phu_Trong.jpg/100px-Nguyen_Phu_Trong.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6c/Nguyen_Phu_Trong.jpg 1.5x" width="100"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Ph%C3%BA_Tr%E1%BB%8Dng" title="Nguy&#7877;n Ph&#250; Tr&#7885;ng">Nguy&#7877;n Ph&#250; Tr&#7885;ng</a><br/><small><a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Communist_Party_of_Vietnam" title="General Secretary of the Communist Party of Vietnam">General Secretary</a> &amp; <a href="/wiki/President_of_Vietnam" title="President of Vietnam">President</a></small></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:102px;max-width:102px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Xu%C3%A2n_Ph%C3%BAc" title="Nguy&#7877;n Xu&#226;n Ph&#250;c"><img alt="Nguy&#7877;n Ph&#250; Tr&#7885;ng" data-file-height="200" data-file-width="150" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Nguyen_Xuan_Phuc.jpg/100px-Nguyen_Xuan_Phuc.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d1/Nguyen_Xuan_Phuc.jpg 1.5x" width="100"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Xu%C3%A2n_Ph%C3%BAc" title="Nguy&#7877;n Xu&#226;n Ph&#250;c">Nguy&#7877;n Xu&#226;n Ph&#250;c</a><br/><small><a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Vietnam" title="Prime Minister of Vietnam">Prime Minister</a></small></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:102px;max-width:102px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Th%E1%BB%8B_Kim_Ng%C3%A2n" title="Nguy&#7877;n Th&#7883; Kim Ng&#226;n"><img alt="Nguy&#7877;n Th&#7883; Kim Ng&#226;n" data-file-height="1372" data-file-width="1029" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Nguyen_Thi_Kim_Ngan_2012.jpg/100px-Nguyen_Thi_Kim_Ngan_2012.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Nguyen_Thi_Kim_Ngan_2012.jpg/150px-Nguyen_Thi_Kim_Ngan_2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Nguyen_Thi_Kim_Ngan_2012.jpg/200px-Nguyen_Thi_Kim_Ngan_2012.jpg 2x" width="100"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Th%E1%BB%8B_Kim_Ng%C3%A2n" title="Nguy&#7877;n Th&#7883; Kim Ng&#226;n">Nguy&#7877;n Th&#7883; Kim Ng&#226;n</a><br/><small><a href="/wiki/Chairman_of_the_National_Assembly_of_Vietnam" title="Chairman of the National Assembly of Vietnam">National Assembly Chairperson</a></small></div></div><div style="clear:left"></div></div></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Communist_Party_of_Vietnam" title="General Secretary of the Communist Party of Vietnam">General Secretary</a> of the CPV performs numerous key administrative functions, controlling the party\'s national organisation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_II_213-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_II-213">[207]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Vietnam" title="Prime Minister of Vietnam">Prime Minister</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>, presiding over a council of ministers composed of five deputy prime ministers and the heads of 26 ministries and commissions. Only political organisations affiliated with or endorsed by the CPV are permitted to contest elections in Vietnam. These include the <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_Fatherland_Front" title="Vietnamese Fatherland Front">Vietnamese Fatherland Front</a> and worker and <a href="/wiki/Trade_union" title="Trade union">trade unionist</a> parties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_II_213-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_II-213">[207]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:National_Assembly_of_Vietnam.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/National_Assembly_of_Vietnam.JPG/220px-National_Assembly_of_Vietnam.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/National_Assembly_of_Vietnam.JPG/330px-National_Assembly_of_Vietnam.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/National_Assembly_of_Vietnam.JPG/440px-National_Assembly_of_Vietnam.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:National_Assembly_of_Vietnam.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Assembly_of_Vietnam" title="National Assembly of Vietnam">National Assembly of Vietnam</a> building in Hanoi</div></div></div>\n<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Assembly_of_Vietnam" title="National Assembly of Vietnam">National Assembly of Vietnam</a> is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unicameral" title="Unicameral">unicameral</a> <a href="/wiki/Legislature" title="Legislature">legislature</a> of the state, composed of 498 members.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEmbassy_of_Vietnam_in_USA_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEmbassy_of_Vietnam_in_USA-217">[211]</a></sup> The legislature is open to all parties. Headed by a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Chairmen_of_the_Standing_Committee_of_the_National_Assembly_of_Vietnam" title="List of Chairmen of the Standing Committee of the National Assembly of Vietnam">Chairman</a>, it is superior to both the executive and judicial branches, with all government ministers being appointed from members of the National Assembly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_II_213-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_II-213">[207]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Supreme_People%27s_Court_of_Vietnam" title="Supreme People\'s Court of Vietnam">Supreme People\'s Court of Vietnam</a>, headed by a Chief Justice, is the country\'s highest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Court_of_appeal" title="Court of appeal">court of appeal</a>, though it is also answerable to the National Assembly. Beneath the Supreme People\'s Court stand the <a href="/wiki/Provincial_Municipal_Courts_of_Vietnam" title="Provincial Municipal Courts of Vietnam">provincial municipal courts</a> and numerous <a href="/wiki/Local_Courts_of_Vietnam" title="Local Courts of Vietnam">local courts</a>. <a href="/wiki/Military_Courts_of_Vietnam" title="Military Courts of Vietnam">Military courts</a> possess special jurisdiction in matters of national security. Vietnam maintains the <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_Vietnam" title="Capital punishment in Vietnam">death penalty</a> for numerous offences.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Penal_Code1999_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Penal_Code1999-218">[212]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Vietnam" title="Foreign relations of Vietnam">Foreign relations of Vietnam</a></div>\n<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tr%E1%BA%A7n_%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i_Quang_and_Vladimir_Putin,_2016-01.jpg"><img alt="Tr&#7847;n &#272;&#7841;i Quang and Vladimir Putin" data-file-height="1160" data-file-width="1880" decoding="async" height="123" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Tr%E1%BA%A7n_%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i_Quang_and_Vladimir_Putin%2C_2016-01.jpg/200px-Tr%E1%BA%A7n_%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i_Quang_and_Vladimir_Putin%2C_2016-01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Tr%E1%BA%A7n_%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i_Quang_and_Vladimir_Putin%2C_2016-01.jpg/300px-Tr%E1%BA%A7n_%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i_Quang_and_Vladimir_Putin%2C_2016-01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Tr%E1%BA%A7n_%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i_Quang_and_Vladimir_Putin%2C_2016-01.jpg/400px-Tr%E1%BA%A7n_%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i_Quang_and_Vladimir_Putin%2C_2016-01.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">President <a href="/wiki/Tr%E1%BA%A7n_%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i_Quang" title="Tr&#7847;n &#272;&#7841;i Quang">Tr&#7847;n &#272;&#7841;i Quang</a> with Russian President <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a> on 19 November 2016.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Secretary_Tillerson_Joins_Commercial_Deals_Signing_Ceremony_at_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Vietnam_(38322247422).jpg"><img alt="Secretary Tillerson at the Presidential Palace" data-file-height="2759" data-file-width="4431" decoding="async" height="125" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Secretary_Tillerson_Joins_Commercial_Deals_Signing_Ceremony_at_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Vietnam_%2838322247422%29.jpg/200px-Secretary_Tillerson_Joins_Commercial_Deals_Signing_Ceremony_at_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Vietnam_%2838322247422%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Secretary_Tillerson_Joins_Commercial_Deals_Signing_Ceremony_at_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Vietnam_%2838322247422%29.jpg/300px-Secretary_Tillerson_Joins_Commercial_Deals_Signing_Ceremony_at_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Vietnam_%2838322247422%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Secretary_Tillerson_Joins_Commercial_Deals_Signing_Ceremony_at_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Vietnam_%2838322247422%29.jpg/400px-Secretary_Tillerson_Joins_Commercial_Deals_Signing_Ceremony_at_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Vietnam_%2838322247422%29.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">US Secretary of State <a href="/wiki/Rex_Tillerson" title="Rex Tillerson">Rex Tillerson</a> accompanies US President <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> to a commercial deals signing ceremony with Vietnamese President on 12 November 2017.</div></div></div></div>\n<p>Throughout its history, Vietnam\'s main foreign relationship has been with various Chinese dynasties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThayer1994_219-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThayer1994-219">[213]</a></sup> Following the partition of Vietnam, the relations are divided between relations with <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bloc" title="Eastern Bloc">Eastern Bloc</a> for North Vietnam while <a href="/wiki/Western_Bloc" title="Western Bloc">Western Bloc</a> for South Vietnam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThayer1994_219-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThayer1994-219">[213]</a></sup> Despite the differences, Vietnam\'s sovereign principles and insistence on cultural independence have been laid down in numerous documents over the centuries since before its independence, such as the 11th-century patriotic poem "<i><a href="/wiki/Nam_qu%E1%BB%91c_s%C6%A1n_h%C3%A0" title="Nam qu&#7889;c s&#417;n h&#224;">Nam qu&#7889;c s&#417;n h&#224;</a></i>" and the 1428 proclamation of independence "<i><a href="/wiki/B%C3%ACnh_Ng%C3%B4_%C4%91%E1%BA%A1i_c%C3%A1o" title="B&#236;nh Ng&#244; &#273;&#7841;i c&#225;o">B&#236;nh Ng&#244; &#273;&#7841;i c&#225;o</a></i>". Though China and Vietnam are now formally at peace,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThayer1994_219-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThayer1994-219">[213]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Spratly_Islands#Military_conflict_and_diplomatic_dialogues" title="Spratly Islands">significant territorial tensions</a> in the South China Sea remain between the two countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThanh_Hai2016177_220-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThanh_Hai2016177-220">[214]</a></sup> Vietnam holds membership of 63 international organisations, including the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> (UN), <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Southeast_Asian_Nations" title="Association of Southeast Asian Nations">Association of Southeast Asian Nations</a> (ASEAN), <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a> (NAM), <a href="/wiki/Organisation_internationale_de_la_Francophonie" title="Organisation internationale de la Francophonie">International Organisation of the Francophonie</a> (La Francophonie) and <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> (WTO). It also maintains relations with over 650 non-government organisations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs2018_221-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs2018-221">[215]</a></sup> Until 2010, Vietnam had established diplomatic relations with 178 countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs2013_222-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs2013-222">[216]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Vietnam current foreign policy is to implement consistently the policy of independence, self-reliance, peace, co-operation and development as well the openness and diversification/<a href="/wiki/Multilateralism" title="Multilateralism">multilateralisation</a> of international relations,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs2007_223-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs2007-223">[217]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs2014_224-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs2014-224">[218]</a></sup> with the country further declares itself as a friend and partner of all countries in the international community regardless of their political affiliation by actively taking part in international and regional co-operation especially in country development.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBich_Loan2007_154-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBich_Loan2007-154">[149]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs2007_223-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs2007-223">[217]</a></sup> Since 1990s, several key steps had been taken by Vietnam to restore diplomatic ties with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_countries" title="Western countries">Western countries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDayley201898_225-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDayley201898-225">[219]</a></sup> Relations with the United States <a href="/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Vietnam_relations" title="United States&#8211;Vietnam relations">began to improve</a> in August 1995 with both nations upgraded their <i><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/liaison" title="wikt:liaison">liaison</a></i> offices to an embassy status.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMitchell1995_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMitchell1995-226">[220]</a></sup> As diplomatic ties between the two nations grew, the United States opened a consulate general in Ho Chi Minh City while Vietnam opened <a href="/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_in_San_Francisco" title="List of diplomatic missions in San Francisco">its consulate</a> in <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco" title="San Francisco">San Francisco</a>. Full diplomatic relations were also restored with <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand" title="New Zealand">New Zealand</a> who opened its embassy in Hanoi in 1995,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGreen2012_227-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGreen2012-227">[221]</a></sup> while Vietnam established an embassy in <a href="/wiki/Wellington" title="Wellington">Wellington</a> in 2003.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESmith2005386_228-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESmith2005386-228">[222]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> also reopened its embassy in Hanoi in October 2000 with Vietnam reopened their embassy in <a href="/wiki/Islamabad" title="Islamabad">Islamabad</a> in December 2005 and trade office in <a href="/wiki/Karachi" title="Karachi">Karachi</a> in November 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEInstitute_of_Regional_Studies200166_229-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInstitute_of_Regional_Studies200166-229">[223]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs-230">[224]</a></sup> In May 2016, US President <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> further normalised relations with Vietnam after he announced the lifting of an arms <a href="/wiki/United_States_embargoes" title="United States embargoes">embargo</a> on sales of lethal arms to Vietnam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGaramone2016_231-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGaramone2016-231">[225]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_People%27s_Armed_Forces" title="Vietnam People\'s Armed Forces">Vietnam People\'s Armed Forces</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vietnam_People%27s_Armed_Forces.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="312" data-file-width="560" decoding="async" height="123" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Vietnam_People%27s_Armed_Forces.jpg/220px-Vietnam_People%27s_Armed_Forces.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Vietnam_People%27s_Armed_Forces.jpg/330px-Vietnam_People%27s_Armed_Forces.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Vietnam_People%27s_Armed_Forces.jpg/440px-Vietnam_People%27s_Armed_Forces.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vietnam_People%27s_Armed_Forces.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Examples of the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_People%27s_Armed_Forces" title="Vietnam People\'s Armed Forces">Vietnam People\'s Armed Forces</a> weaponry assets. Clockwise from top right: <a href="/wiki/T-54/T-55" title="T-54/T-55">T-54B tank</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sukhoi_Su-27" title="Sukhoi Su-27">Sukhoi Su-27UBK fighter aircraft</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_Coast_Guard" title="Vietnam Coast Guard">Vietnam Coast Guard</a> <a href="/wiki/Hamilton-class_cutter" title="Hamilton-class cutter">Hamilton-class cutter</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vietnam_People%27s_Army" title="Vietnam People\'s Army">Vietnam People\'s Army</a> chemical corps with <a href="/wiki/Type_56_assault_rifle" title="Type 56 assault rifle">Type 56</a>.</div></div></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_People%27s_Armed_Forces" title="Vietnam People\'s Armed Forces">Vietnam People\'s Armed Forces</a> consists of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vietnam_People%27s_Army" title="Vietnam People\'s Army">Vietnam People\'s Army</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/People%27s_Police_of_Vietnam" title="People\'s Police of Vietnam">Vietnam People\'s Public Security</a> and the Vietnam Civil Defence Force. The Vietnam People\'s Army (VPA) is the official name for the active military services of Vietnam, and is subdivided into the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vietnam_People%27s_Ground_Forces" title="Vietnam People\'s Ground Forces">Vietnam People\'s Ground Forces</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_People%27s_Navy" title="Vietnam People\'s Navy">Vietnam People\'s Navy</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_People%27s_Air_Force" title="Vietnam People\'s Air Force">Vietnam People\'s Air Force</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_Border_Defence_Force" title="Vietnam Border Defence Force">Vietnam Border Defence Force</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_Coast_Guard" title="Vietnam Coast Guard">Vietnam Coast Guard</a>. The VPA has an active manpower of around 450,000, but its total strength, including paramilitary forces, may be as high as 5,000,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylorRutherford201150_232-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylorRutherford201150-232">[226]</a></sup> In 2015, Vietnam\'s <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" title="List of countries by military expenditures">military expenditure</a> totalled approximately US$4.4 billion, equivalent to around 8% of their total government spending.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYan2016_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYan2016-233">[227]</a></sup> Joint military exercises and war games also being held with <a href="/wiki/Brunei" title="Brunei">Brunei</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVoice_of_Vietnam2016_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVoice_of_Vietnam2016-234">[228]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Economic_Times2018_235-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Economic_Times2018-235">[229]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Japan_Times2015_236-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Japan_Times2015-236">[230]</a></sup> Laos,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVoice_of_Vietnam2018b_237-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVoice_of_Vietnam2018b-237">[231]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESputnik_News2015_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESputnik_News2015-238">[232]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERussia_Ministry_of_Defence2018_239-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERussia_Ministry_of_Defence2018-239">[233]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVoice_of_Vietnam2016_234-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVoice_of_Vietnam2016-234">[228]</a></sup> and the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Telegraph2012_240-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Telegraph2012-240">[234]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Subdivisions_of_Vietnam" title="Subdivisions of Vietnam">Subdivisions of Vietnam</a></div>\n<p>Vietnam is divided into 58 <a href="/wiki/Province" title="Province">provinces</a> (Vietnamese: <i>t&#7881;nh</i>, from the Chinese <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%9C%81" title="wikt:&#30465;">&#30465;</a>, <i>sh&#283;ng</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJapan_Ministry_of_Land,_Infrastructure,_Transport_and_Tourism_241-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJapan_Ministry_of_Land,_Infrastructure,_Transport_and_Tourism-241">[235]</a></sup> There are also five <a href="/wiki/Municipality" title="Municipality">municipalities</a> (<i>th&#224;nh ph&#7889; tr&#7921;c thu&#7897;c trung &#432;&#417;ng</i>), which are administratively on the same level as provinces.\n</p>\n<div class="center"><small>A clickable map of Vietnam exhibiting its 58 provinces and 5 centrally controlled municipalities.</small></div>\n<div class="center"><div class="floatnone"><div class="noresize" style="height: 750px; width: 450px; "><map name="ImageMap_1_738763912"><area alt="Lai Ch&#226;u Province" coords="54,46,105,65" style="border: none;"/></a></div></div></div></div>\n<table style="margin:auto;">\n<tbody><tr>\n<td style="padding-right:1em; vertical-align:top;">\n<div class="center"><b><a href="/wiki/Red_River_Delta" title="Red River Delta">Red River Delta</a></b></div>\n<hr/>\n<p><a href="/wiki/B%E1%BA%AFc_Ninh_Province" title="B&#7855;c Ninh Province">B&#7855;c Ninh</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/H%C3%A0_Nam_Province" title="H&#224; Nam Province">H&#224; Nam</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/H%E1%BA%A3i_D%C6%B0%C6%A1ng_Province" title="H&#7843;i D&#432;&#417;ng Province">H&#7843;i title="Hanoi">H&#224; N&#7897;i</a> (municipality)<br/>\n<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hai_Phong" title="Hai Phong">H&#7843;i Ph&#242;ng</a> (municipality)\n</p>\n</td>\n<td style="padding-right:1em; vertical-align:top;">\n<div class="center"><b><a href="/wiki/Northeast_(Vietnam)" title="Northeast (Vietnam)">Northeast</a></b></div>\n<hr/>\n<p><a href="/wiki/B%E1%BA%AFc_Giang_Province" title="B&#7855;c Giang Province">B&#7855;c Giang</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/B%E1%BA%AFc_K%E1%BA%A1n_Province" title="B&#7855;c K&#7841;n Province">B&#7855;c K&#7841;n</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/Cao_B%E1%BA%B1ng_Province" title="Cao B&#7857;ng Province">Cao B&#7857;ng</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/H%C3%A0_Giang_Province" title="H&#224; Giang Province">H&#224; Giang</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/L%E1%BA%A1ng_S%C6%A1n_Province" title="L&#7841;ng S&#417;n Province">L&#7841;ng S&#417;n</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/L%C3%A0o_Cai_Province" title="L&#224;o Cai B&#225;i</a>\n</p>\n</td>\n<td style="padding-right:1em; vertical-align:top;">\n<div class="center"><b><a href="/wiki/Northwest_(Vietnam)" title="Northwest (Vietnam)">Northwest</a></b></div>\n<hr/>\n<p><a href="/wiki/%C4%90i%E1%BB%87n_Bi%C3%AAn_Province" title="&#272;i&#7879;n Bi&#234;n Province">&#272;i&#7879;n Bi&#234;n</a><br/>\n<a Ch&#226;u</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/S%C6%A1n_La_Province" title="S&#417;n La Province">S&#417;n La</a>\n</p>\n</td>\n<td style="padding-right:1em; vertical-align:top;">\n<div class="center"><b><a T&#297;nh</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/Ngh%E1%BB%87_An_Province" title="Ngh&#7879; An Province">Ngh&#7879; An</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/Qu%E1%BA%A3ng_B%C3%ACnh_Province" title="Qu&#7843;ng B&#236;nh Province">Qu&#7843;ng B&#236;nh</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/Qu%E1%BA%A3ng_Tr%E1%BB%8B_Province" title="Qu&#7843;ng Tr&#7883; Province">Qu&#7843;ng Tr&#7883;</a><br/>\n<a Thi&#234;n&#8211;Hu&#7871; Province">Th&#7915;a Thi&#234;n&#8211;Hu&#7871;</a>\n</p>\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td style="padding-right:1em; vertical-align:top;">\n<div class="center"><b><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Highlands_(Vietnam)" title="Central Highlands (Vietnam)">Central Highlands</a></b></div>\n<hr/>\n<p><a href="/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BA%AFk_L%E1%BA%AFk_Province" N&#244;ng</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/Gia_Lai_Province" title="Gia Lai Province">Gia Lai</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/Kon_Tum_Province" title="Kon Tum Province">Kon Tum</a><br/>\n<a class="center"><b><a href="/wiki/South_Central_Coast" title="South Central Coast">South Central Coast</a></b></div>\n<hr/>\n<p><a href="/wiki/B%C3%ACnh_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh_Province" title="B&#236;nh &#272;&#7883;nh Province">B&#236;nh &#272;&#7883;nh</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/B%C3%ACnh_Thu%E1%BA%ADn_Province" title="B&#236;nh Thu&#7853;n Province">B&#236;nh Thu&#7853;n</a><br/>\n<a Province">Qu&#7843;ng Nam</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/Qu%E1%BA%A3ng_Ng%C3%A3i_Province" title="Qu&#7843;ng Ng&#227;i Province">Qu&#7843;ng Ng&#227;i</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/Da_Nang" title="Da Nang">&#272;&#224; N&#7861;ng</a> (municipality)\n</p>\n</td>\n<td style="padding-right:1em; vertical-align:top;">\n<div class="center"><b><a href="/wiki/Southeast_(Vietnam)" title="Southeast (Vietnam)">Southeast</a></b></div>\n<hr/>\n<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/B%C3%A0_R%E1%BB%8Ba%E2%80%93V%C5%A9ng_T%C3%A0u_Province" title="B&#224; R&#7883;a&#8211;V&#361;ng T&#224;u Province">B&#224; R&#7883;a&#8211;V&#361;ng T&#224;u</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/B%C3%ACnh_D%C6%B0%C6%A1ng_Province" title="B&#236;nh D&#432;&#417;ng Province">B&#236;nh D&#432;&#417;ng</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/B%C3%ACnh_Ph%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Bc_Province" title="B&#236;nh Ph&#432;&#7899;c Province">B&#236;nh Ph&#432;&#7899;c</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BB%93ng_Nai_Province" title="Ho Chi Minh City">H&#7891; Ch&#237; Minh City</a> (municipality)\n</p>\n</td>\n<td style="padding-right:1em; vertical-align:top;">\n<div class="center"><b><a href="/wiki/Mekong_Delta" title="Mekong Delta">Mekong Delta</a></b></div>\n<hr/>\n<p><a href="/wiki/An_Giang_Province" title="An Giang Province">An Giang</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/B%E1%BA%A1c_Li%C3%AAu_Province" title="B&#7841;c Li&#234;u Province">B&#7841;c Li&#234;u</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/B%E1%BA%BFn_Tre_Province" title="B&#7871;n Tre Province">B&#7871;n Tre</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/C%C3%A0_Mau_Province" title="C&#224; Mau Province">C&#224; Mau</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BB%93ng_Th%C3%A1p_Province" title="&#272;&#7891;ng Th&#225;p Province">&#272;&#7891;ng Th&#225;p</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/H%E1%BA%ADu_Giang_Province" title="H&#7853;u Giang Province">H&#7853;u Giang</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/Ki%C3%AAn_Giang_Province" title="Ki&#234;n Giang Province">Ki&#234;n Giang</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/Long_An_Province" title="Long An Province">Long An</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/S%C3%B3c_Tr%C4%83ng_Province" title="S&#243;c Tr&#259;ng Province">S&#243;c Tr&#259;ng</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/Ti%E1%BB%81n_Giang_Province" title="Ti&#7873;n Giang Province">Ti&#7873;n Giang</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/Tr%C3%A0_Vinh_Province" title="Tr&#224; Vinh Province">Tr&#224; Vinh</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/V%C4%A9nh_Long_Province" title="V&#297;nh Long Province">V&#297;nh Long</a><br/>\n<a href="/wiki/C%E1%BA%A7n_Th%C6%A1" title="C&#7847;n Th&#417;">C&#7847;n Th&#417;</a> (municipality)\n</p>\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tay_Ho_Communist_propaganda_posters_in_2015_11.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1728" data-file-width="3072" decoding="async" height="124"
