src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Tay_Ho_Communist_propaganda_posters_in_2015_11.jpg/220px-Tay_Ho_Communist_propaganda_posters_in_2015_11.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Tay_Ho_Communist_propaganda_posters_in_2015_11.jpg/330px-Tay_Ho_Communist_propaganda_posters_in_2015_11.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Tay_Ho_Communist_propaganda_posters_in_2015_11.jpg/440px-Tay_Ho_Communist_propaganda_posters_in_2015_11.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tay_Ho_Communist_propaganda_posters_in_2015_11.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Vietnam" title="Communist Party of Vietnam">Communist Party</a>\'s propaganda poster in Hanoi</div></div></div>\n<p>The provinces are subdivided into <a href="/wiki/Provincial_city_(Vietnam)" title="Provincial city (Vietnam)">provincial municipalities</a> (<i>th&#224;nh ph&#7889; tr&#7921;c thu&#7897;c t&#7881;nh</i>), <a href="/wiki/Township" title="Township">townships</a> (<i>th&#7883; x&#227;</i>) and <a href="/wiki/County" title="County">counties</a> (<i>huy&#7879;n</i>), which are in turn subdivided into towns (<i>th&#7883; tr&#7845;n</i>) or <a href="/wiki/Commune-level_subdivisions_(Vietnam)" title="Commune-level subdivisions (Vietnam)">communes</a> (<i>x&#227;</i>). The centrally controlled municipalities are subdivided into <a href="/wiki/District" title="District">districts</a> (<i>qu&#7853;n</i>) and counties, which are further subdivided into <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ward_(country_subdivision)" title="Ward (country subdivision)">wards</a> (<i>ph&#432;&#7901;ng</i>).\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights">Human rights</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Vietnam" title="Human rights in Vietnam">Human rights in Vietnam</a></div>\n<p>Under the current constitution, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Communist_Party" title="Communist Party">Communist Party</a> of Vietnam is the only one allowed to rule, the operation of all other political parties being outlawed. Other human rights issues concern <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_association" title="Freedom of association">freedom of association</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_speech" title="Freedom of speech">freedom of speech</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press" title="Freedom of the press">freedom of the press</a>. In 2009, Vietnamese lawyer <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/L%C3%AA_C%C3%B4ng_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh" title="L&#234; C&#244;ng &#272;&#7883;nh">L&#234; C&#244;ng &#272;&#7883;nh</a> was arrested and charged with the capital crime of <a href="/wiki/Subversion" title="Subversion">subversion</a>; several of his associates were also arrested.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBBC_News2009_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBBC_News2009-242">[236]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMydans2009_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMydans2009-243">[237]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a> named him and his arrested associates <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prisoners_of_conscience" title="Prisoners of conscience">prisoners of conscience</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBBC_News2009_242-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBBC_News2009-242">[236]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Vietnam" title="Economy of Vietnam">Economy of Vietnam</a></div>\n<table class="wikitable" style="float: right; margin-left: 10px">\n<tbody><tr>\n<th colspan="2" style="text-align:center; background:#cfb;">Share of world <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> (<a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">PPP</a>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEInternational_Monetary_Fund_8-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInternational_Monetary_Fund-8">[6]</a></sup>\n</th></tr>\n<tr>\n<th style="background:#cfb;">Year\n</th>\n<th style="background:#cfb;">Share\n</th></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>1980</td>\n<td style="text-align:right;">0.18%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>1990</td>\n<td style="text-align:right;">0.23%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>2000</td>\n<td style="text-align:right;">0.32%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>2010</td>\n<td style="text-align:right;">0.43%\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Viet_Nam_Export_Treemap.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="751" data-file-width="961" decoding="async" height="172" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Viet_Nam_Export_Treemap.png/220px-Viet_Nam_Export_Treemap.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Viet_Nam_Export_Treemap.png/330px-Viet_Nam_Export_Treemap.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Viet_Nam_Export_Treemap.png/440px-Viet_Nam_Export_Treemap.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Viet_Nam_Export_Treemap.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tree_map" title="Tree map">Tree map</a> of Vietnam export in 2012</div></div></div>\n<p>Throughout the history of Vietnam, its economy has been largely on <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agriculture</a> based on <a href="/wiki/Rice_production_in_Vietnam" title="Rice production in Vietnam">wet rice cultivation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECornell_University_244-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECornell_University-244">[238]</a></sup> There is also an industry for <a href="/wiki/Bauxite_mining_in_Vietnam" title="Bauxite mining in Vietnam">bauxite mining in central Vietnam</a>, an important material for the production of <a href="/wiki/Aluminium" title="Aluminium">aluminium</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKim_Phuong20141_245-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKim_Phuong20141-245">[239]</a></sup> Since reunification, the country economy is shaped primarily by the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Vietnam" title="Communist Party of Vietnam">Communist Party of Vietnam</a> (CPV) through the <a href="/wiki/Five-Year_Plans_of_Vietnam" title="Five-Year Plans of Vietnam">Five Year Plans</a> which are being decided from the plenary sessions of the Central Committee and national congresses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKimura1986_246-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKimura1986-246">[240]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Collectivisation" title="Collectivisation">collectivisation</a> of farms, factories and capital goods was carried out as components in establishing central planning, with millions of people working in state enterprises. Despite strict state control, Vietnam\'s economy continued to be plagued with inefficiency and <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Vietnam" title="Corruption in Vietnam">corruption in state-owned enterprises</a>, poor quality and underproduction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAdhikariKirkpatrickWeiss1992249_247-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAdhikariKirkpatrickWeiss1992249-247">[241]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENgoc_VoLe20147_248-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENgoc_VoLe20147-248">[242]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Tho200311_249-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Tho200311-249">[243]</a></sup> With the decrease of Soviet economic aid as the main trading partners for Vietnam following the erosion of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_bloc" title="Eastern bloc">Eastern bloc</a> in the late 1980s and subsequent <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">Soviet Union collapse</a> in addition to the negative impacts from the post-war <a href="/wiki/Economic_sanctions" title="Economic sanctions">trade embargo</a> imposed by the United States,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELitvackLitvackRondinelli199931_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELitvackLitvackRondinelli199931-250">[244]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFreeman2002_251-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFreeman2002-251">[245]</a></sup> Vietnam began to liberalise its trade by <a href="/wiki/Devaluation" title="Devaluation">devaluing</a> its exchange rate to increase exports and embark on a policy of economic development.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELitvackLitvackRondinelli199933_252-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELitvackLitvackRondinelli199933-252">[246]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:HVNLM_2018.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="621" data-file-width="424" decoding="async" height="322" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/HVNLM_2018.jpg/220px-HVNLM_2018.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/HVNLM_2018.jpg/330px-HVNLM_2018.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c6/HVNLM_2018.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:HVNLM_2018.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Vietnam&#8217;s tallest skyscraper, the <a href="/wiki/Landmark_81" title="Landmark 81">Landmark 81</a> located in <a href="/wiki/B%C3%ACnh_Th%E1%BA%A1nh_District" title="B&#236;nh Th&#7841;nh District">B&#236;nh Th&#7841;nh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_City" title="Ho Chi Minh City">Ho Chi Minh City</a>.</div></div></div>\n<p>In 1986, the <a href="/wiki/6th_National_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_Vietnam" title="6th National Congress of the Communist Party of Vietnam">Sixth National Congress</a> of the CPV introduced <a href="/wiki/Socialist-oriented_market_economy" title="Socialist-oriented market economy">socialist-oriented market</a> economic reforms as part of the <i><a href="/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BB%95i_M%E1%BB%9Bi" title="&#272;&#7893;i M&#7899;i">&#272;&#7893;i M&#7899;i</a></i> reform program with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Private_ownership" title="Private ownership">private ownership</a> began to be encouraged in industries, commerce and agriculture and state enterprises were <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Corporatisation" title="Corporatisation">restructured</a> to operate under market constraints,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Tho20035_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Tho20035-253">[247]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoang_VuongDung_Tran2009_254-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoang_VuongDung_Tran2009-254">[248]</a></sup> resulting the old-fashioned five-year economic plans are being replaced with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Socialist_market" title="Socialist market">socialist market</a> mechanism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoang_Vuong2014_255-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoang_Vuong2014-255">[249]</a></sup> As a result of these reforms, Vietnam achieved around 8% annual <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">Gross domestic product</a> (GDP) growth between 1990 and 1997,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELargo200266_256-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELargo200266-256">[250]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEInternational_Monetary_Fund199923_257-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInternational_Monetary_Fund199923-257">[251]</a></sup> with the United States also ended its economic embargo against Vietnam in early 1994.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECockburn1994_258-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECockburn1994-258">[252]</a></sup> Despite the <a href="/wiki/1997_Asian_financial_crisis" title="1997 Asian financial crisis">1997 Asian financial crisis</a> affecting Vietnam and causing economic slow down to 4-5% growth <i><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/per_annum" title="wikt:per annum">per annum</a></i>, its economy began to recover in 1999,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Tho20035_253-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Tho20035-253">[247]</a></sup> with growth at an annual rate of around 7% from 2000 to 2005 and making the country as one of the world\'s fastest growing economies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPincus201527_259-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPincus201527-259">[253]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEQuang_Vinh13_260-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEQuang_Vinh13-260">[254]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/General_Statistics_Office_of_Vietnam" title="General Statistics Office of Vietnam">General Statistics Office of Vietnam</a> (GSO), growth remained strong even in the face of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Late-2000s_global_recession" title="Late-2000s global recession">late-2000s global recession</a>, holding at 6.8% in 2010, although Vietnam\'s year-on-year inflation rate hit 11.8% in December 2010 with the country currency, the <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_%C4%91%E1%BB%93ng" title="Vietnamese &#273;&#7891;ng">Vietnamese &#273;&#7891;ng</a> are being devalued three times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAsian_Development_Bank2010388_261-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsian_Development_Bank2010388-261">[255]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThanh_Ni&#234;n2010_262-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThanh_Ni&#234;n2010-262">[256]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vinfast,_m%C3%B4_h%C3%ACnh_SUV_Lux_SA2.0_.jpg"><img alt="Vinfast SVU Lux SA 2.0 at the 2018 Paris Motor Show" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="400" data-file-width="640" decoding="async" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Vinfast%2C_m%C3%B4_h%C3%ACnh_SUV_Lux_SA2.0_.jpg/220px-Vinfast%2C_m%C3%B4_h%C3%ACnh_SUV_Lux_SA2.0_.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Vinfast%2C_m%C3%B4_h%C3%ACnh_SUV_Lux_SA2.0_.jpg/330px-Vinfast%2C_m%C3%B4_h%C3%ACnh_SUV_Lux_SA2.0_.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Vinfast%2C_m%C3%B4_h%C3%ACnh_SUV_Lux_SA2.0_.jpg/440px-Vinfast%2C_m%C3%B4_h%C3%ACnh_SUV_Lux_SA2.0_.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vinfast,_m%C3%B4_h%C3%ACnh_SUV_Lux_SA2.0_.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/VinFast" title="VinFast">VinFast</a> company is a Vietnamese car manufacturer.</div></div></div>\n<p>Deep <a href="/wiki/Poverty" title="Poverty">poverty</a> which defined as the percentage of the population living on less than $1 per day has declined significantly in Vietnam and the relative poverty rate is now less than that of China, India and the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVierraVierra20115_263-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVierraVierra20115-263">[257]</a></sup> This decline in the poverty rate can be attributed to <a href="/wiki/Equity_(economics)" title="Equity (economics)">equitable economic policies</a> aimed at improving <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Living_standards" title="Living standards">living standards</a> and preventing the rise of <a href="/wiki/Economic_inequality" title="Economic inequality">inequality</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVandemoorteleBird2010_264-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVandemoorteleBird2010-264">[258]</a></sup> these policies have included egalitarian land distribution during the initial stages of the <i>&#272;&#7893;i M&#7899;i</i> program, investment in poorer remote areas, and subsidising of education and healthcare.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECuong_LeKuboFujinoMinh_Pham201023_265-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECuong_LeKuboFujinoMinh_Pham201023-265">[259]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEH._DangGlewwe20179_266-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEH._DangGlewwe20179-266">[260]</a></sup> Since the early 2000s, Vietnam has applied sequenced trade liberalisation, a two-track approach opening some sectors of the economy to international markets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVandemoorteleBird2010_264-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVandemoorteleBird2010-264">[258]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVandemoortele2010_267-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVandemoortele2010-267">[261]</a></sup> Manufacturing, <a href="/wiki/Information_technology" title="Information technology">information technology</a> and high-tech industries now form a large and fast-growing part of the national economy. Though Vietnam is a relative newcomer to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oil_industry" title="Oil industry">oil industry</a>, it is currently the third-largest oil producer in Southeast Asia with a total 2011 output of 318,000 barrels per day (50,600&#160;m<sup>3</sup>/d).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUPI.com2013_268-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUPI.com2013-268">[262]</a></sup> In 2010, Vietnam was ranked as the 8th largest crude <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">petroleum</a> producers in the Asia and Pacific region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFong-Sam201026_269-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFong-Sam201026-269">[263]</a></sup> The United States was the country that purchased the highest amount of Vietnam\'s exports,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVi&#7879;t_Nam_News2018b_270-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVi&#7879;t_Nam_News2018b-270">[264]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Goods" title="Goods">goods</a> from China were the most popular Vietnamese import.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_News_Agency2018_271-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_News_Agency2018-271">[265]</a></sup>\n</p><p>According to a December 2005 forecast by <a href="/wiki/Goldman_Sachs" title="Goldman Sachs">Goldman Sachs</a>, the Vietnamese economy will become the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_past_and_future_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by past and future GDP (nominal)">world\'s 21st-largest by 2025</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKarmel20101_272-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKarmel20101-272">[266]</a></sup> with an estimated nominal GDP of $436 billion and a nominal GDP per capita of $4,357.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELyimo2016_273-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELyimo2016-273">[267]</a></sup> Based on a findings by <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> (IMF) in 2012, the <a href="/wiki/Unemployment" title="Unemployment">unemployment</a> rate in Vietnam stood at 4.46%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEInternational_Monetary_Fund_8-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInternational_Monetary_Fund-8">[6]</a></sup> Along the same year, Vietnam\'s <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nominal_GDP" title="Nominal GDP">nominal GDP</a> reached US$138 billion, with a nominal <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GDP_per_capita" title="GDP per capita">GDP per capita</a> of $1,527.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEInternational_Monetary_Fund_8-6"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInternational_Monetary_Fund-8">[6]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/HSBC" title="HSBC">HSBC</a> also predicted that Vietnam\'s total GDP would surpass those of <a href="/wiki/Norway" title="Norway">Norway</a>, Singapore and <a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">Portugal</a> by 2050.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELyimo2016_273-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELyimo2016-273">[267]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETu&#7893;i_Tr&#7867;_News2012_274-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETu&#7893;i_Tr&#7867;_News2012-274">[268]</a></sup> Another forecast by <a href="/wiki/PricewaterhouseCoopers" title="PricewaterhouseCoopers">PricewaterhouseCoopers</a> in 2008 stating that Vietnam may be the fastest-growing of the world\'s emerging economies by 2025, with a potential growth rate of almost 10% <i>per annum</i> in real dollar terms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPWC2008_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPWC2008-275">[269]</a></sup> Apart from the <a href="/wiki/Primary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Primary sector of the economy">primary sector economy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Vietnam" title="Tourism in Vietnam">tourism</a> has contributed significantly to Vietnam\'s economic growth with 7.94 million foreign visitors are recorded in 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Net2016a_276-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Net2016a-276">[270]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture">Agriculture</span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Terraced_fields_Sa_Pa_3.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4288" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Terraced_fields_Sa_Pa_3.jpg/220px-Terraced_fields_Sa_Pa_3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Terraced_fields_Sa_Pa_3.jpg/330px-Terraced_fields_Sa_Pa_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Terraced_fields_Sa_Pa_3.jpg/440px-Terraced_fields_Sa_Pa_3.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Terraced_fields_Sa_Pa_3.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Terraced rice fields in <a href="/wiki/Sa_Pa" title="Sa Pa">Sa Pa</a></div></div></div>\n<p>As a result of several <a href="/wiki/Land_reform" title="Land reform">land reform</a> measures, Vietnam has become a major exporter of agricultural products. It is now the world\'s largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Cashew" title="Cashew">cashew</a> nuts, with a one-third global share;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMai2017_277-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMai2017-277">[271]</a></sup> the largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Black_pepper" title="Black pepper">black pepper</a>, accounting for one-third of the world\'s market;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVoice_of_Vietnam2018c_278-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVoice_of_Vietnam2018c-278">[272]</a></sup> and the second-largest <a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a> exporter in the world after <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">Thailand</a> since the 1990s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENielsen20071_279-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENielsen20071-279">[273]</a></sup> Subsequently, Vietnam is also the world\'s second largest exporter of <a href="/wiki/Coffee" title="Coffee">coffee</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESummers2014_280-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESummers2014-280">[274]</a></sup> The country has the highest proportion of land use for <a href="/wiki/Permanent_crop" title="Permanent crop">permanent crops</a> together with other nations in the <a href="/wiki/Greater_Mekong_Subregion" title="Greater Mekong Subregion">Greater Mekong Subregion</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETruongVoNguyen2018172_281-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETruongVoNguyen2018172-281">[275]</a></sup> Other primary exports include <a href="/wiki/Tea" title="Tea">tea</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rubber" title="Rubber">rubber</a> and fishery products although agriculture\'s share of Vietnam\'s GDP has fallen in recent decades, declining from 42% in 1989 to 20% in 2006 as production in other sectors of the economy has risen.\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Vietnam" title="Science and technology in Vietnam">Science and technology in Vietnam</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:TOPIO_3.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1362" data-file-width="2042" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/TOPIO_3.jpg/220px-TOPIO_3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/TOPIO_3.jpg/330px-TOPIO_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/TOPIO_3.jpg/440px-TOPIO_3.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:TOPIO_3.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A Vietnamese-made <a href="/wiki/TOPIO" title="TOPIO">TOPIO 3.0</a> <a href="/wiki/Humanoid_robot" title="Humanoid robot">humanoid</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ping-pong" title="Ping-pong">ping-pong</a> playing robot displayed during the 2009 <a href="/wiki/International_Robot_Exhibition" title="International Robot Exhibition">International Robot Exhibition</a> (IREX) in <a href="/wiki/Tokyo" title="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDigInfo2007_282-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDigInfo2007-282">[276]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBorel2010_283-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBorel2010-283">[277]</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>In 2010, Vietnam\'s total state spending on science and technology equalled around 0.45% of its GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVi&#7879;t_Nam_News2010_284-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVi&#7879;t_Nam_News2010-284">[278]</a></sup> Since the dynastic era, Vietnamese scholars has developed many academic fields especially in <a href="/wiki/Social_science" title="Social science">social sciences</a> and humanities. Vietnam has a millennium-deep legacy of analytical histories, such as the <i><a href="/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i_Vi%E1%BB%87t_s%E1%BB%AD_k%C3%BD_to%C3%A0n_th%C6%B0" title="&#272;&#7841;i Vi&#7879;t s&#7917; k&#253; to&#224;n th&#432;">&#272;&#7841;i Vi&#7879;t s&#7917; k&#253; to&#224;n th&#432;</a></i> of <a href="/wiki/Ng%C3%B4_S%C4%A9_Li%C3%AAn" title="Ng&#244; S&#297; Li&#234;n">Ng&#244; S&#297; Li&#234;n</a>. Vietnamese monks led by the abdicated Emperor <a href="/wiki/Tr%E1%BA%A7n_Nh%C3%A2n_T%C3%B4ng" title="Tr&#7847;n Nh&#226;n T&#244;ng">Tr&#7847;n Nh&#226;n T&#244;ng</a> developed the Tr&#250;c L&#226;m Zen branch of philosophy in the 13th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTER&#243;&#380;ycka-TranAnh_Tran2014123_285-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTER&#243;&#380;ycka-TranAnh_Tran2014123-285">[279]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Arithmetic" title="Arithmetic">Arithmetics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Geometry" title="Geometry">geometry</a> have been widely taught in Vietnam since the 15th century, using the textbook <i>&#272;&#7841;i th&#224;nh to&#225;n ph&#225;p</i> by L&#432;&#417;ng Th&#7871; Vinh as a basis. L&#432;&#417;ng Th&#7871; Vinh introduced Vietnam to the notion of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/0_(number)" title="0 (number)">zero</a>, while M&#7841;c Hi&#7875;n T&#237;ch used the term <i>s&#7889; &#7849;n</i> (en: "unknown/secret/hidden number") to refer to <a href="/wiki/Negative_number" title="Negative number">negative numbers</a>. Vietnamese scholars furthermore produced numerous <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Encyclopaedia" title="Encyclopaedia">encyclopaedias</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/L%C3%AA_Qu%C3%BD_%C4%90%C3%B4n" title="L&#234; Qu&#253; &#272;&#244;n">L&#234; Qu&#253; &#272;&#244;n</a>\'s <i>V&#226;n &#273;&#224;i lo&#7841;i ng&#7919;</i>. In modern times, Vietnamese scientists have made many significant contributions in various fields of study, most notably in <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">mathematics</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hoang_Tuy" title="Hoang Tuy">Ho&#224;ng T&#7909;y</a> pioneered the <a href="/wiki/Applied_mathematics" title="Applied mathematics">applied mathematics</a> field of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Global_optimisation" title="Global optimisation">global optimisation</a> in the 20th century,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoblitz2009198_286-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoblitz2009198-286">[280]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Ng%C3%B4_B%E1%BA%A3o_Ch%C3%A2u" title="Ng&#244; B&#7843;o Ch&#226;u">Ng&#244; B&#7843;o Ch&#226;u</a> won the 2010 <a href="/wiki/Fields_Medal" title="Fields Medal">Fields Medal</a> for his proof of <a href="/wiki/Fundamental_lemma_(Langlands_program)" title="Fundamental lemma (Langlands program)">fundamental lemma in the theory of automorphic forms</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECNRS2010_287-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECNRS2010-287">[281]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoppes2010_288-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoppes2010-288">[282]</a></sup> Since the establishment of <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_Academy_of_Science_and_Technology" title="Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology">Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology</a> (VAST) by the government in 1975, the country is working to develop its first national <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Space_flight" title="Space flight">space flight</a> program especially after the completion of the infrastructure of Vietnam Space Centre (VSC) in 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Space_Centre2016_289-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Space_Centre2016-289">[283]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Academy_of_Science_and_Technology2017_290-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Academy_of_Science_and_Technology2017-290">[284]</a></sup> Vietnam has also made significant advances in the development of <a href="/wiki/Robot" title="Robot">robots</a>, such as the <a href="/wiki/TOPIO" title="TOPIO">TOPIO</a> humanoid model.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDigInfo2007_282-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDigInfo2007-282">[276]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBorel2010_283-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBorel2010-283">[277]</a></sup> Vietnam\'s main <a href="/wiki/Messaging_apps" title="Messaging apps">messaging apps</a>, Zalo is developed by V&#432;&#417;ng Quang Kh&#7843;i, a Vietnamese <a href="/wiki/Hacker" title="Hacker">hacker</a> who later work with the country largest <a href="/wiki/Information_technology" title="Information technology">information technology</a> service company, the <a href="/wiki/FPT_Group" title="FPT Group">FPT Group</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERaslan2017_291-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERaslan2017-291">[285]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Svhutech_nckh4.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="533" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Svhutech_nckh4.jpg/220px-Svhutech_nckh4.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Svhutech_nckh4.jpg/330px-Svhutech_nckh4.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Svhutech_nckh4.jpg/440px-Svhutech_nckh4.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Svhutech_nckh4.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Vietnamese science students making an <a href="/wiki/Experiment" title="Experiment">experiment</a> in their university lab.</div></div></div>\n<p>According to the <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_Institute_for_Statistics" title="UNESCO Institute for Statistics">UNESCO Institute for Statistics</a>, Vietnam devoted 0.19% of its GDP for science research and development in 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Media_Services2016_292-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Media_Services2016-292">[286]</a></sup> Between 2005 and 2014, the number of scientific publications recorded in Thomson Reuters\' <a href="/wiki/Web_of_Science" title="Web of Science">Web of Science</a> increased at a rate well above the average for Southeast Asia, albeit from a modest starting point.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Publishing713&#8211;714_293-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Publishing713&#8211;714-293">[287]</a></sup> Publications focus mainly on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Life_science" title="Life science">life sciences</a> (22%), <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/physic" title="wikt:physic">physics</a> (13%) and <a href="/wiki/Engineering" title="Engineering">engineering</a> (13%), which is consistent with recent advances in the production of diagnostic equipment and shipbuilding.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Publishing713&#8211;714_293-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Publishing713&#8211;714-293">[287]</a></sup> Almost 77% of all papers published between 2008 and 2014 had at least one international co-author. The autonomy which Vietnamese research centres have enjoyed since the mid-1990s has enabled many of them to operate as quasi-private organisations, providing services such as consulting and technology development.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Publishing713&#8211;714_293-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Publishing713&#8211;714-293">[287]</a></sup> Some have \'spun off\' from the larger institutions to form their own semi-private enterprises, fostering the transfer of public sector science and technology personnel to these semi-private establishments. One comparatively new university, the <a href="/wiki/T%C3%B4n_%C4%90%E1%BB%A9c_Th%E1%BA%AFng_University" title="T&#244;n &#272;&#7913;c Th&#7855;ng University">T&#244;n &#272;&#7913;c Th&#7855;ng University</a> which built in 1997 has already set up 13 centres for technology transfer and services that together produce 15% of university revenue. Many of these research centres serve as valuable intermediaries bridging public research institutions, universities and firms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Publishing713&#8211;714_293-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Publishing713&#8211;714-293">[287]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Vietnam" title="Tourism in Vietnam">Tourism in Vietnam</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pont-pagode_%22japonais%22_de_Hoi-an,_vue_de_nuit.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1333" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Pont-pagode_%22japonais%22_de_Hoi-an%2C_vue_de_nuit.jpg/220px-Pont-pagode_%22japonais%22_de_Hoi-an%2C_vue_de_nuit.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Pont-pagode_%22japonais%22_de_Hoi-an%2C_vue_de_nuit.jpg/330px-Pont-pagode_%22japonais%22_de_Hoi-an%2C_vue_de_nuit.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Pont-pagode_%22japonais%22_de_Hoi-an%2C_vue_de_nuit.jpg/440px-Pont-pagode_%22japonais%22_de_Hoi-an%2C_vue_de_nuit.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Pont-pagode_%22japonais%22_de_Hoi-an,_vue_de_nuit.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/H%E1%BB%99i_An" title="H&#7897;i An">H&#7897;i An</a>, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Nations_Educational,_Scientific_and_Cultural_Organization" title="United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Italy" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Italy">World Heritage Site</a> is a major tourist destination.</div></div></div>\n<p>Tourism is an important element of economic activity in the country, contributing 7.5% of the gross domestic product. Vietnam welcomed over 12.9 million visitors in 2017, an increase of 29.1% over the previous year, making Vietnam one of the fastest growing tourist destination in recent years. The vast majority of visitors to Vietnam in 2017 came from <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a>, numbering 9.7 million. China (4 million), South Korea (2.6 million) and Japan (798,119) made up half of all international arrivals in 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2018_294-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2018-294">[288]</a></sup> Vietnam also attracts large numbers of visitors from <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a> with almost 1.9 millions vistors in 2017. <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a> (574,164), United Kingdom (283,537), followed closely by France (255,396) and <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a> (199,872) were the largest source of international arrivals from Europe. Other significant international arrivals by nationality include the United States (614,117) and <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australia</a> (370,438).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2018_294-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2018-294">[288]</a></sup> The most visited destinations in Vietnam is Ho Chi Minh City with an 5.8 million international arrivals, followed by Hanoi with 4.6 million and <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BA%A1_Long" title="H&#7841; Long">H&#7841; Long</a>, including H&#7841; Long Bay with 4.4 million arrivals. All three are ranked in the top 100 most visited cities in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEQuy2018_295-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEQuy2018-295">[289]</a></sup> Vietnam is home to 8 <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Sites</a>, the equal highest by number of sites in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>. In 2018, <a href="/wiki/Travel_%2B_Leisure" title="Travel + Leisure">Travel + Leisure</a> ranked <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BB%99i_An" title="H&#7897;i An">H&#7897;i An</a> as the world\'s top 15 best destinations to visit.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETerzian2018_296-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETerzian2018-296">[290]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h2>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Vietnam" title="Transport in Vietnam">Transport in Vietnam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Vietnam" title="Rail transport in Vietnam">Rail transport in Vietnam</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Vietnam" title="List of airports in Vietnam">List of airports in Vietnam</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Metro_Saigon_Lines.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2985" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="164" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Metro_Saigon_Lines.png/220px-Metro_Saigon_Lines.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Metro_Saigon_Lines.png/330px-Metro_Saigon_Lines.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Metro_Saigon_Lines.png/440px-Metro_Saigon_Lines.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Metro_Saigon_Lines.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Proposed map for the <a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_City_Metro" title="Ho Chi Minh City Metro">HCMC Metro</a>.</div></div></div>\n<p>Much of Vietnam\'s modern transportation network traced its roots since the French colonial era where it was used to facilitate the transportation of <a href="/wiki/Raw_material" title="Raw material">raw materials</a> to main ports before being extensively expanded and modernised following the partition of Vietnam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrook20147_297-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrook20147-297">[291]</a></sup> Vietnam\'s road system includes national roads administered at the central level, provincial roads managed at the provincial level, district roads managed at the district level, urban roads managed by cities and towns and commune roads managed at the commune level.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2010_298-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2010-298">[292]</a></sup> In 2010, Vietnam road system has a total length of about 188,744 kilometres (117,280&#160;mi) with 93,535 kilometres (58,120&#160;mi) are <a href="/wiki/Asphalt" title="Asphalt">asphalt</a> road comprising national, provincial and district roads.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2010_298-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2010-298">[292]</a></sup> The national road system length is about 15,370 kilometres (9,550&#160;mi) with 15,085 kilometres (9,373&#160;mi) of its length are paved, the provincial road has around 27,976 kilometres (17,383&#160;mi) paved road while district road has 50,474 kilometres (31,363&#160;mi) paved road.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2010_298-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2010-298">[292]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:C%E1%BA%A7u_Long_Th%C3%A0nh,_%C4%90%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Dng_cao_t%E1%BB%91c_TP.HCM_-_Long_Th%C3%A0nh_-_D%E1%BA%A7u_Gi%C3%A2y.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1632" data-file-width="2456" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/C%E1%BA%A7u_Long_Th%C3%A0nh%2C_%C4%90%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Dng_cao_t%E1%BB%91c_TP.HCM_-_Long_Th%C3%A0nh_-_D%E1%BA%A7u_Gi%C3%A2y.JPG/220px-C%E1%BA%A7u_Long_Th%C3%A0nh%2C_%C4%90%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Dng_cao_t%E1%BB%91c_TP.HCM_-_Long_Th%C3%A0nh_-_D%E1%BA%A7u_Gi%C3%A2y.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/C%E1%BA%A7u_Long_Th%C3%A0nh%2C_%C4%90%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Dng_cao_t%E1%BB%91c_TP.HCM_-_Long_Th%C3%A0nh_-_D%E1%BA%A7u_Gi%C3%A2y.JPG/330px-C%E1%BA%A7u_Long_Th%C3%A0nh%2C_%C4%90%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Dng_cao_t%E1%BB%91c_TP.HCM_-_Long_Th%C3%A0nh_-_D%E1%BA%A7u_Gi%C3%A2y.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/C%E1%BA%A7u_Long_Th%C3%A0nh%2C_%C4%90%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Dng_cao_t%E1%BB%91c_TP.HCM_-_Long_Th%C3%A0nh_-_D%E1%BA%A7u_Gi%C3%A2y.JPG/440px-C%E1%BA%A7u_Long_Th%C3%A0nh%2C_%C4%90%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Dng_cao_t%E1%BB%91c_TP.HCM_-_Long_Th%C3%A0nh_-_D%E1%BA%A7u_Gi%C3%A2y.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:C%E1%BA%A7u_Long_Th%C3%A0nh,_%C4%90%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Dng_cao_t%E1%BB%91c_TP.HCM_-_Long_Th%C3%A0nh_-_D%E1%BA%A7u_Gi%C3%A2y.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_City_%E2%80%93_Long_Thanh_%E2%80%93_Dau_Giay_Expressway" title="Ho Chi Minh City &#8211; Long Thanh &#8211; Dau Giay Expressway">HCMC&#8211;LT&#8211;DG</a> section of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North%E2%80%93South_Expressway_(Vietnam)" title="North&#8211;South Expressway (Vietnam)">North&#8211;South Expressway</a>.</div></div></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tan_Son_Nhat_International_Airport.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1800" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Tan_Son_Nhat_International_Airport.jpg/220px-Tan_Son_Nhat_International_Airport.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Tan_Son_Nhat_International_Airport.jpg/330px-Tan_Son_Nhat_International_Airport.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Tan_Son_Nhat_International_Airport.jpg/440px-Tan_Son_Nhat_International_Airport.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tan_Son_Nhat_International_Airport.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Tan_Son_Nhat_International_Airport" title="Tan Son Nhat International Airport">Tan Son Nhat International Airport</a> is the busiest airport in the country.</div></div></div>\n<p><a href="/wiki/Bicycle" title="Bicycle">Bicycles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Motorcycle" title="Motorcycle">motorcycles</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Motor_scooter" title="Motor scooter">motor scooters</a> remain the most popular forms of road transport in the country as one of the legacy of French through transportation although the number of privately owned <a href="/wiki/Car" title="Car">cars</a> have been rising in recent years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHuu_DucMai_HoaThien_HuongNgoc_Bao20132080_299-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuu_DucMai_HoaThien_HuongNgoc_Bao20132080-299">[293]</a></sup> Public buses operated by private companies are the main mode of long-distance travel for much of the population. <a href="/wiki/Traffic_collision" title="Traffic collision">Road accidents</a> remain the major safety issue in Vietnamese transportation with an average of 30 people lost their lives daily,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2011_300-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2011-300">[294]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Traffic_congestion" title="Traffic congestion">traffic congestion</a> is a growing problem in both major cities of Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City especially with the growing of individual car ownership.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinh_LeAnh_Trinh2016_301-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinh_LeAnh_Trinh2016-301">[295]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESohrBrockfeldSauerl&#228;nderMelde2016220_302-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESohrBrockfeldSauerl&#228;nderMelde2016220-302">[296]</a></sup> Vietnam\'s primary cross-country rail service is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North%E2%80%93South_Railway_(Vietnam)" title="North&#8211;South Railway (Vietnam)">Reunification Express</a> from Ho Chi Minh City to Hanoi with a distance of nearly 1,726 kilometres (1,072&#160;mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChin2018_303-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChin2018-303">[297]</a></sup> From Hanoi, railway lines branch out to the northeast, north and west; the eastbound line runs from Hanoi to H&#7841; Long Bay, the northbound line from Hanoi to <a href="/wiki/Th%C3%A1i_Nguy%C3%AAn" title="Th&#225;i Nguy&#234;n">Th&#225;i Nguy&#234;n</a>, and the northeast line from Hanoi to L&#224;o Cai. In 2009, Vietnam and Japan signed a deal to build a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North%E2%80%93South_Express_Railway_(Vietnam)" title="North&#8211;South Express Railway (Vietnam)">high-speed railway</a> by using the technology of Japanese <i><a href="/wiki/Shinkansen" title="Shinkansen">Shinkansen</a></i>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Japan_Times2009_304-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Japan_Times2009-304">[298]</a></sup> numerous Vietnamese engineers were later sent to Japan to receive training in the operation and maintenance of high-speed trains.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam+2008_305-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam+2008-305">[299]</a></sup> The planned railway will be a 1,545 kilometres (960&#160;mi) long express route serving a total of 23 stations including in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City with 70% of its route will running on bridges and through underground tunnels,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Nation2018_306-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Nation2018-306">[300]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Net2018b_307-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Net2018b-307">[301]</a></sup> while the trains will travelling at a maximum speed of 350 kilometres (220&#160;mi) per hour.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Net2018b_307-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Net2018b-307">[301]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESouth_East_Asia_Iron_and_Steel_Institute2009_308-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESouth_East_Asia_Iron_and_Steel_Institute2009-308">[302]</a></sup> The plan for the country first high-speed rail however are being postponed with the Vietnamese government made a decision to putting the main priority on the development of both <a href="/wiki/Hanoi_Metro" title="Hanoi Metro">Hanoi Metro</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_City_Metro" title="Ho Chi Minh City Metro">Ho Chi Minh City Metro</a> as well the expansion of road networks instead.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChin2018_303-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChin2018-303">[297]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChi2017_309-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChi2017-309">[303]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETatarski2017_310-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETatarski2017-310">[304]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ch%C3%B9a_V%E1%BA%BD_Terminal,_Port_of_H%E1%BA%A3i_Ph%C3%B2ng.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Ch%C3%B9a_V%E1%BA%BD_Terminal%2C_Port_of_H%E1%BA%A3i_Ph%C3%B2ng.JPG/220px-Ch%C3%B9a_V%E1%BA%BD_Terminal%2C_Port_of_H%E1%BA%A3i_Ph%C3%B2ng.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Ch%C3%B9a_V%E1%BA%BD_Terminal%2C_Port_of_H%E1%BA%A3i_Ph%C3%B2ng.JPG/330px-Ch%C3%B9a_V%E1%BA%BD_Terminal%2C_Port_of_H%E1%BA%A3i_Ph%C3%B2ng.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Ch%C3%B9a_V%E1%BA%BD_Terminal%2C_Port_of_H%E1%BA%A3i_Ph%C3%B2ng.JPG/440px-Ch%C3%B9a_V%E1%BA%BD_Terminal%2C_Port_of_H%E1%BA%A3i_Ph%C3%B2ng.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ch%C3%B9a_V%E1%BA%BD_Terminal,_Port_of_H%E1%BA%A3i_Ph%C3%B2ng.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Port of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hai_Phong" title="Hai Phong">Hai Phong</a> is one of the largest and busiest container ports in Vietnam.</div></div></div>\n<p>Vietnam operates 20 major civil airports, including three international gateways: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Noi_Bai" title="Noi Bai">Noi Bai</a> in Hanoi, <a href="/wiki/Da_Nang_International_Airport" title="Da Nang International Airport">Da Nang International Airport</a> in &#272;&#224; N&#7861;ng and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tan_Son_Nhat" title="Tan Son Nhat">Tan Son Nhat</a> in Ho Chi Minh City. Tan Son Nhat is the nation\'s largest airport by which it handling the majority of international passenger traffic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoang20161_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoang20161-311">[305]</a></sup> According to a state-approved plan, Vietnam will have another seven international airports by 2015, these include <a href="/wiki/Vinh_International_Airport" title="Vinh International Airport">Vinh International Airport</a>, <a href="/wiki/Phu_Bai_International_Airport" title="Phu Bai International Airport">Phu Bai International Airport</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cam_Ranh_International_Airport" title="Cam Ranh International Airport">Cam Ranh International Airport</a>, <a href="/wiki/Phu_Quoc_International_Airport" title="Phu Quoc International Airport">Phu Quoc International Airport</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cat_Bi_International_Airport" title="Cat Bi International Airport">Cat Bi International Airport</a>, <a href="/wiki/Can_Tho_International_Airport" title="Can Tho International Airport">Can Tho International Airport</a> and <a href="/wiki/Long_Thanh_International_Airport" title="Long Thanh International Airport">Long Thanh International Airport</a>. The planned Long Thanh International Airport will have an annual service capacity of 100 million passengers once it becomes fully operational in 2025.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Investment_Review2018_312-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Investment_Review2018-312">[306]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_Airlines" title="Vietnam Airlines">Vietnam Airlines</a>, the state-owned national airline maintains a fleet of 86 passenger aircraft and aims to operate 170 by 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHaGiangDenslow2012_313-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHaGiangDenslow2012-313">[307]</a></sup> Several private airlines are also in operation in Vietnam, including <a href="/wiki/Air_Mekong" title="Air Mekong">Air Mekong</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bamboo_Airways" title="Bamboo Airways">Bamboo Airways</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jetstar_Pacific_Airlines" title="Jetstar Pacific Airlines">Jetstar Pacific Airlines</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vietnam_Air_Service_Company" title="Vietnam Air Service Company">VASCO</a> and <a href="/wiki/VietJet_Air" title="VietJet Air">VietJet Air</a>. As a coastal country, Vietnam has many major sea ports, including <a href="/wiki/Cam_Ranh" title="Cam Ranh">Cam Ranh</a>, &#272;&#224; N&#7861;ng, <a href="/wiki/Haiphong" title="Haiphong">H&#7843;i Ph&#242;ng</a>, Ho Chi Minh City, <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BA%A1_Long" title="H&#7841; Long">H&#7841; Long</a>, <a href="/wiki/Qui_Nh%C6%A1n" title="Qui Nh&#417;n">Qui Nh&#417;n</a>, <a href="/wiki/V%C5%A9ng_T%C3%A0u" title="V&#361;ng T&#224;u">V&#361;ng T&#224;u</a>, <a href="/wiki/C%E1%BB%ADa_L%C3%B2" title="C&#7917;a L&#242;">C&#7917;a L&#242;</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nha_Trang" title="Nha Trang">Nha Trang</a>. Further inland, the country\'s extensive network of rivers play a key role in rural transportation with over 47,130 kilometres (29,290&#160;mi) of navigable <a href="/wiki/Waterway" title="Waterway">waterways</a> carrying ferries, barges and <a href="/wiki/Water_taxi" title="Water taxi">water taxis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIndex_Mundi2018_314-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIndex_Mundi2018-314">[308]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Vietnam" title="Energy in Vietnam">Energy in Vietnam</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_power_stations_in_Vietnam" title="List of power stations in Vietnam">List of power stations in Vietnam</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:S%C6%A1n_La_Dam.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1728" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/S%C6%A1n_La_Dam.JPG/220px-S%C6%A1n_La_Dam.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/S%C6%A1n_La_Dam.JPG/330px-S%C6%A1n_La_Dam.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/S%C6%A1n_La_Dam.JPG/440px-S%C6%A1n_La_Dam.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:S%C6%A1n_La_Dam.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/S%C6%A1n_La_Dam" title="S&#417;n La Dam">S&#417;n La Dam</a> in northern Vietnam, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_hydroelectric_power_stations" title="List of largest hydroelectric power stations">largest hydroelectric dam</a> in Southeast Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIntellasia2010_315-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIntellasia2010-315">[309]</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>Vietnam\'s energy sector is largely dominated by <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_Electricity" title="Vietnam Electricity">Electricity of Vietnam</a> (EVN) nationwide. As of 2017, EVN contributed about 61.4% of the country power generation system with a total power capacity of 25,884 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Megawatt" title="Megawatt">MW</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEElectricity_of_Vietnam201710_316-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEElectricity_of_Vietnam201710-316">[310]</a></sup> Other energy source are distributed by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PetroVietnam" title="PetroVietnam">PetroVietnam</a> (4,435 MW), <a href="/wiki/Vinacomin" title="Vinacomin">Vinacomin</a> (1,785 MW) and by <a href="/wiki/Build%E2%80%93operate%E2%80%93transfer" title="Build&#8211;operate&#8211;transfer">build&#8211;operate&#8211;transfer</a> (BOT) with other investors (10,031 MW).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEElectricity_of_Vietnam201712_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEElectricity_of_Vietnam201712-317">[311]</a></sup> Most of the powers are generated from either <a href="/wiki/Hydropower" title="Hydropower">hydropower</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuel_power_station" title="Fossil fuel power station">fossil fuel power</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Coal" title="Coal">coal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oil" title="Oil">oil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">gas</a> while the remaining are from <a href="/wiki/Diesel_fuel" title="Diesel fuel">diesel</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Small_hydropower" title="Small hydropower">small hydropower</a> and renewable energy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEElectricity_of_Vietnam201712_317-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEElectricity_of_Vietnam201712-317">[311]</a></sup> The Vietnamese government also previously planning to develop their first <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_reactor" title="Nuclear reactor">nuclear reactor</a> as the path to establish <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_energy_in_Vietnam" title="Nuclear energy in Vietnam">another source of electric energy</a> from <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power" title="Nuclear power">nuclear power</a> but the plan was abandoned in late 2016 with a majority oppose vote through the country National Assembly due to large concerns from Vietnamese society over <a href="/wiki/Radioactive_contamination" title="Radioactive contamination">radioactive contamination</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENguyenBinh_MinhPhamBurmistrova2016_318-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENguyenBinh_MinhPhamBurmistrova2016-318">[312]</a></sup> The household gas sector in Vietnam is dominated by PetroVietnam which controls nearly 70% of the country domestic market for <a href="/wiki/Liquefied_petroleum_gas" title="Liquefied petroleum gas">liquefied petroleum gas</a> (LPG).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENikkei_Asian_Review_319-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENikkei_Asian_Review-319">[313]</a></sup> Since 2011, the company also operating five renewable energy power plants including the Nh&#417;n Tr&#7841;ch 2 Thermal Power Plant (750 MW), Ph&#250; Qu&#253; Wind Power Plant (6 MW), H&#7911;a Na Hydro-power Plant (180 MW), Dakdrinh Hydro-power Plant (125 MW) and V&#361;ng &#193;ng 1 Thermal Power Plant (1,200 MW).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEViet_TrungQuoc_VietVan_Chat201670_320-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEViet_TrungQuoc_VietVan_Chat201670-320">[314]</a></sup> According to statistics by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Petroleum" title="British Petroleum">British Petroleum</a> (BP), Vietnam is listed among the 52 countries that have oil and gas potential in the world with <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_proven_oil_reserves" title="List of countries by proven oil reserves">proven crude oil reserves</a> of the country in 2015 were approximately 4.4 billion barrels and ranked first place in Southeast Asia, while the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_natural_gas_proven_reserves" title="List of countries by natural gas proven reserves">proven gas reserves</a> were about 0.6 trillion cubic metres (tcm) and ranked the third place in Southeast Asia after <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Malaysia" title="Malaysia">Malaysia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEViet_TrungQuoc_VietVan_Chat201664_321-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEViet_TrungQuoc_VietVan_Chat201664-321">[315]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Water_supply_and_sanitation">Water supply and sanitation</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Vietnam" title="Water supply and sanitation in Vietnam">Water supply and sanitation in Vietnam</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Village_vietnam_sapa_bridge.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2048" data-file-width="1536" decoding="async" height="293" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Village_vietnam_sapa_bridge.jpg/220px-Village_vietnam_sapa_bridge.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Village_vietnam_sapa_bridge.jpg/330px-Village_vietnam_sapa_bridge.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Village_vietnam_sapa_bridge.jpg/440px-Village_vietnam_sapa_bridge.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Village_vietnam_sapa_bridge.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>In rural areas of Vietnam, <a href="/wiki/Water_supply" title="Water supply">piped water systems</a> are operated by a wide variety of institutions including a national organisation, people committees (local government), community groups, co-operatives and private companies.</div></div></div>\n<p>Vietnam has 2,360 rivers with average annual discharge of 310 billion <a href="/wiki/Cubic_metre" title="Cubic metre">m&#179;</a> by which raining season accounts for 70% of the whole year discharge.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_Kingdom_Department_for_International_Trade20171_322-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_Kingdom_Department_for_International_Trade20171-322">[316]</a></sup> Most urban <a href="/wiki/Water_supply" title="Water supply">water supply</a> systems in the country have been developed without proper management since the past 10 years. Based on a 2008 survey by Vietnam Water Supply and Sewerage Association (VWSA), the existing water production capacity even exceeded the demand but the service coverage is still very low since most of clean water supply infrastructures are not much developed where it only been delivered to a small proportion of the population with about one third of 727 district towns having some form of piped water supply.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_Kingdom_Department_for_International_Trade20172_323-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_Kingdom_Department_for_International_Trade20172-323">[317]</a></sup> There is also concern on the safety of existing water resources for urban and rural water supply systems since domestic and industrial factories releasing their <a href="/wiki/Wastewater" title="Wastewater">wastewater</a> directly into the water sources without treatment where the government does not take more urgent measures to address the problem with the majority of domestic wastewater is discharged back to the environment and polluting the <a href="/wiki/Surface_water" title="Surface water">surface water</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_Kingdom_Department_for_International_Trade20172_323-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_Kingdom_Department_for_International_Trade20172-323">[317]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In recent years, there have been some efforts and collaboration between local and foreign universities to developing access to safe water in the country by introducing <a href="/wiki/Water_filter" title="Water filter">water filtration system</a> with the growing concern from local population about the serious public health issues associated with water contamination caused by pollution as well the <a href="/wiki/Arsenic_contamination_of_groundwater" title="Arsenic contamination of groundwater">high levels of arsenic</a> in their <a href="/wiki/Groundwater" title="Groundwater">groundwater</a> sources.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUniversity_of_Technology_Sydney2018_324-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUniversity_of_Technology_Sydney2018-324">[318]</a></sup> The government of <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">Netherlands</a> also have been providing aid by focusing its entirety investments in the country mainly on water-related sectors including in <a href="/wiki/Water_treatment" title="Water treatment">water treatment</a> projects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_the_Netherlands2016_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_the_Netherlands2016-325">[319]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_the_Netherlands2018_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_the_Netherlands2018-326">[320]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnh2018_327-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnh2018-327">[321]</a></sup> Regarding <a href="/wiki/Sanitation" title="Sanitation">sanitation</a>, 78% of the population in Vietnam had access to <a href="/wiki/Improved_sanitation" title="Improved sanitation">"improved" sanitation</a> or 94% of the urban population and 70% of the rural population despite there are still about 21 million people in the country lacked accessed to "improved" sanitation according to a survey conducted in 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUNICEF2015_328-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUNICEF2015-328">[322]</a></sup> In 2018, the construction ministry said that the country water supply and drainage industry had been applying hi-tech methods and <a href="/wiki/Information_technology" title="Information technology">information technology</a> (IT) but facing problems such as limited funding, climate change and pollution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVi&#7879;t_Nam_News2018c_329-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVi&#7879;t_Nam_News2018c-329">[323]</a></sup> The health ministry also have announced that water inspection units will be established in the country nationwide from June 2019 with inspections to be conducted without notice since there have been many cases involving health caused by poor and polluted water supply as well hygiene conditions are reported every year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVi&#7879;t_Nam_News2018d_330-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVi&#7879;t_Nam_News2018d-330">[324]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Vietnam" title="Health in Vietnam">Health in Vietnam</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:FV_hospital.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2560" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/FV_hospital.JPG/220px-FV_hospital.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/FV_hospital.JPG/330px-FV_hospital.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/FV_hospital.JPG/440px-FV_hospital.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:FV_hospital.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Franco-Vietnamese_Hospital" title="Franco-Vietnamese Hospital">Franco-Vietnamese Hospital</a> in <a href="/wiki/District_7,_Ho_Chi_Minh_City" title="District 7, Ho Chi Minh City">District 7</a>, Ho Chi Minh City</div></div></div>\n<p>By 2015, 97% of the population had access to improved water sources.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIndex_Mundi2016_331-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIndex_Mundi2016-331">[325]</a></sup> In 2016, Vietnam\'s national <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">life expectancy</a> stood at 80.9 years for women and 71.5 for men, and the <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality" title="Infant mortality">infant mortality</a> rate was 17 per 1,000 live births.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2016a_9-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2016a-9">[7]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2016b_332-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2016b-332">[326]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2017_333-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2017-333">[327]</a></sup> Despite these improvements, <a href="/wiki/Malnutrition" title="Malnutrition">malnutrition</a> is still common in the rural provinces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWagstaffvan_DoorslaerWatanabe2003_158-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWagstaffvan_DoorslaerWatanabe2003-158">[153]</a></sup> Since the partition, North Vietnam has established a public health system that reached down to the <a href="/wiki/Hamlet_(place)" title="Hamlet (place)">hamlet</a> level.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Harvard_Crimson1972_334-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Harvard_Crimson1972-334">[328]</a></sup> After the national reunification in 1975, a nationwide health service was established.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWagstaffvan_DoorslaerWatanabe2003_158-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWagstaffvan_DoorslaerWatanabe2003-158">[153]</a></sup> In the late 1980s, the quality of healthcare declined to some degree as a result of budgetary constraints, a shift of responsibility to the provinces and the introduction of charges.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECuong_LeKuboFujinoMinh_Pham201023_265-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECuong_LeKuboFujinoMinh_Pham201023-265">[259]</a></sup> Inadequate funding has also contributed to a shortage of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nurses" title="Nurses">nurses</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Midwives" title="Midwives">midwives</a> and hospital beds; in 2000, Vietnam had only 24.7 hospital beds per 10,000 people before declining to 23.7 in 2005 as stated in the annual report of <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_(Vietnam)" title="Ministry of Health (Vietnam)">Vietnamese Health Ministry</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrung_Chien200665_335-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrung_Chien200665-335">[329]</a></sup> The controversial use of herbicides as a chemical weapon by the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces" title="United States Armed Forces">US military</a> during the war has left tangible, long-term <a href="/wiki/Effects_of_Agent_Orange_on_the_Vietnamese_people" title="Effects of Agent Orange on the Vietnamese people">impacts upon the Vietnamese people</a> that still persists in the country until present.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBBC_News2005_336-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBBC_News2005-336">[330]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHaberman2014_337-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHaberman2014-337">[331]</a></sup> For instance, it led to 3 million Vietnamese people suffering health problems, one million birth defects caused directly by exposure to the chemical and 24% of the area of Vietnam being defoliated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGustafsson2010125_338-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGustafsson2010125-338">[332]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Since the early 2000s, Vietnam has made significant progress in combating <a href="/wiki/Malaria" title="Malaria">malaria</a>, with the malaria mortality rate falling to about 5% of its 1990s equivalent by 2005, after the country introduced improved antimalarial drugs and treatment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Namde_VriesVan_ToiNagelkerke2005_339-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Namde_VriesVan_ToiNagelkerke2005-339">[333]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tuberculosis" title="Tuberculosis">Tuberculosis</a> (TB) cases however are on the rise which become the second most infectious diseases in the country after <a href="/wiki/Respiratory_disease" title="Respiratory disease">respiratory-related illness</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrinhNguyenDoNguyen2016_340-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrinhNguyenDoNguyen2016-340">[334]</a></sup> With an intensified vaccination program, better hygiene and foreign assistance, Vietnam hopes to reduce sharply the number of TB cases and annual new TB infections.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcNeil_Jr.2016_341-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcNeil_Jr.2016-341">[335]</a></sup> In 2004, government subsidies covering about 15% of health care expenses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELiebermanWagstaff200940_342-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELiebermanWagstaff200940-342">[336]</a></sup> Along the same year, the United States announced that Vietnam would be one of 15 nations to receive funding as part of its global AIDS relief plan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEManyin20054_343-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEManyin20054-343">[337]</a></sup> By the following year, Vietnam had diagnosed 101,291 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Human_immunodeficiency_virus" title="Human immunodeficiency virus">human immunodeficiency virus</a> (HIV) cases, of which 16,528 progressed to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Acquired_immune_deficiency_syndrome" title="Acquired immune deficiency syndrome">acquired immune deficiency syndrome</a> (AIDS) with 9,554 have died.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Women\'s_Union2005_344-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Women\'s_Union2005-344">[338]</a></sup> The actual number of HIV-positive individuals is estimated to be much higher as on average as between 40&#8211;50 new infections are reported daily in the country. In 2007, 0.4% of the population is estimated to be infected with HIV and the figure has remained stable since 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2018a_345-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2018a-345">[339]</a></sup> More global aid are being delivered through <a href="/wiki/The_Global_Fund_to_Fight_AIDS,_Tuberculosis_and_Malaria" title="The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria">The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria</a> to fight the spread of the diseases in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcNeil_Jr.2016_341-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcNeil_Jr.2016-341">[335]</a></sup> In September 2018, the Hanoi People\'s Committee urged the citizens of the country to stop eating <a href="/wiki/Dog_meat" title="Dog meat">dog</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cat_meat" title="Cat meat">cat meat</a> as it can cause other diseases like <a href="/wiki/Rabies" title="Rabies">rabies</a> and <a href="/wiki/Leptospirosis" title="Leptospirosis">leptospirosis</a> as more than 1,000 stores in the capital city of Hanoi are found to be selling both meats. The decision received positive comments among Vietnamese society on <a href="/wiki/Social_media" title="Social media">social media</a> despite many still disagreed as it has been a habit that couldn\'t be resisted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBBC_News2018_346-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBBC_News2018-346">[340]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Vietnam" title="Education in Vietnam">Education in Vietnam</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:VNU_lethanhtong_900x600.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1004" data-file-width="1506" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/VNU_lethanhtong_900x600.jpg/220px-VNU_lethanhtong_900x600.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/VNU_lethanhtong_900x600.jpg/330px-VNU_lethanhtong_900x600.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/VNU_lethanhtong_900x600.jpg/440px-VNU_lethanhtong_900x600.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:VNU_lethanhtong_900x600.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indochina_Medical_College" title="Indochina Medical College">Indochina Medical College</a> in Hanoi, the first modern university in Vietnam</div></div></div><p>\nVietnam has an extensive state-controlled network of schools, colleges and universities and a growing number of privately run and partially privatised institutions. General education in Vietnam is divided into five categories: <a href="/wiki/Kindergarten" title="Kindergarten">kindergarten</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elementary_school" title="Elementary school">elementary schools</a>, <a href="/wiki/Middle_school" title="Middle school">middle schools</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High_school" title="High school">high schools</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Universities" title="Universities">universities</a>. A large number of public schools have been constructed across the country to raise the national <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Literacy_rate" title="Literacy rate">literacy rate</a>, which stood at 90% in 2008.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUNICEF_347-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUNICEF-347">[341]</a></sup> Most universities are located in major cities of Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City with the country education system continuously undergoing a series of reform by the government. <a href="/wiki/Basic_education" title="Basic education">Basic education</a> in the country is relatively free for the poor although some families may still have trouble paying tuition fee for their children without some form of public or private assistance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHa_Tr&#226;n2014_348-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHa_Tr&#226;n2014-348">[342]</a></sup> Regardless, school enrolment is among the highest in the world,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2013_349-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2013-349">[343]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2015_350-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2015-350">[344]</a></sup> and the number of colleges and universities increased dramatically in the 2000s from 178 in 2000 to 299 in 2005. In higher education, the government provide subsidised loans for students through national bank although there are deep concerns about its access as well the burdens among students in repaying.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPham2012_351-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPham2012-351">[345]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChapmanLiu2013_352-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChapmanLiu2013-352">[346]</a></sup></p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:RMIT_Vietnam_Saigon_campus.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="398" data-file-width="760" decoding="async" height="115" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/RMIT_Vietnam_Saigon_campus.jpg/220px-RMIT_Vietnam_Saigon_campus.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/RMIT_Vietnam_Saigon_campus.jpg/330px-RMIT_Vietnam_Saigon_campus.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/RMIT_Vietnam_Saigon_campus.jpg/440px-RMIT_Vietnam_Saigon_campus.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:RMIT_Vietnam_Saigon_campus.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/RMIT_University_Vietnam" title="RMIT University Vietnam">RMIT Vietnam</a>&#8217;s <a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_City" title="Ho Chi Minh City">Ho Chi Minh City</a> campus.</div></div></div><p>Since 1995, enrolment in higher education has grown tenfold to over 2.2 million with 84,000
