Ninh</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:right;">272,634\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">9</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/H%E1%BA%A3i_D%C6%B0%C6%A1ng" title="H&#7843;i D&#432;&#417;ng">H&#7843;i D&#432;&#417;ng</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/H%E1%BA%A3i_D%C6%B0%C6%A1ng" title="H&#7843;i D&#432;&#417;ng">H&#7843;i D&#432;&#417;ng</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:right;">403,893</td>\n<td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">19</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Th%E1%BB%A7_D%E1%BA%A7u_M%E1%BB%99t" title="Th&#7911; D&#7847;u M&#7897;t">Th&#7911; D&#7847;u M&#7897;t</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/B%C3%ACnh_D%C6%B0%C6%A1ng" title="B&#236;nh D&#432;&#417;ng">B&#236;nh D&#432;&#417;ng</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:right;">271,000\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">10</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%A0_L%E1%BA%A1t" title="&#272;&#224; L&#7841;t">&#272;&#224; L&#7841;t</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/L%C3%A2m_%C4%90%E1%BB%93ng" title="L&#226;m &#272;&#7891;ng">L&#226;m &#272;&#7891;ng</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:right;">356,393</td>\n<td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">20</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Th%C3%A1i_B%C3%ACnh" title="Th&#225;i B&#236;nh">Th&#225;i B&#236;nh</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Th%C3%A1i_B%C3%ACnh" title="Th&#225;i B&#236;nh">Th&#225;i B&#236;nh</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:right;">270,000\n</td></tr>\n</tbody></table>\n<div style="clear:both;"></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Vietnam" title="Religion in Vietnam">Religion in Vietnam</a></div>\n<div class="PieChartTemplate thumb tright" style=""><div class="thumbinner" style="width:200px">\n<div style="background-color:white;margin:auto;position:relative;width:200px;height:200px;overflow:hidden;border-radius:100px;border:1px solid black">\n<div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:0; top:0; border-width:0 200px 200px 0; border-color:#F0FFF0"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 15915.284869156px; border-left-color:#FFF8DC"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#FFF8DC"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:#FFF8DC"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 1057.8894993407px; border-left-color:#87CEFA"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#87CEFA"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:#87CEFA"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 524.21835811135px; border-left-color:#FF69B4"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#FF69B4"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:#FF69B4"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 187.44080219943px; border-left-color:#DDA0DD"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#DDA0DD"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:#DDA0DD"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 76.566454547803px; border-left-color:#FFDEAD"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#FFDEAD"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:#FFDEAD"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;right:100px; top:100px; border-width:99.361131052001px 11.285638487348px 0 0; border-top-color:#E0FFFF"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#E0FFFF"></div>\n</div>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<p>Religion in Vietnam (2014)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBielefeldt2014_3-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBielefeldt2014-3">[2]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #E0FFFF; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_folk_religion" title="Vietnamese folk religion">Vietnamese folk religion</a> or not religious population (73.2%)</div><div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #FFDEAD; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a> (12.2%)</div><div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #DDA0DD; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholicism" title="Catholicism">Catholicism</a> (6.8%)</div><div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #FF69B4; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Caodaism" title="Caodaism">Caodaism</a> (4.8%)</div><div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #87CEFA; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestantism</a> (1.5%)</div><div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #FFF8DC; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;<a href="/wiki/H%C3%B2a_H%E1%BA%A3o" title="H&#242;a H&#7843;o">Hoahaoism</a> (1.4%)</div><div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #F0FFF0; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;Others (0.1%)</div>\n</div>\n</div></div>\n<p>Under Article 70 of the 1992 Constitution of Vietnam, all citizens enjoy <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">freedom of belief and religion</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Vietnam1992_374-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Vietnam1992-374">[368]</a></sup> which means that they can follow any religion or be <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Irreligious" title="Irreligious">irreligious</a> and that all religions are equal before the law and that each <a href="/wiki/Place_of_worship" title="Place of worship">place of worship</a> is protected under Vietnamese state law, but religious beliefs cannot be misused to undermine state law and policies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Vietnam1992_374-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Vietnam1992-374">[368]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ordinance_of_Beliefs_and_Religion2004_375-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ordinance_of_Beliefs_and_Religion2004-375">[369]</a></sup> According to a survey in 2007, 81% of the Vietnamese people <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">do not believe in a god</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZuckerman200711_376-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZuckerman200711-376">[370]</a></sup> Based on new government findings in 2009, the number of religious people has increased by 932,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2009a_357-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2009a-357">[351]</a></sup> Through the latest official statistics presented by the Vietnamese government to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_special_rapporteur" title="United Nations special rapporteur">United Nations special rapporteur</a> in 2014,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBielefeldt2014_3-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBielefeldt2014-3">[2]</a></sup> the overall number of followers of recognised religions is about 24 million from the total population of almost 90 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBielefeldt2014_3-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBielefeldt2014-3">[2]</a></sup> Formally recognised religious communities include 11 million <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhist" title="Buddhist">Buddhists</a>, 6.2 million <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholicism" title="Catholicism">Catholics</a>, 1.4 million <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestants</a>, 4.4 million <a href="/wiki/Caodaism" title="Caodaism">Caodaisms</a> followers, 1.3 million <a href="/wiki/H%C3%B2a_H%E1%BA%A3o" title="H&#242;a H&#7843;o">Hoahaoism Buddhists</a> as well as 75,000 <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Muslims</a>, 7,000 <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD_Faith" title="Bah&#225;\'&#237; Faith">Baha\'&#237;s</a> and 1,500 <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hindus</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBielefeldt2014_3-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBielefeldt2014-3">[2]</a></sup>\n</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81y%C4%81na_Buddhism" title="Mah&#257;y&#257;na Buddhism">Mah&#257;y&#257;na</a> is the dominant branch of Buddhism among the Kinh majority who follows religion, while <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Therav%C4%81da_Buddhism" title="Therav&#257;da Buddhism">Therav&#257;da</a> are practised in almost entirely by the Khmer minority. About 7% of the population are Christians, totalling around six million Roman Catholics and one million Protestants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBielefeldt2014_3-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBielefeldt2014-3">[2]</a></sup> Catholicism have been introduced to Vietnam by nearby <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese</a> missionaries (<i><a href="/wiki/Society_of_Jesus" title="Society of Jesus">Jesuits</a></i>) from <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Macau" title="Portuguese Macau">Portuguese Macau</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Malacca" title="Portuguese Malacca">Malacca</a> towards Annam and from remnants of the persecuted <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Catholic_Church_in_Japan" title="History of the Catholic Church in Japan">Japanese Catholic</a> between the 16th and 17th centuries before being massively propagated by French missionaries aided by <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish</a> missionaries (<i><a href="/wiki/Dominican_Order" title="Dominican Order">Dominicans</a></i>) from neighbouring <a href="/wiki/Spanish_East_Indies" title="Spanish East Indies">Spanish East Indies</a> towards Tonkin in the 19th and 20th centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWoods200234_377-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWoods200234-377">[371]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeith201242,_72_378-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeith201242,_72-378">[372]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELamport2018898_379-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELamport2018898-379">[373]</a></sup> A significant number of Vietnamese people are also adherents of Caodaism, an indigenous folk religion which has structured itself on the model of the Catholic Church together with another Buddhist section of Hoahaoism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELargo2002168_380-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELargo2002168-380">[374]</a></sup> Protestantism was only recently spread by American and Canadian missionaries throughout the modern civil war,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Hoang20171_381-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Hoang20171-381">[375]</a></sup> where it was largely accepted among the highland <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Montagnard_(Vietnam)" title="Montagnard (Vietnam)">Montagnards</a> of South Vietnam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECultural_Orientation_Resource_Centre5,_7_382-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECultural_Orientation_Resource_Centre5,_7-382">[376]</a></sup> The largest Protestant churches are the Southern Evangelical Church of Vietnam (SECV) and the Evangelical Church of Vietnam North (ECVN) with around 770,000 of the country Protestants come from members of ethnic minorities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Hoang20171_381-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Hoang20171-381">[375]</a></sup> Although it is one of the country minority religion and has a shorter history than Catholicism, Protestantism are found to be the country\'s <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fastest-growing_religion" title="Fastest-growing religion">fastest-growing religion</a>, expanding at a rate of 600% in recent decades.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Hoang20171_381-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Hoang20171-381">[375]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_States_Department_of_State2005_383-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_States_Department_of_State2005-383">[377]</a></sup> Several other minority faiths exist in Vietnam, these includes Bani, <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni</a> and <a href="/wiki/Non-denominational_Muslim" title="Non-denominational Muslim">non-denominational</a> section of Islam which is primarily practised among the ethnic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cham_people" title="Cham people">Cham</a> minority,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEK&#7923;_Ph&#432;&#417;ngLockhart201135_384-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEK&#7923;_Ph&#432;&#417;ngLockhart201135-384">[378]</a></sup> though there were also a few Kinh adherents of Islam along with other minority adherents of Baha\'is as well <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Southeast_Asia#Vietnam" title="Hinduism in Southeast Asia">Hindus among the Cham</a>\'s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELevinsonChristensen200289_385-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELevinsonChristensen200289-385">[379]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma200948_386-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma200948-386">[380]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Amit_Offir%27s_Book_-_24-8_(Vietnamese_Edition).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2268" data-file-width="4032" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Amit_Offir%27s_Book_-_24-8_%28Vietnamese_Edition%29.jpg/220px-Amit_Offir%27s_Book_-_24-8_%28Vietnamese_Edition%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Amit_Offir%27s_Book_-_24-8_%28Vietnamese_Edition%29.jpg/330px-Amit_Offir%27s_Book_-_24-8_%28Vietnamese_Edition%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Amit_Offir%27s_Book_-_24-8_%28Vietnamese_Edition%29.jpg/440px-Amit_Offir%27s_Book_-_24-8_%28Vietnamese_Edition%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Amit_Offir%27s_Book_-_24-8_(Vietnamese_Edition).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese language</a> books in a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bookstore" title="Bookstore">bookstore</a> in Ho Chi Minh City.</div></div></div>\n<p>The official national language of the country is <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese</a> (<i>Ti&#7871;ng Vi&#7879;t</i>), a tonal <a href="/wiki/Austroasiatic_languages" title="Austroasiatic languages">Austroasiatic languages</a> (Mon&#8211;Khmer) which is spoken by the majority of the population. In its early history, Vietnamese writing used <a href="/wiki/Chinese_characters" title="Chinese characters">Chinese characters</a> before a different meaning set of Chinese characters known as <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ch%E1%BB%AF_n%C3%B4m" title="Ch&#7919; n&#244;m">Ch&#7919; n&#244;m</a></i> developed between the 7th&#8211;13th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZwartjes2011292_387-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZwartjes2011292-387">[381]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChoy2013340_388-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChoy2013340-388">[382]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDinh_Tham201867_389-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDinh_Tham201867-389">[383]</a></sup> The folk epic <i lang="vi" title="Vietnamese language text"><a href="/wiki/The_Tale_of_Kieu" title="The Tale of Kieu">Truy&#7879;n Ki&#7873;u</a></i> ("The Tale of Kieu", originally known as <i lang="vi" title="Vietnamese language text">&#272;o&#7841;n tr&#432;&#7901;ng t&#226;n thanh</i>) by <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Du" title="Nguy&#7877;n Du">Nguy&#7877;n Du</a> was written in <i>Ch&#7919; n&#244;m</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOzolin&#353;2016130_390-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOzolin&#353;2016130-390">[384]</a></sup> <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Qu%E1%BB%91c_ng%E1%BB%AF" title="Qu&#7889;c ng&#7919;">Qu&#7889;c ng&#7919;</a></i> as the romanised Vietnamese alphabet used for spoken Vietnamese, was developed in the 17th century by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jesuit" title="Jesuit">Jesuit</a> <a href="/wiki/Alexandre_de_Rhodes" title="Alexandre de Rhodes">Alexandre de Rhodes</a> and several other Catholic missionaries by using the alphabets of <a href="/wiki/Romance_languages" title="Romance languages">Romance languages</a>, particularly the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Portuguese_alphabet" title="Portuguese alphabet">Portuguese alphabet</a> which later became widely used through Vietnamese institutions during the French colonial period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZwartjes2011292_387-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZwartjes2011292-387">[381]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJacques199821_391-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJacques199821-391">[385]</a></sup> Vietnam\'s minority groups speak a variety of languages, including <a href="/wiki/T%C3%A0y_language" title="T&#224;y language">T&#224;y</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muong_language" title="Muong language">M&#432;&#7901;ng</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cham_language" title="Cham language">Cham</a>, <a href="/wiki/Khmer_language" title="Khmer language">Khmer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_language" title="Chinese language">Chinese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nung_language_(Tai)" title="Nung language (Tai)">N&#249;ng</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hmong_language" title="Hmong language">Hmong</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Montagnard_(Vietnam)" title="Montagnard (Vietnam)">Montagnard</a> peoples of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Highlands_(Vietnam)" title="Central Highlands (Vietnam)">Central Highlands</a> also speak a number of distinct languages as their language is derived from both the Austroasiatic and <a href="/wiki/Malayo-Polynesian_languages" title="Malayo-Polynesian languages">Malayo-Polynesian</a> language groups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECultural_Orientation_Resource_Centre10_392-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECultural_Orientation_Resource_Centre10-392">[386]</a></sup> In recent years, a number of <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_sign_languages" title="Vietnamese sign languages">sign languages</a> have developed in the major cities.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vietnamese_calligraphy.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="505" data-file-width="760" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Vietnamese_calligraphy.jpg/220px-Vietnamese_calligraphy.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Vietnamese_calligraphy.jpg/330px-Vietnamese_calligraphy.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Vietnamese_calligraphy.jpg/440px-Vietnamese_calligraphy.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vietnamese_calligraphy.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Traditional <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_calligraphy" title="Vietnamese calligraphy">Vietnamese calligraphy</a>.</div></div></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French language</a>, a legacy of colonial rule, is spoken by many educated Vietnamese as a second language, especially among the older generation and those educated in the former <a href="/wiki/South_Vietnam" title="South Vietnam">South Vietnam</a>, where it was a principal language in administration, education and commerce. Vietnam remains a full member of the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_internationale_de_la_Francophonie" title="Organisation internationale de la Francophonie">International Organisation of the Francophonie</a> (La Francophonie) and education has revived some interest in the language.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrench_Senate1997_393-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrench_Senate1997-393">[387]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a> and to a much lesser extent <a href="/wiki/German_language" title="German language">German</a>, <a href="/wiki/Czech_language" title="Czech language">Czech</a> and <a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish</a> are known among some northern Vietnamese whose families had ties with the Eastern Bloc during the Cold War.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENguyen2012261_394-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENguyen2012261-394">[388]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Van8_395-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Van8-395">[389]</a></sup> With improved relations with Western countries and recent reforms in Vietnamese administration, <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a> has been increasingly used as a second language and the study of English is now obligatory in most schools either alongside or in place of French.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENguyen2012259_396-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENguyen2012259-396">[390]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Van9_397-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Van9-397">[391]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_Kingdom_Department_for_International_Trade2018_398-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_Kingdom_Department_for_International_Trade2018-398">[392]</a></sup> The popularity of <a href="/wiki/Japanese_language" title="Japanese language">Japanese</a> and <a href="/wiki/Korean_language" title="Korean language">Korean</a> have also grown as the country\'s ties with other East Asian nations have strengthened.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWai-ming20023_399-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWai-ming20023-399">[393]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnh_Dinh201663_400-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnh_Dinh201663-400">[394]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirano2016_401-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirano2016-401">[395]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Vietnam" title="Culture of Vietnam">Culture of Vietnam</a></div>\n<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hanoi_Temple_of_Litterature.jpeg"><img alt="The Temple of Literature in Hanoi" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Hanoi_Temple_of_Litterature.jpeg/200px-Hanoi_Temple_of_Litterature.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Hanoi_Temple_of_Litterature.jpeg/300px-Hanoi_Temple_of_Litterature.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Hanoi_Temple_of_Litterature.jpeg/400px-Hanoi_Temple_of_Litterature.jpeg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Temple_of_Literature" title="Temple of Literature">Temple of Literature</a> in Hanoi</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%C3%93pera,_Ciudad_Ho_Chi_Minh,_Vietnam,_2013-08-14,_DD_02.JPG"><img alt="The Municipal Theatre in Ho Chi Minh City" data-file-height="3101" data-file-width="5114" decoding="async" height="121" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/%C3%93pera%2C_Ciudad_Ho_Chi_Minh%2C_Vietnam%2C_2013-08-14%2C_DD_02.JPG/200px-%C3%93pera%2C_Ciudad_Ho_Chi_Minh%2C_Vietnam%2C_2013-08-14%2C_DD_02.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/%C3%93pera%2C_Ciudad_Ho_Chi_Minh%2C_Vietnam%2C_2013-08-14%2C_DD_02.JPG/300px-%C3%93pera%2C_Ciudad_Ho_Chi_Minh%2C_Vietnam%2C_2013-08-14%2C_DD_02.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/%C3%93pera%2C_Ciudad_Ho_Chi_Minh%2C_Vietnam%2C_2013-08-14%2C_DD_02.JPG/400px-%C3%93pera%2C_Ciudad_Ho_Chi_Minh%2C_Vietnam%2C_2013-08-14%2C_DD_02.JPG 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">The <a href="/wiki/Municipal_Theatre,_Ho_Chi_Minh_City" title="Municipal Theatre, Ho Chi Minh City">Municipal Theatre</a> (Saigon Opera House) in Ho Chi Minh City</div></div></div></div>\n<p>Vietnam\'s culture has developed over the centuries from indigenous ancient <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%B4ng_S%C6%A1n_culture" title="&#272;&#244;ng S&#417;n culture">&#272;&#244;ng S&#417;n culture</a> with wet rice cultivation as its economic base.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHigham1984_32-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHigham1984-32">[28]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECal&#242;200951_35-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECal&#242;200951-35">[31]</a></sup> Some elements of the national culture have Chinese origins, drawing on elements of <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianism</a>, Mah&#257;y&#257;na Buddhism and <a href="/wiki/Taoism" title="Taoism">Taoism</a> in its traditional political system and philosophy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETung_Hieu201571_402-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETung_Hieu201571-402">[396]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENhu_Nguyen201632_403-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENhu_Nguyen201632-403">[397]</a></sup> Vietnamese society is structured around <i>l&#224;ng</i> (ancestral villages);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEndres2001_404-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEndres2001-404">[398]</a></sup> all Vietnamese mark a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gi%E1%BB%97_T%E1%BB%95_H%C3%B9ng_V%C6%B0%C6%A1ng" title="Gi&#7895; T&#7893; H&#249;ng V&#432;&#417;ng">common ancestral anniversary</a> on the tenth day of the third <a href="/wiki/Lunar_calendar" title="Lunar calendar">lunar month</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGrigoreva20144_405-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGrigoreva20144-405">[399]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage2012_406-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage2012-406">[400]</a></sup> The influence of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_culture" title="Chinese culture">Chinese culture</a> such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cantonese_culture" title="Cantonese culture">Cantonese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hakka_culture" title="Hakka culture">Hakka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hokkien_culture" title="Hokkien culture">Hokkien</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hainan" title="Hainan">Hainanese</a> cultures are more evidenced in the north with the national religion of Buddhism is strongly entwined with popular culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZhuRenCollinsWarner2017142_407-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZhuRenCollinsWarner2017142-407">[401]</a></sup> Despite this, there is also a <a href="/wiki/Chinatown" title="Chinatown">Chinatown</a> in the south such as in <a href="/wiki/Ch%E1%BB%A3_L%E1%BB%9Bn,_Ho_Chi_Minh_City" title="Ch&#7907; L&#7899;n, Ho Chi Minh City">Ch&#7907; L&#7899;n</a> where many of the Chinese have <a href="/wiki/Interracial_marriage" title="Interracial marriage">intermarried</a> with Kinh and are presently indistinguishable among them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcLeodThi_Dieu20018_408-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcLeodThi_Dieu20018-408">[402]</a></sup> In the central and southern part, traces of Champa and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Khmer_culture" title="Khmer culture">Khmer culture</a> are evidenced through the remains of ruins, artefacts as well within their population as the successor of the ancient <a href="/wiki/Sa_Hu%E1%BB%B3nh_culture" title="Sa Hu&#7923;nh culture">Sa Hu&#7923;nh culture</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMomoki199636_409-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMomoki199636-409">[403]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEK&#7923;_Ph&#432;&#417;ngLockhart201184_410-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEK&#7923;_Ph&#432;&#417;ngLockhart201184-410">[404]</a></sup> In recent centuries, the influence of Western cultures have become popular among newer Vietnamese generations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENhu_Nguyen201632_403-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENhu_Nguyen201632-403">[397]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ao-dai-xu-Hue-2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="601" data-file-width="400" decoding="async" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Ao-dai-xu-Hue-2.jpg/170px-Ao-dai-xu-Hue-2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Ao-dai-xu-Hue-2.jpg/255px-Ao-dai-xu-Hue-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Ao-dai-xu-Hue-2.jpg/340px-Ao-dai-xu-Hue-2.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ao-dai-xu-Hue-2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Vietnamese traditional white <a href="/wiki/School_uniforms_by_country#Vietnam" title="School uniforms by country">school uniform</a> for girls in the country, the <i><a href="/wiki/%C3%81o_d%C3%A0i" title="&#193;o d&#224;i">&#225;o d&#224;i</a></i> with the addition of <i><a href="/wiki/Asian_conical_hat" title="Asian conical hat">n&#243;n l&#225;</a>,</i> a conical hat.</div></div></div>\n<p>The traditional focuses of Vietnamese culture are based on humanity (<i>nh&#226;n ngh&#297;a</i>) and harmony (<i>h&#242;a</i>); in which family and community values are highly regarded.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZhuRenCollinsWarner2017142_407-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZhuRenCollinsWarner2017142-407">[401]</a></sup> Vietnam reveres a number of key cultural symbols,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVo201296_411-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVo201296-411">[405]</a></sup> such as the <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_dragon" title="Vietnamese dragon">Vietnamese dragon</a> which is derived from <a href="/wiki/Crocodile" title="Crocodile">crocodile</a> and <a href="/wiki/Snake" title="Snake">snake</a> imagery; Vietnam\'s national father, <a href="/wiki/L%E1%BA%A1c_Long_Qu%C3%A2n" title="L&#7841;c Long Qu&#226;n">L&#7841;c Long Qu&#226;n</a> is depicted as a holy dragon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGrigoreva20144_405-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGrigoreva20144-405">[399]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGallop2017_412-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGallop2017-412">[406]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnamese-American_Association_413-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnamese-American_Association-413">[407]</a></sup> The <i>l&#7841;c</i> is a holy bird representing Vietnamese national mother of <a href="/wiki/%C3%82u_C%C6%A1" title="&#194;u C&#417;">&#194;u C&#417;</a> is another prominent symbol, while <a href="/wiki/Turtle" title="Turtle">turtle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Water_buffalo" title="Water buffalo">buffalo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Horse" title="Horse">horse</a> images are also revered.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChonchirdsin2016_414-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChonchirdsin2016-414">[408]</a></sup> Many Vietnamese also believes in <a href="/wiki/Supernatural" title="Supernatural">supernatural</a> and <a href="/wiki/Spiritualism" title="Spiritualism">spiritualism</a> where illness could be brought on by a <a href="/wiki/Curse" title="Curse">curse</a> or <a href="/wiki/Witchcraft" title="Witchcraft">sorcery</a> or caused by non-observance of a religious ethic where it needs to be treated through traditional medical practitioners, <a href="/wiki/Amulet" title="Amulet">amulets</a> and other forms of spiritual protection where religious practices may be employed to treating the ill person.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWaitemata_District_Health_Board20152_415-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWaitemata_District_Health_Board20152-415">[409]</a></sup> In the modern era, the cultural life of Vietnam has been deeply influenced by government-controlled media and cultural programs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENhu_Nguyen201632_403-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENhu_Nguyen201632-403">[397]</a></sup> For many decades, foreign cultural influences especially those of Western origin were shunned. But since the recent reformation, Vietnam has seen a greater exposure to neighbouring Southeast Asian, East Asian as well to Western culture and media.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPhuong2012_416-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhuong2012-416">[410]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The main Vietnamese formal dress, the <i><a href="/wiki/%C3%81o_d%C3%A0i" title="&#193;o d&#224;i">&#225;o d&#224;i</a></i> is worn for special occasions such as in weddings and religious festivals. White <i>&#225;o d&#224;i</i> is the required uniform for girls in many high schools across the country. Other examples of traditional Vietnamese clothing include the <i><a href="/wiki/%C3%81o_t%E1%BB%A9_th%C3%A2n" title="&#193;o t&#7913; th&#226;n">&#225;o t&#7913; th&#226;n</a></i>, a four-piece woman\'s dress; the <i>&#225;o ng&#361;</i>, a form of the <i>th&#226;n</i> in 5-piece form, mostly worn in the north of the country; the <i><a href="/wiki/Y%E1%BA%BFm" title="Y&#7871;m">y&#7871;m</a></i>, a woman\'s undergarment; the <i><a href="/wiki/%C3%81o_b%C3%A0_ba" title="&#193;o b&#224; ba">&#225;o b&#224; ba</a></i>, rural working "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pyjamas" title="Pyjamas">pyjamas</a>" for men and women; the <i><a href="/wiki/%C3%81o_g%E1%BA%A5m" title="&#193;o g&#7845;m">&#225;o g&#7845;m</a></i>, a formal brocade tunic for government receptions; and the <i>&#225;o the</i>, a variant of the <i>&#225;o g&#7845;m</i> worn by grooms at weddings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewandowski201112_417-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewandowski201112-417">[411]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoward201690_418-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoward201690-418">[412]</a></sup> Traditional headwear includes the standard conical <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/N%C3%B3n_l%C3%A1" title="N&#243;n l&#225;">n&#243;n l&#225;</a></i> and the "lampshade-like" <i><a href="/wiki/N%C3%B3n_quai_thao" title="N&#243;n quai thao">n&#243;n quai thao</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoward201690_418-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoward201690-418">[412]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChico2013354_419-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChico2013354-419">[413]</a></sup> In tourism, a number of popular cultural tourist destinations include the former imperial capital of Hu&#233;, the <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Sites</a> of <a href="/wiki/Phong_Nha-K%E1%BA%BB_B%C3%A0ng_National_Park" title="Phong Nha-K&#7867; B&#224;ng National Park">Phong Nha-K&#7867; B&#224;ng National Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BB%99i_An" title="H&#7897;i An">H&#7897;i An</a> and <a href="/wiki/M%E1%BB%B9_S%C6%A1n" title="M&#7929; S&#417;n">M&#7929; S&#417;n</a>, coastal regions such as Nha Trang, the caves of H&#7841; Long Bay and the <a href="/wiki/Marble_Mountains_(Vietnam)" title="Marble Mountains (Vietnam)">Marble Mountains</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPha_Le2014_420-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPha_Le2014-420">[414]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Net2017a_421-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Net2017a-421">[415]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_literature" title="Vietnamese literature">Vietnamese literature</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_poetry" title="Vietnamese poetry">Vietnamese poetry</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_fairy_tales" title="Vietnamese fairy tales">Vietnamese fairy tales</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dragon_on_Emperor_Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%99s_scroll,_1917_(British_Library).png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="503" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="123" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Dragon_on_Emperor_Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%99s_scroll%2C_1917_%28British_Library%29.png/250px-Dragon_on_Emperor_Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%99s_scroll%2C_1917_%28British_Library%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Dragon_on_Emperor_Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%99s_scroll%2C_1917_%28British_Library%29.png/375px-Dragon_on_Emperor_Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%99s_scroll%2C_1917_%28British_Library%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Dragon_on_Emperor_Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%99s_scroll%2C_1917_%28British_Library%29.png/500px-Dragon_on_Emperor_Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%99s_scroll%2C_1917_%28British_Library%29.png 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dragon_on_Emperor_Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%99s_scroll,_1917_(British_Library).png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_dragon" title="Vietnamese dragon">Vietnamese dragon</a> on Emperor <a href="/wiki/Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh" title="Kh&#7843;i &#272;&#7883;nh">Kh&#7843;i &#272;&#7883;nh</a>\'s <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">&#8201;1917</span> scroll in <a href="/wiki/British_Library" title="British Library">British Library</a> collection.</div></div></div>\n<p>Vietnamese literature has centuries-deep history and the country has a rich tradition of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Folk_literature" title="Folk literature">folk literature</a> based on the typical 6&#8211;to-8-verse poetic form named <i>ca dao</i> which usually focuses on village ancestors and heroes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHuong2010_422-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuong2010-422">[416]</a></sup> Written literature has been found dating back to the 10th century <a href="/wiki/Ng%C3%B4_dynasty" title="Ng&#244; dynasty">Ng&#244; dynasty</a>, with notable ancient authors including <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Tr%C3%A3i" title="Nguy&#7877;n Tr&#227;i">Nguy&#7877;n Tr&#227;i</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tr%E1%BA%A7n_H%C6%B0ng_%C4%90%E1%BA%A1o" title="Tr&#7847;n H&#432;ng &#272;&#7841;o">Tr&#7847;n H&#432;ng &#272;&#7841;o</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Du" title="Nguy&#7877;n Du">Nguy&#7877;n Du</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_%C4%90%C3%ACnh_Chi%E1%BB%83u" title="Nguy&#7877;n &#272;&#236;nh Chi&#7875;u">Nguy&#7877;n &#272;&#236;nh Chi&#7875;u</a>. Some literary genres play an important role in theatrical performance, such as <i>h&#225;t n&#243;i</i> in <i><a href="/wiki/Ca_tr%C3%B9" title="Ca tr&#249;">ca tr&#249;</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENorton2015_423-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorton2015-423">[417]</a></sup> Some poetic unions have also been formed in Vietnam, such as the <i>tao &#273;&#224;n</i>. Vietnamese literature has in recent times been influenced by Western styles, with the first literary transformation movement of <i><a href="/wiki/Th%C6%A1_m%E1%BB%9Bi" title="Th&#417; m&#7899;i">th&#417; m&#7899;i</a></i> emerging in 1932.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELe2008_424-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELe2008-424">[418]</a></sup> Vietnamese folk literature is an intermingling of many forms. It is not only an oral tradition, but a mixing of three media: hidden (only retained in the memory of folk authors), fixed (written), and shown (performed). Folk literature usually exist in many versions, passed down orally and have unknown authors. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Myths" title="Myths">Myths</a> consist of stories about supernatural beings, heroes, creator gods and reflect the viewpoint of ancient people about human life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVo20124_425-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVo20124-425">[419]</a></sup> They consist of creation stories, stories about their origins (<i>L&#7841;c Long Qu&#226;n</i> and <i>&#194;u C&#417;</i>), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Culture_heroes" title="Culture heroes">culture heroes</a> (<a href="/wiki/S%C6%A1n_Tinh_%E2%80%93_Th%E1%BB%A7y_Tinh" title="S&#417;n Tinh &#8211; Th&#7911;y Tinh"><i>S&#417;n Tinh</i> and <i>Th&#7911;y Tinh</i></a>) which is referred as a mountain and water spirit respectively and many other folklore tales.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcLeodThi_Dieu20018_408-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcLeodThi_Dieu20018-408">[402]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETranLe20175_426-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETranLe20175-426">[420]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Vietnam" title="Music of Vietnam">Music of Vietnam</a></div>\n<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;max-width:252px"><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:122px;max-width:122px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vpop_Monstar.jpg"><img alt="Vietnamese boy band Monstar" data-file-height="1024" data-file-width="683" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Vpop_Monstar.jpg/120px-Vpop_Monstar.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Vpop_Monstar.jpg/180px-Vpop_Monstar.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Vpop_Monstar.jpg/240px-Vpop_Monstar.jpg 2x" width="120"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><center>Vietnamese boy band, <a class="extiw" href="https://vi.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monstar_(nh%C3%B3m_nh%E1%BA%A1c)" title="vi:Monstar (nh&#243;m nh&#7841;c)">Monstar</a>.</center></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:126px;max-width:126px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:S%C6%A1n_T%C3%B9ng_M-TP_h%C3%A1t_Ch%C3%ADn_b%E1%BA%ADc_t%C3%ACnh_y%C3%AAu_t%E1%BA%A1i_%C4%91%C3%AAm_nh%E1%BA%A1c_An_Thuy%C3%AAn_27s.jpg"><img alt="S&#417;n T&#249;ng M-TP, Vietnamese rapper and singer" data-file-height="720" data-file-width="500" decoding="async" height="179" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/S%C6%A1n_T%C3%B9ng_M-TP_h%C3%A1t_Ch%C3%ADn_b%E1%BA%ADc_t%C3%ACnh_y%C3%AAu_t%E1%BA%A1i_%C4%91%C3%AAm_nh%E1%BA%A1c_An_Thuy%C3%AAn_27s.jpg/124px-S%C6%A1n_T%C3%B9ng_M-TP_h%C3%A1t_Ch%C3%ADn_b%E1%BA%ADc_t%C3%ACnh_y%C3%AAu_t%E1%BA%A1i_%C4%91%C3%AAm_nh%E1%BA%A1c_An_Thuy%C3%AAn_27s.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/S%C6%A1n_T%C3%B9ng_M-TP_h%C3%A1t_Ch%C3%ADn_b%E1%BA%ADc_t%C3%ACnh_y%C3%AAu_t%E1%BA%A1i_%C4%91%C3%AAm_nh%E1%BA%A1c_An_Thuy%C3%AAn_27s.jpg/186px-S%C6%A1n_T%C3%B9ng_M-TP_h%C3%A1t_Ch%C3%ADn_b%E1%BA%ADc_t%C3%ACnh_y%C3%AAu_t%E1%BA%A1i_%C4%91%C3%AAm_nh%E1%BA%A1c_An_Thuy%C3%AAn_27s.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/S%C6%A1n_T%C3%B9ng_M-TP_h%C3%A1t_Ch%C3%ADn_b%E1%BA%ADc_t%C3%ACnh_y%C3%AAu_t%E1%BA%A1i_%C4%91%C3%AAm_nh%E1%BA%A1c_An_Thuy%C3%AAn_27s.jpg/248px-S%C6%A1n_T%C3%B9ng_M-TP_h%C3%A1t_Ch%C3%ADn_b%E1%BA%ADc_t%C3%ACnh_y%C3%AAu_t%E1%BA%A1i_%C4%91%C3%AAm_nh%E1%BA%A1c_An_Thuy%C3%AAn_27s.jpg 2x" width="124"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><center><a href="/wiki/S%C6%A1n_T%C3%B9ng_M-TP" title="S&#417;n T&#249;ng M-TP">S&#417;n T&#249;ng M-TP</a>, Vietnamese <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rapper" title="Rapper">rapper</a> and singer.</center></div></div><div style="clear:left"></div></div></div>\n<p><a href="/wiki/Bolero#Vietnam" title="Bolero">Bolero</a> music has gained its position in the country since 1930s, albeit with a different style from a combination between traditional Vietnamese music with Western elements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDuy2016_427-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDuy2016-427">[421]</a></sup> However, the modern Vietnamese music industry, known as <a href="/wiki/V-pop" title="V-pop">V-pop</a>, is currently making its mark in the entertainment field. Many Vietnamese artists have started to collaborate with foreign artists and producers, especially South Korean, to facilitate the entrance of <a href="/wiki/K-pop" title="K-pop">K-pop</a> into the Vietnamese market while also promoting V-pop overseas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChen2018194_428-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChen2018194-428">[422]</a></sup> For example, in 2014, the South Korean seven-member <a href="/wiki/Boy_band" title="Boy band">boy band</a> <a href="/wiki/BTS_(band)" title="BTS (band)">BTS</a> (&#48169;&#53444;&#49548;&#45380;&#45800;) collaborated with Vietnamese singer <a href="/wiki/North_(band)" title="North (band)">Thanh B&#249;i</a> on the single called "<a href="/wiki/Dark_%26_Wild#Track_listing" title="Dark &amp; Wild">Danger</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChen2018194_428-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChen2018194-428">[422]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYan_News2014_429-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYan_News2014-429">[423]</a></sup> In 2018, South Korean artist and idol <a href="/wiki/Park_Ji-yeon" title="Park Ji-yeon">Park Ji-yeon</a> (&#48149;&#51648;&#50672;) collaborated with <a class="extiw" href="https://vi.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soobin_Ho%C3%A0ng_S%C6%A1n" title="vi:Soobin Ho&#224;ng S&#417;n">Soobin Ho&#224;ng S&#417;n</a> in two versions of the title track called "Between Us" (<a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese</a>: <i lang="vi">&#272;&#7865;p Nh&#7845;t L&#224; Em</i>; <a href="/wiki/Korean_language" title="Korean language">Korean</a>: <span lang="ko">&#50864;&#47532;&#49324;&#51060;</span>) to promote the two countries&#8217; partnership in terms of the music industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPh&#432;&#417;ng2018_430-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPh&#432;&#417;ng2018-430">[424]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/V_Live_(website)" title="V Live (website)">V Live</a>, which is a South Korean live video streaming service also collaborated with RBW Entertainment Vietnam (a subsidiary of <a href="/wiki/RBW_(company)" title="RBW (company)">the Korean entertainment company</a>) to produce Vietnamese-based shows. V Live also launched special monthly mini-concerts called "V Heartbeat Live" to connect V-pop and K-pop idols.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEQu&#7889;c_Ho&#224;ng2018_431-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEQu&#7889;c_Ho&#224;ng2018-431">[425]</a></sup> Furthermore, South Korean entertainment company <a href="/wiki/SM_Entertainment" title="SM Entertainment">SM Entertainment</a> signed an agreement with IPP Group to advance into the country&#8217;s market and promote joint business.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESM_Entertainment_Group2018_432-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESM_Entertainment_Group2018-432">[426]</a></sup> The company held its 2018 Global Audition in both Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City in search for new talents among the Vietnamese youth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDam-young2018_433-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDam-young2018-433">[427]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ca_tr%C3%B9_performance.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1135" data-file-width="1545" decoding="async" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Ca_tr%C3%B9_performance.jpg/220px-Ca_tr%C3%B9_performance.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Ca_tr%C3%B9_performance.jpg/330px-Ca_tr%C3%B9_performance.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Ca_tr%C3%B9_performance.jpg/440px-Ca_tr%C3%B9_performance.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ca_tr%C3%B9_performance.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ca_tr%C3%B9" title="Ca tr&#249;">Ca tr&#249;</a> trio performance in northern Vietnam</div></div></div>\n<p>Traditional Vietnamese music varies between the country\'s northern and southern regions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEvan_Kh&#232;1972_434-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEvan_Kh&#232;1972-434">[428]</a></sup> Northern classical music is Vietnam\'s oldest musical form and is traditionally more formal. The origins of Vietnamese classical music can be traced since the Mongol invasions in the 13th century when the Vietnamese captured a <a href="/wiki/Chinese_opera" title="Chinese opera">Chinese opera</a> troupe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiettinen1992163_435-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiettinen1992163-435">[429]</a></sup> Throughout its history, Vietnamese has been the most heavily impacted by the <a href="/wiki/Music_of_China" title="Music of China">Chinese musical tradition</a> as an integral part along with Japan, <a href="/wiki/Korea" title="Korea">Korea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mongolia" title="Mongolia">Mongolia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Kh&#234;1985_436-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Kh&#234;1985-436">[430]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Nh%C3%A3_nh%E1%BA%A1c" title="Nh&#227; nh&#7841;c">Nh&#227; nh&#7841;c</a></i> is the most popular form of imperial court music, <i><a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A8o" title="Ch&#232;o">Ch&#232;o</a></i> is a form of generally satirical <a href="/wiki/Musical_theatre" title="Musical theatre">musical theatre</a> while <i><a href="/wiki/X%E1%BA%A9m" title="X&#7849;m">X&#7849;m</a></i> or <i>h&#225;t x&#7849;m</i> (x&#7849;m singing) is a type of Vietnamese <a href="/wiki/Folk_music" title="Folk music">folk music</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Quan_h%E1%BB%8D" title="Quan h&#7885;">Quan h&#7885;</a></i> (alternate singing) is popular in the former <a href="/wiki/H%C3%A0_B%E1%BA%AFc_Province" title="H&#224; B&#7855;c Province">H&#224; B&#7855;c Province</a> (which is now divided into <a href="/wiki/B%E1%BA%AFc_Ninh_Province" title="B&#7855;c Ninh Province">B&#7855;c Ninh</a> and <a href="/wiki/B%E1%BA%AFc_Giang_Province" title="B&#7855;c Giang Province">B&#7855;c Giang</a> Provinces) and across Vietnam. Another form of music called <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hat_chau_van" title="Hat chau van">H&#225;t ch&#7847;u v&#259;n</a></i> or <i>h&#225;t v&#259;n</i> is used to invoke spirits during ceremonies. <i><a href="/wiki/Nh%E1%BA%A1c_d%C3%A2n_t%E1%BB%99c_c%E1%BA%A3i_bi%C3%AAn" title="Nh&#7841;c d&#226;n t&#7897;c c&#7843;i bi&#234;n">Nh&#7841;c d&#226;n t&#7897;c c&#7843;i bi&#234;n</a></i> is a modern form of Vietnamese <a href="/wiki/Folk_music" title="Folk music">folk music</a> which arose in the 1950s while <i><a href="/wiki/Ca_tr%C3%B9" title="Ca tr&#249;">ca tr&#249;</a></i> (also known as <i>h&#225;t &#7843; &#273;&#224;o</i>) is a popular folk music. "H&#242;" can not be thought of as the southern style of <i>quan h&#7885;</i>. There are a range of traditional instruments, including the <i><a href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%A0n_b%E1%BA%A7u" title="&#272;&#224;n b&#7847;u">&#273;&#224;n b&#7847;u</a></i> (a monochord zither), the <i><a href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%A0n_g%C3%A1o" title="&#272;&#224;n g&#225;o">&#273;&#224;n g&#225;o</a></i> (a two-stringed fiddle with coconut body), and the <i><a href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%A0n_nguy%E1%BB%87t" title="&#272;&#224;n nguy&#7879;t">&#273;&#224;n nguy&#7879;t</a></i> (a two-stringed fretted moon lute. In recent times, there have been some efforts to mixing Vietnamese traditional music especially folk music with modern music to revive and promote national music in the modern context and educating the younger generations about Vietnam\'s traditional musical instruments and singing styles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVoice_of_Vietnam2018d_437-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVoice_of_Vietnam2018d-437">[431]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_cuisine" title="Vietnamese cuisine">Vietnamese cuisine</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cuisine_of_Vietnam.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="404" data-file-width="404" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Cuisine_of_Vietnam.jpg/220px-Cuisine_of_Vietnam.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Cuisine_of_Vietnam.jpg/330px-Cuisine_of_Vietnam.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/57/Cuisine_of_Vietnam.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cuisine_of_Vietnam.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Some of the notable Vietnamese cuisine, clockwise from top-right: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ph%E1%BB%9F" title="Ph&#7903;">ph&#7903; noodle</a>, ch&#232; th&#225;i fruit dessert, <a href="/wiki/Ch%E1%BA%A3_gi%C3%B2" title="Ch&#7843; gi&#242;">ch&#7843; gi&#242; spring roll</a> and <a href="/wiki/B%C3%A1nh_m%C3%AC" title="B&#225;nh m&#236;">b&#225;nh m&#236; sandwich</a>.</div></div></div>\n<p>Vietnamese cuisine traditionally features a combination of five fundamental taste "elements" (<a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese</a>: <i>ng&#361; v&#7883;</i>): spicy (metal), sour (wood), bitter (fire), salty (water) and sweet (earth).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Culture_Information_Network2014_438-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Culture_Information_Network2014-438">[432]</a></sup> Common ingredients include <a href="/wiki/Fish_sauce" title="Fish sauce">fish sauce</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shrimp_paste" title="Shrimp paste">shrimp paste</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soy_sauce" title="Soy sauce">soy sauce</a>, rice, fresh herbs, fruits and vegetables. Vietnamese recipes use <a href="/wiki/Cymbopogon" title="Cymbopogon">lemongrass</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ginger" title="Ginger">ginger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mentha" title="Mentha">mint</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vietnamese_mint" title="Vietnamese mint">Vietnamese mint</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eryngium_foetidum" title="Eryngium foetidum">long coriander</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saigon_cinnamon" title="Saigon cinnamon">Saigon cinnamon</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bird%27s_eye_chilli" title="Bird\'s eye chilli">bird\'s eye chilli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lime_(fruit)" title="Lime (fruit)">lime</a> and <a href="/wiki/Basil" title="Basil">basil</a> leaves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAustralia_Special_Broadcasting_Service2013_439-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAustralia_Special_Broadcasting_Service2013-439">[433]</a></sup> Traditional Vietnamese cooking is known for its fresh ingredients, minimal use of oil and reliance on herbs and vegetables where it is considered one of the healthiest cuisines worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECorapi2010_440-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECorapi2010-440">[434]</a></sup> The use of such meats as pork, beef and chicken was relatively limited in the past, and as a result freshwater fish, <a href="/wiki/Crustacean" title="Crustacean">crustaceans</a> particularly <a href="/wiki/Crab" title="Crab">crabs</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mollusc" title="Mollusc">molluscs</a> became widely used. Fish sauce, soy sauce, prawn sauce and limes are among the main flavouring ingredients. There is an estimate of 40 Vietnamese dishes with many are usually served as a norm in the country <a href="/wiki/Street_food" title="Street food">street food</a> culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEClarkMiller2017_441-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEClarkMiller2017-441">[435]</a></sup> Many notable Vietnamese dishes such as <i><a href="/wiki/B%C3%A1nh_cu%E1%BB%91n" title="B&#225;nh cu&#7889;n">b&#225;nh cu&#7889;n</a></i> (ride noodle roll), <i><a href="/wiki/B%C3%BAn_ri%C3%AAu" title="B&#250;n ri&#234;u">b&#250;n ri&#234;u</a></i> (rice vermicelli soup) and <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ph%E1%BB%9F" title="Ph&#7903;">ph&#7903;</a></i> noodles are originated from the north and were carried to central and southern Vietnam by northern migrants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENguyen2011_442-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENguyen2011-442">[436]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThakerBarton2012170_443-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThakerBarton2012170-443">[437]</a></sup> Local foods in the north are often less spicy than southern dishes as the colder northern climate limits the production and availability of spices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams2017_444-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams2017-444">[438]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Black_pepper" title="Black pepper">Black pepper</a> is used in place of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chilli_pepper" title="Chilli pepper">chillis</a> to produce spicy flavours. Vietnamese drinks in the south also are usually served cold with <a href="/wiki/Ice_cube" title="Ice cube">ice cube</a> especially during the annual hot seasons compared to the north where hot drinks are much more preferable in colder climate. Some examples of basic Vietnamese drinks include <i><a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_iced_coffee" title="Vietnamese iced coffee">c&#224; ph&#234; &#273;&#225;</a></i> (Vietnamese iced coffee), <i><a href="/wiki/Egg_coffee" title="Egg coffee">c&#224; ph&#234; tr&#7913;ng</a></i> (egg coffee), <i><a href="/wiki/Chanh_mu%E1%BB%91i" title="Chanh mu&#7889;i">chanh mu&#7889;i</a></i> (salted pickled lime juice), <i><a href="/wiki/C%C6%A1m_r%C6%B0%E1%BB%A3u" title="C&#417;m r&#432;&#7907;u">c&#417;m r&#432;&#7907;u</a></i> (glutinous rice wine), <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/N%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Bc_m%C3%ADa" title="N&#432;&#7899;c m&#237;a">n&#432;&#7899;c m&#237;a</a></i> (sugarcane juice) and <i><a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_lotus_tea" title="Vietnamese lotus tea">tr&#224; sen</a></i> (Vietnamese lotus tea).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBatruny2014_445-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBatruny2014-445">[439]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Vietnam" title="Media of Vietnam">Media of Vietnam</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vietnam_Television_logo_from_2013.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="273" data-file-width="663" decoding="async" height="91" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Vietnam_Television_logo_from_2013.svg/220px-Vietnam_Television_logo_from_2013.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Vietnam_Television_logo_from_2013.svg/330px-Vietnam_Television_logo_from_2013.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Vietnam_Television_logo_from_2013.svg/440px-Vietnam_Television_logo_from_2013.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vietnam_Television_logo_from_2013.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Vietnam_Television" title="Vietnam Television">Vietnam Television</a> (VTV), the main <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/State_television" title="State television">state television</a></div></div></div>\n<p>Vietnam\'s media sector is regulated by the government in accordance with the 2004 Law on Publication.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Assembly2004_446-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Assembly2004-446">[440]</a></sup> It is generally perceived that the country media sector is controlled by the government to follow the official communist party line, though some newspapers are relatively outspoken.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEXuan_Dinh2000_447-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEXuan_Dinh2000-447">[441]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDattaMendizabal2018_448-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDattaMendizabal2018-448">[442]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Voice_of_Vietnam" title="Voice of Vietnam">Voice of Vietnam</a> (VOV) is the official state-run national radio broadcasting service, broadcasting internationally via shortwave using rented transmitters in other countries and providing broadcasts from its website while <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_Television" title="Vietnam Television">Vietnam Television</a> (VTV) is the national television broadcasting company. Since 1997, Vietnam has extensively regulated public <a href="/wiki/Internet" title="Internet">internet</a> access using both legal and technical means. The resulting lockdown is widely referred to as the "<a href="/wiki/Internet_censorship_in_Vietnam" title="Internet censorship in Vietnam">Bamboo Firewall</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilkey2002_449-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilkey2002-449">[443]</a></sup> The collaborative project <a href="/wiki/OpenNet_Initiative" title="OpenNet Initiative">OpenNet Initiative</a> classifies Vietnam\'s level of online political censorship to be "pervasive",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOpenNet_Initiative2012_450-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOpenNet_Initiative2012-450">[444]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">Reporters Without Borders</a> (RWB) considers Vietnam to be one of 15 global "internet enemies".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReporters_Without_Borders_451-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReporters_Without_Borders-451">[445]</a></sup> Though the government of Vietnam maintains that such censorship is necessary to safeguard the country against obscene or sexual explicit content, many political and religious sensitive websites that was deemed to be undermining state authority are also being blocked.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBerkman_Klein_Center2006_452-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBerkman_Klein_Center2006-452">[446]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Holidays_and_festivals">Holidays and festivals</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Vietnam" title="Public holidays in Vietnam">Public holidays in Vietnam</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_festivals_in_Vietnam" title="List of festivals in Vietnam">List of festivals in Vietnam</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%C4%90%C3%A8n_k%C3%A9o_qu%C3%A2n.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/%C4%90%C3%A8n_k%C3%A9o_qu%C3%A2n.jpg/220px-%C4%90%C3%A8n_k%C3%A9o_qu%C3%A2n.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/%C4%90%C3%A8n_k%C3%A9o_qu%C3%A2n.jpg/330px-%C4%90%C3%A8n_k%C3%A9o_qu%C3%A2n.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/%C4%90%C3%A8n_k%C3%A9o_qu%C3%A2n.jpg/440px-%C4%90%C3%A8n_k%C3%A9o_qu%C3%A2n.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%C4%90%C3%A8n_k%C3%A9o_qu%C3%A2n.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Special <a href="/wiki/T%E1%BA%BFt" title="T&#7871;t">T&#7871;t</a> decoration in the country seen during the holiday</div></div></div>\n<p>The country has eleven national recognised holidays which includes the <a href="/wiki/New_Year" title="New Year">New Year</a>\'s Day on 1 January, Vietnamese New Year (<a href="/wiki/T%E1%BA%BFt" title="T&#7871;t">T&#7871;t</a>) from last day of the last lunar month to fifth day of the first <a href="/wiki/Lunar_calendar" title="Lunar calendar">lunar month</a>, <a href="/wiki/H%C3%B9ng_Kings%27_Festival" title="H&#249;ng Kings\' Festival">Hung Kings Commemorations</a> on 10th day of the third lunar month, <a href="/wiki/Reunification_Day" title="Reunification Day">Day of liberating the South for national reunification</a> on 30 April, <a href="/wiki/International_Workers%27_Day" title="International Workers\' Day">International Workers\' Day</a> on 1 May and <a href="/wiki/National_Day_(Vietnam)" title="National Day (Vietnam)">National Day Celebration</a> on 2 September.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENational_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_Vietnam2012_453-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENational_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_Vietnam2012-453">[447]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETravel201737_454-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETravel201737-454">[448]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELoan2018_455-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELoan2018-455">[449]</a></sup> During T&#7871;t, many Vietnamese from the major cities will return to their villages for family reunions and praying for dead ancestors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnh2016b_456-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnh2016b-456">[450]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrieu_Dan201792_457-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrieu_Dan201792-457">[451]</a></sup> Older people will usually give the young a <i><a href="/wiki/Red_envelope" title="Red envelope">l&#236; x&#236;</a></i> (red envelope) while special holiday food of <i><a href="/wiki/B%C3%A1nh_ch%C6%B0ng" title="B&#225;nh ch&#432;ng">b&#225;nh ch&#432;ng</a></i> (rice cake) in a square shape together with variety of <a href="/wiki/Dried_fruit" title="Dried fruit">dried fruits</a> as the festival <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sweets" title="Sweets">sweets</a> are presented in the house for visitors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPike2018_458-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPike2018-458">[452]</a></sup> Many other festivals are celebrated throughout the <a href="/wiki/Season" title="Season">seasons</a> in a year including the <a href="/wiki/Lantern_Festival" title="Lantern Festival">Lantern Festival</a> (<i>T&#7871;t Nguy&#234;n Ti&#234;u</i>), <a href="/wiki/Mid-Autumn_Festival" title="Mid-Autumn Festival">Mid-Autumn Festival</a> (<i>T&#7871;t Trung Thu</i>) and various temple and nature festivals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETravel201734_459-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETravel201734-459">[453]</a></sup> In the highlands, Elephant Race Festival are held annually during the <a href="/wiki/Spring_(season)" title="Spring (season)">spring</a> where riders will ride their elephants for about 1.6 kilometres with the winning elephant will be given sugarcane.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEnglar200623_460-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEnglar200623-460">[454]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Vietnamese_wedding" title="Traditional Vietnamese wedding">Traditional Vietnamese weddings</a> remain widely popular and are often celebrated by <a href="/wiki/Overseas_Vietnamese" title="Overseas Vietnamese">expatriate Vietnamese</a> in Western countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAndersonLee2005217_461-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAndersonLee2005217-461">[455]</a></sup> In Vietnam, the dressing have been influenced by Western styles with the wearing of white <a href="/wiki/Wedding_dress" title="Wedding dress">wedding dresses</a> and black <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tuxedo" title="Tuxedo">tuxedos</a> although there were also many who still preferring to choose Vietnamese traditional wedding costumes for traditional ceremonies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhanh2008_462-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhanh2008-462">[456]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Vietnam" title="Sport in Vietnam">Sport in Vietnam</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Vietnamese_traditional_games" title="List of Vietnamese traditional games">List of Vietnamese traditional games</a></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Vovinam" title="Vovinam">Vovinam</a>, <i>kim ke</i> and <i>b&#236;nh &#273;&#7883;nh</i> <a href="/wiki/Martial_arts" title="Martial arts">martial arts</a> are widespread in Vietnam,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGreen2001548_463-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGreen2001548-463">[457]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENghiaLuan2017_464-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENghiaLuan2017-464">[458]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a> is the country\'s most popular sport.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFourFourTwo2017_465-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFourFourTwo2017-465">[459]</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_national_football_team" title="Vietnam national football team">national team</a> won the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ASEAN_Football_Championship" title="ASEAN Football Championship">ASEAN Football Championship</a> twice in <a href="/wiki/2008_AFF_Championship" title="2008 AFF Championship">2008</a> and <a href="/wiki/2018_AFF_Championship" title="2018 AFF Championship">2018</a> and reaching the <a href="/wiki/2019_AFC_Asian_Cup_knockout_stage#Vietnam_vs_Japan" title="2019 AFC Asian Cup knockout stage">quarter-finals</a> of <a href="/wiki/2019_AFC_Asian_Cup" title="2019 AFC Asian Cup">2019 AFC Asian Cup</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChina_Daily2008_466-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChina_Daily2008-466">[460]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Saigon_Times_Daily2018_467-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Saigon_Times_Daily2018-467">[461]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGomes2019_468-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGomes2019-468">[462]</a></sup> its junior team of <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_national_under-23_football_team" title="Vietnam national under-23 football team">under-23</a> became the runners-up of <a href="/wiki/2018_AFC_U-23_Championship" title="2018 AFC U-23 Championship">2018 AFC U-23 Championship</a> and reach fourth place in <a href="/wiki/Football_at_the_2018_Asian_Games" title="Football at the 2018 Asian Games">2018 Asian Games</a> while the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_national_under-20_football_team" title="Vietnam national under-20 football team">under-20</a> managed to qualify the <a href="/wiki/2017_FIFA_U-20_World_Cup" title="2017 FIFA U-20 World Cup">2017 FIFA U-20 World Cup</a> for the first time in their football history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERick2018_469-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERick2018-469">[463]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYanJunLong2018_470-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYanJunLong2018-470">[464]</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_women%27s_national_football_team" title="Vietnam women\'s national football team">women team</a> also dominating the <a href="/wiki/Football_at_the_Southeast_Asian_Games#Women\'s_tournament" title="Football at the Southeast Asian Games">Southeast Asian Games</a> with main rival of <a href="/wiki/Thailand_women%27s_national_football_team" title="Thailand women\'s national football team">Thailand</a>. Other Western sports such as <a href="/wiki/Badminton" title="Badminton">badminton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">tennis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Volleyball" title="Volleyball">volleyball</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ping-pong" title="Ping-pong">ping-pong</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chess" title="Chess">chess</a> are also widely popular. Vietnam has participated in the <a href="/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games" title="Summer Olympic Games">Summer Olympic Games</a> since <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_at_the_1952_Summer_Olympics" title="Vietnam at the 1952 Summer Olympics">1952</a> when it competed as the State of Vietnam. After the partition of the country in 1954, only South Vietnam competed in the games, sending athletes to the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_at_the_1956_Summer_Olympics" title="Vietnam at the 1956 Summer Olympics">1956</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_at_the_1972_Summer_Olympics" title="Vietnam at the 1972 Summer Olympics">1972</a> Olympics. Since the reunification of Vietnam in 1976, it has competed as the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, attending every Summer Olympics from 1988 onwards. The present Vietnam Olympic Committee was formed in 1976 and recognised by the <a href="/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee" title="International Olympic Committee">International Olympic Committee</a> (IOC) in 1979.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEInternational_Olympic_Committee_471-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInternational_Olympic_Committee-471">[465]</a></sup> Vietnam has never participated in the <a href="/wiki/Winter_Olympic_Games" title="Winter Olympic Games">Winter Olympic Games</a>. In 2016, Vietnam participated in the <a href="/wiki/2016_Summer_Olympics" title="2016 Summer Olympics">2016 Summer Olympics</a> where they won their first <a href="/wiki/Gold_medal" title="Gold medal">gold medal</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESims2016_472-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESims2016-472">[466]</a></sup> In 2020, Vietnam will host the inaugural <a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">Formula One</a> Vietnam Grand Prix in the city of Hanoi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFormula_One2018_473-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFormula_One2018-473">[467]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>\n<table class="metadata mbox-small" role="presentation" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000">\n<tbody><tr>\n<td class="mbox-image"><img alt="" data-file-height="48" data-file-width="48" decoding="async" height="30" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Office-book.svg/30px-Office-book.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Office-book.svg/45px-Office-book.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Office-book.svg/60px-Office-book.svg.png 2x" width="30"/></td>\n<td class="mbox-text plainlist"><ul style="font-weight: bold">\n<li><a href="/wiki/Book:Vietnam" title="Book:Vietnam">Book: Vietnam</a></li>\n</ul></td></tr></tbody></table>\n<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Index_of_Vietnam-related_articles" title="Index of Vietnam-related src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Flag_of_Vietnam.svg/24px-Flag_of_Vietnam.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Flag_of_Vietnam.svg/36px-Flag_of_Vietnam.svg.png 1.5x, portal</a></span></li></ul></div>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Footnotes">Footnotes</span></h2>\n<div class="reflist columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 24em;
